texts: "It appears so, mon ami,” said Poirot cautiously. “Appearances are deceptive, they say, but it certainly appears so.” As we hurried in a taxi to the Magnificent, I puzzled out the true inwardness of the scheme. “That ‘full of the moon’ idea was clever. The whole point of it was to get us to concentrate on the Friday, and so be off our guard beforehand. It is a pity you did not realize that.” “Ma foi!” said Poirot airily, his nonchalance quite restored after its brief eclipse. “One cannot think of everything!” I felt sorry for him. He did so hate failure of any kind. “Cheer up,” I said consolingly. “Better luck next time.” At the Magnificent, we were ushered at once into the manager’s office.

There was only one diamond, my friend! Originally in the Yardly collection, for three years it has been in the possession of Mr. Rolf. He stole it this morning with the assistance of a touch of grease paint at the corner of each eye! Ah, I must see him on the film, he is indeed an artist, celui-là! “But why should he steal his own diamond?” I asked, puzzled. “For many reasons. To begin with, Lady Yardly was getting restive.” “Lady Yardly?” “You comprehend she was left much alone in California. Her husband was amusing himself elsewhere. Mr. Rolf was handsome, he had an air about him of romance.

Julius was interested. “What did the guy mean, do you think?” he asked. “I don’t quite know,” said Tuppence meditatively. “But I think that, in an ambiguous, legal, without prejudishish lawyer’s way, he was trying to warn me.” “Why should he?” “I don’t know,” confessed Tuppence.

Pagett left the table half-way through the meal, which annoyed me, as I had planned to say goodbye to him. However, doubtless Sir Eustace would do as well. I went over to him when I had finished. “Good-bye, Sir Eustace,” I said. “I’m off to-night to Durban.” Sir Eustace sighed heavily. “So I heard. You wouldn’t like me to come with you, would you?” “I should love it.” “Nice girl. Sure you won’t change your mind and come and look for lions in Rhodesia?” “Quite sure.” “He must be a very handsome fellow,” said Sir Eustace plaintively.

I have heard of you from several quarters, and all reports go to show that you are not only a man of decided ability, but one who also knows how to be discreet. I do not wish to trust details to the post, but, on account of a secret I possess, I go in daily fear of my life.

Japp closed one eye knowingly. “No, indeed. Pretty clear case I should say.” But Poirot answered gravely: “There I differ from you.” “Oh, come!” said Summerhaye, opening his lips for the first time. “Surely the whole thing is clear as daylight. The man’s caught red-handed.

Since then he had been hand and glove with those sworn to hunt him down. Every secret of theirs has been known to him. Only once did he come near disaster. Mrs. Vandemeyer knew his secret. It was no part of his plan that that huge bribe should ever be offered to her.

I don’t know what bêche-de-mer is, I never have known, I probably never shall know. I’ve guessed once or twice and guessed wrong. In South Africa I know you at once begin to talk about a stoep_ I do know what a stoep is it’s the thing round a house and you sit on it. In various other parts of the world you call it a veranda, a piazza, and a ha-ha. Then again, there are pawpaws. I had often read of pawpaws. I discovered at once what they were, because I had one plumped down in front of me for breakfast. I thought at first that it was a melon gone bad. The Dutch waitress enlightened me, and persuaded me to use lemon juice and sugar and try again. I was very pleased to meet a pawpaw.

No, I can’t say I am.” “Will you read this letter, M. Renauld? And tell me if you have any idea as to who the person was who addressed it to your father?” Jack Renauld took the letter, and read it through, the colour mounting in his face as he did so.

Why would any one return them to you that way in the middle of the night? It’s a mad idea. No they were a message, the films had been taken out of the yellow tin case, and something else put inside. Have you got it still?” “I may have used it. No, here it is. I remember I tossed it into the rack at the side of the bunk.” She held it out to me. It was an ordinary round tin cylinder, such as films are packed in for the tropics.

Everything was still. The moonlight came in through a window and showed me the dusty uncarpeted staircase. Cautiously I crept down it. Still no sound but as I stood on the landing below, a faint murmur of voices reached me. I stopped dead and stood there for some time. A clock on the wall registered the fact that it was after midnight. I was fully aware of the risks I might run if I descended lower, but my curiosity was too much for me. With infinite precautions I prepared to explore. I crept softly down the last flight of stairs and stood in the square hall. I looked round me and then caught my breath with a gasp.

Moth balls again! I held the paper gingerly to my nose. Yes, it smelt strongly of them. But, then I folded up the paper carefully and put it in my bag. I walked home slowly and did a good deal of thinking. I explained to Mrs. Flemming that I had witnessed a nasty accident in the Tube and that I was rather upset and would go to my room and lie down. The kind woman insisted on my having a cup of tea. After that I was left to my own devices, and I proceeded to carry out a plan I had formed coming home. I wanted to know what it was that had produced that curious feeling of unreality whilst I was watching the doctor examine the body.

Suddenly an idea struck me. “Poirot!” I cried. “This is a fragment of a will!” “Exactly.” I looked up at him sharply. “You are not surprised?” “No,” he said gravely, “I expected it.” I relinquished the piece of paper, and watched him put it away in his case, with the same methodical care that he bestowed on everything. My brain was in a whirl.

The idea of suicide seems impossible. She was one of those energetic young women who are in love with life, and have not the faintest intention of quitting it. There was no train either way until midday on the morrow, so she can’t have left the place. Then where the devil is she? Race is almost beside himself, poor fellow. He has left no stone unturned. My faith in Poirot revived a little. It occupied the same position in the building as that of the Robinsons, but was two floors higher. The day after our installation was a Sunday. In the afternoon, Poirot left the front door ajar, and summoned me hastily as a bang reverberated from somewhere below. “Look over the banisters. Are those your friends. Do not let them see you.” I craned my neck over the staircase. “That’s them,” I declared in an ungrammatical whisper.

A crash of crockery came from the attic above. In a trice the men were pushing each other up the rickety ladder and had disappeared into the darkness above. Quick as a flash Tommy leapt from his hiding-place and dashed down the stairs, pulling the girl with him. There was no one in the hall. He fumbled over the bolts and chain. At last they yielded, the door swung open. He turned. Annette had disappeared. Tommy stood spell-bound. Had she run upstairs again? What madness possessed her! He fumed with impatience, but he stood his ground.

There were plenty of books in the villa, and delightful rambles all around, but I chafed sometimes at the forced inactivity of our life, and marvelled at Poirot's state of placid content. Nothing occurred to ruffle our quiet existence, and it was not until the end of June, well within the limit that Poirot had given them, that we had our news of the Big Four. A car drove up to the villa early one morning, such an unusual event in our peaceful life that I hurried down to satisfy my curiosity. I found Poirot talking to a pleasant-faced young fellow of about my own age. He introduced me.

Madame Beroldy lay on the floor, bound hand and foot, uttering feeble moans, having managed to free her mouth from a gag. On the bed was Monsieur Beroldy, lying in a pool of blood, with a knife driven through his heart. Madame Beroldy’s story was clear enough. Suddenly awakened from sleep, she had discerned two masked men bending over her. Stifling her cries, they had bound and gagged her. They had then demanded of Monsieur Beroldy the famous “secret.

Everybody swore that no one had been to Granite Bungalow that morning, but, nevertheless, I found in the larder a leg of mutton, still frozen. It was Monday, so the meat must have been delivered that morning; for if on Saturday, in this hot weather, it would not have remained frozen over Sunday. So some one had been to the Bungalow, and a man on whom a trace of blood here and there would attract no attention." "Damned ingenious!" cried Ingles approvingly. "Yes, he is clever, Number Four." We were hurried through the woods at a break-neck pace, going uphill the whole time. At last we emerged in the open, on the mountain-side, and I saw just in front of us an extraordinary conglomeration of fantastic rocks and boulders. This must be the Felsenlabyrynth of which Harvey had spoken. Soon we were winding in and out of its recesses. The place was like a maze devised by some evil genie. Suddenly we stopped. An enormous rock barred our path.

) Man is an unoriginal animal. Unoriginal within the law in his daily respectable life, equally unoriginal outside the law. If a man commits a crime, any other crime he commits will resemble it closely. The English murderer who disposed of his wives in succession by drowning them in their baths was a case in point. Had he varied his methods, he might have escaped detection to this day. But he obeyed the common dictates of human nature, arguing that what had once succeeded would succeed again, and he paid the penalty of his lack of originality.

I rose cautiously, scanning the shadows for any sign of movement. With delicate fingers, I removed a portrait of Marguerite holding a casket of jewels from the wall. With the help of some adhesive from the envelopes, I reattached the brown paper, ensuring no one would suspect a thing.

As I entered the sitting-room designated for us, I saw Poirot already there, pacing back and forth with a pained expression on his face.

Jack rushed to catch his train in Paris after a heated argument. Léonie, who witnessed his departure, couldn't understand the cause of the dispute due to the language barrier. Poirot handed back the worn English letter with a grave face. The magistrate assumed that M. Renauld was involved with an Englishwoman named Bella, leading to jealousy and threats. The masked men and the mysterious letter further complicated the investigation. The magistrate suggested looking into M. Renauld's past in Santiago for clues to his murder. Poirot agreed, praising the idea. The magistrate also mentioned involving M. Renauld's wife in the investigation and confirmed that there were no other letters from Bella among M. Poirot and I sat on the grassy knoll facing the sea, reviewing the case of Jack Renauld. I pondered over the details, considering Madame Daubreuil's connection to the Beroldy Case. Suddenly, a thought struck me - Georges Conneau. Poirot was impressed by my revelation, encouraging me to continue. We assumed Conneau was alive and had a vendetta against Renauld, leading to a fatal encounter. Madame Daubreuil's involvement and a cover-up scheme unfolded in my theory. Poirot, however, pointed out the unrealistic aspects of my reconstruction, suggesting it belonged in the movies. I defended my theory, but Poirot's skepticism lingered.

"Poirot, what do you make of this?" I asked, watching as he scanned the letter with intense concentration. After a moment, he looked up and replied thoughtfully, "It appears to be a classic case of deception and betrayal. The question is, who is the true mastermind behind it all?" I nodded, pondering his words. "Do you think it's someone close to the victim?" I inquired. Poirot's eyes gleamed with a hint of mischief. "Ah, but in matters of crime, my dear Hastings, one must always consider all possibilities. Even those that seem most unlikely."

I found myself staring ahead, a sense of confusion settling in. Norman and I were a formidable pair, capable of handling any challenge. Gradually, as the car decelerated, the familiar sights of Hendon Aerodrome came into view. Poirot's plan became clear to me in an instant - we were to fly to France. While bold, the idea seemed impractical at first glance. Sending a telegram would undoubtedly be faster. Time was of the essence, and Poirot would have to forego the personal accolades of saving the Prime Minister. As we came to a stop, Major Norman exited the vehicle, replaced by an undercover officer.

I had been dancing with Colonel Race several times that evening and we eventually ended up sitting in deck-chairs, engaged in conversation. As I retired to my cabin that night, I couldn't shake the feeling that he might have been testing me, perhaps suspecting that I was not who I claimed to be. It was a puzzling thought that lingered in my mind as I drifted off to sleep.

As various individuals attempted to make small talk in the casual setting of a boat, I couldn't help but notice how Mrs. Blair skillfully rebuffed their advances. The unexpected arrival of Bella threatens to derail his carefully orchestrated scheme, forcing him to act quickly to eliminate her interference. With every passing moment crucial to the success of his plan, Renauld wastes no time in dispatching Bella and setting in motion the next phase of his deadly plot. Leaving the front door slightly open, he skillfully manipulates the scene to divert attention from his true intentions.

“Did you find anything in Renauld’s belongings?” inquired Poirot. “We conducted a thorough search of his study, sifting through his personal papers. Unfortunately, we came up empty-handed. Everything appeared to be in order and nothing caught our attention, except for his will. Take a look.” Poirot quickly perused the document. “I see. A generous bequest of a thousand pounds to Mr. Stonor – do you know who he is?” “He was Mr. Renauld’s secretary. Although he primarily resided in England, he did visit here occasionally for short periods.” “And the rest of his estate was bequeathed to his dear wife, Eloise. The will is simple, yet legally binding.”

"The truth is undeniable. But how did you come by this information?" Marthe questioned with a hint of embarrassment. Poirot's face twisted in displeasure. "Secrecy is non-existent in cases like this! However, it makes no difference. So, what are you curious about, mademoiselle?" After a moment of hesitation, the girl finally gathered the courage to ask, almost in a hushed tone: "Has anyone been singled out as a suspect?" Poirot observed her intently before responding vaguely, "Suspicions are circulating, mademoiselle."

The young woman is quite astute. Single-handedly, it seems, she has uncovered the true identity of the deceased woman found in my residence. The victim was a Russian performer named Nadina. When I inquired with Anne Beddingfeld about the accuracy of this information, she claimed it was a deduction in the style of Sherlock Holmes. Nevertheless, it appears she has already sent this information to Nasby as an established fact. Women possess these instincts, and I am confident that Anne Beddingfeld's assumption is correct, although labeling it a deduction is preposterous. How she secured a position at the Daily Budget is beyond my comprehension.

He remained motionless, his eyes shut tight, only the slightest rise and fall of his chest indicating that he was still alive. A doctor monitored his pulse, his expression grave. "He's fading fast," he murmured. "You recognize him, don't you?" I shook my head. "I've never crossed paths with him." "Then why does he have your name and address in his possession? You are Captain Hastings, correct?" "Yes, but I'm just as puzzled as you are." "Strange. According to his documents, he was in the service of a man named Ingles, a retired government official. You're familiar with him, aren't you?" he asked sharply, noticing my reaction to the name. Ingles's servant! Suddenly, it clicked - I had encountered him before.

They were a striking pair, the tall, dark young man and the blonde beauty standing together. Despite the dark cloud of tragedy hanging over them, they exuded happiness. The girl appeared uneasy, a fact not lost on Jack Renauld, who pulled her in closer and inquired, "What troubles you, my love? What haunts you now?" As she gazed back with the same fearful expression Poirot had mentioned, she whispered softly, almost revealing her thoughts, "I fear for your safety."

"We need incriminating evidence to stop the Cabinet from turning against him so easily. What do you know about the other individuals involved? You mentioned recognizing two of them, right? Is one of them affiliated with the Labour party? Take a look at these pictures and see if you can identify him." Shortly after, Tommy presented a photograph. Mr. Carter appeared taken aback. "Ah, Westway! I wouldn't have guessed. Tries to come off as moderate. And as for the other person, I have a strong suspicion." Passing another picture to Tommy, he grinned at the ensuing reaction. "I was correct, then. Who is he? An Irishman. Well-known Unionist M.P. It's all a façade, obviously."

And the moral of the story is that a criminal's lack of originality will be their downfall. They will repeat the same crime in the same way, leading to their inevitable capture. This lack of creativity in criminal behavior is a key clue for detectives like Hercule Poirot. The small details, like a wristwatch gaining two hours or footprints in a flower-bed, can reveal the true identity of the criminal behind the acts. When Gabriel Stonor, the well-travelled secretary, enters the scene, his connections and insights shed new light on the case. His lack of knowledge about certain names and incidents, like Duveen and Bella, only adds to the mystery at hand. The truth is out there, waiting to be uncovered.

"It's a small, elegant spot nestled between Bolougne and Calais. Lately, it's been gaining popularity among wealthy Brits seeking tranquility. Does M. Renauld own property in England?" "Yes, in Rutland Gate, and a sizable estate in Hertfordshire. Not much is known about him socially. He's rumored to have significant business dealings in South America, primarily in Chile and Argentina." "We'll find out more from the man directly. Let's get ready to leave."

Pagett abruptly left the table midway through dinner, leaving me slightly irritated since I had intended to bid him farewell. However, I assumed Sir Eustace could serve the same purpose. After finishing my meal, I approached Sir Eustace. "Farewell, Sir Eustace," I declared. "I depart for Durban tonight." Sir Eustace let out a weary sigh. "Yes, I heard about your plans. Would you prefer some company on your journey?" "I would appreciate it." "Lovely girl. Are you absolutely certain you wouldn't rather join me in searching for lions in Rhodesia?" "Absolutely." "The man must be quite dashing," Sir Eustace remarked with a hint of sadness.

"It occurred to me at that moment that despite my willingness to sacrifice myself, I should have at least been consulted. Then I recalled Poirot's insistence that I remain behind, which eased my mind. "And how exactly will sacrificing yourself benefit anyone?" Ryland asked sarcastically. "You clearly do not grasp the true depth of Hercule's strategy. For starters, your hiding place was discovered months ago, and nearly everyone around – from hotel staff to visitors – is a detective or Secret Service agent. The mountain is surrounded. You may think you have multiple escape routes, but there is no way out."

"He was unfamiliar with Hercule Poirot's techniques. Unlike Poirot, he preferred to work internally, relying on his intuition and intellect rather than frantic legwork. This approach, he believed, was more effective. Poirot's dismissive attitude towards certain investigative methods sparked a debate. While fingerprints had indeed solved cases, Poirot pointed out the potential for wrongful convictions. His skepticism was met with resistance."

We managed to track down Joseph Aarons, the theatrical agent, after a long search. He recognized the name Bella Duveen as one of the Dulcibella Kids, a pair of acrobat and singer sisters currently performing in Coventry. Poirot decided to attend their variety show, where he saw them perform and recognized Cinderella as one of the sisters. After the show, Cinderella approached us in fear, confessing that she was the one who took the dagger and asking if we would turn her in to the police. In a surprising turn of events, I declared my love for her and promised to protect her.

As soon as the crash of crockery echoed from the attic above, the men sprang into action, scrambling up the creaky ladder and vanishing into the shadows. Without hesitation, Tommy bolted from his concealment, hurtling down the staircase and dragging the girl along. The hall was empty. Frantically, he struggled with the locks until they finally gave way, the door swinging open. Whirling around, he found Annette gone. A mix of confusion and frustration washed over Tommy. Why would she go back upstairs? Anger boiled within him, yet he remained steadfast in his position.

" Tommy stopped suddenly. A moment of silence passed. “By the way,” Julius interjected, “you're mistaken about Jane's photo. It was taken from me, but I recovered it.” “Where?” Tuppence exclaimed. “In the small safe on Mrs. Vandemeyer's bedroom wall.” “I knew you discovered something,” Tuppence said accusingly. “To be honest, that's what made me start suspecting you. Why keep it to yourself?” “I suppose I was a bit suspicious as well."

On the following night, Tommy ventured out alone to investigate the area surrounding the house. Despite his efforts to move quietly, he couldn't help but make more noise than he intended. As he approached the dining-room window, he saw a group of people inside, enjoying a drink together. The scene was calm and peaceful, far from the danger he had anticipated.

The clever heroine always found herself in the clutches of the Master Criminal, facing death in unusual ways. Fortunately, the hero always came to her rescue just in time. One day, Papa was in a frenzy over the discovery of an ancient skull. He insisted on an immediate trip to explore the area, despite financial concerns. Papa's focus on science clashed with practical matters, leaving Anne to sort out the details. The prospect of an adventure in Rhodesia excited Anne, but she couldn't help noticing her father's mismatched boots.

"Ingles examined the Chinese pottery pieces with great interest. Poirot inquired, "You seem uninterested in this investigation, monsieur?" The man smiled slowly and replied, "It's not my expertise. I appreciate art, but not this. I prefer to observe from a distance. My time in the East taught me patience." The Inspector entered, apologizing for the delay. After going over the details again, we were able to leave. Poirot thanked the Inspector, saying, "I am grateful for your many kindnesses. There is one more favor I wish to ask of you."

After thoroughly inspecting the table and its precise placement, he requested to examine the chess pieces. They were brought to him by Sonia Daviloff in a decorative box. He casually looked over a couple of them. "A truly exquisite set," he commented absentmindedly. There was no inquiry about the refreshments served or the guests in attendance. I tried to speak up, but he cut me off abruptly. "Do not trouble yourself with thoughts, my dear friend. Leave everything to me. Mademoiselle, is there any chance I could speak with your uncle?" A slight smile appeared on her lips. "He will be available to see you, yes. Just so you know, it is my duty to speak with all visitors first."

Poirot and I sat on the grassy knoll, overlooking the sea, reviewing the case. The bathers' cries reached us faintly, the sea pale blue in the calm. Poirot encouraged me to arrange my ideas methodically. Madame Daubreuil's connection with the Beroldy Case was key. I had a sudden epiphany about Georges Conneau. Poirot embraced me warmly, impressed. I theorized that Conneau, driven by old grievances, had killed Renauld. Madame Daubreuil was involved, and Jack Renauld had been manipulated. Poirot appreciated the story but pointed out the lack of realism in my reconstruction. I defended my theory, suggesting Conneau had obtained clothes and money from Madame Daubreuil. Poirot disagreed, questioning the plausibility of my supposition.

This clarifies the reason for their willingness to hand over everything to Halliday so easily. Madame Olivier was the dominant force, with Vera Rossakoff as her right-hand woman. Madame required Halliday's concepts, while she possessed the brilliance to fill in the gaps that confounded him. Indeed, Hastings, we are now aware of the true identity of Number Three - the woman who may be the most brilliant scientist in existence! Consider that. The intellect of the East, the technology of the West, and two others whose names remain a mystery. However, we must uncover them. Tomorrow, we shall journey back to London and commence our investigation.

"The words were sharp, cutting through the tense air like a knife. Tommy’s eyes shot up in surprise. Julius seemed on edge, a mix of nerves and excitement evident in his trembling hand as he brought the glass to his lips. Despite his defiance, he eventually averted his gaze, conceding defeat. “For now, you have the upper hand,” he muttered. “Thank you,” replied the other calmly. “Shall we settle for ten o’clock?” With a smooth transition, he redirected his attention to Tommy. “I must admit, Mr. Smith, I am intrigued by your proposal.”

"Sentiment means everything to a woman, does it not? But a man like you, who lacks such delicate sensibilities, may find some small comfort in that fact." "Of course, of course," Mr. Opalsen replied, somewhat uncertainly. "Still..." His words were cut off by a triumphant shout from the inspector. He entered the room, holding something between his fingers. Mrs. Opalsen sprang up from her seat with a cry. She looked like a different person. "Oh, my necklace!" she exclaimed, holding it tightly to her chest. We all gathered around her. "Where was it?" Opalsen demanded. "In the maid's bed."

Inadvertently, Mademoiselle Marthe revealed the truth about another matter, contradicting Jack Renauld in the process. His noticeable pause when questioned about seeing Marthe Daubreuil on the night of the crime raised suspicions of deceit. To confirm my doubts, I needed to speak with Mademoiselle Marthe before Jack could warn her. Just three simple words from her provided the crucial information I sought. When I inquired if she was aware of Jack Renauld's presence that night, her response was simply, "He informed me."

"I need those documents before I release you," the voice demanded. Tommy chuckled, "Do you expect me to find them while I'm chained up here?"   "What's your proposal, then?"   "I require freedom to handle this situation as I see fit."  The German scoffed, "Do you take us for fools? We won't let you stroll out of here with just words."  Tommy pondered for a moment, "I knew you wouldn't agree to that. Let's find a middle ground."

Tuppence couldn't help but feel a sense of satisfaction at outsmarting the other taxi driver. She quickly took note of his number, planning to send him a postal order the next day to cover any damages. Suddenly, there was a loud grinding noise followed by a jarring bump as another taxi collided with theirs. Without missing a beat, Tuppence was out of the taxi and handing the driver five shillings before disappearing into the crowd with Jane. As they made their way through the bustling streets, Tuppence couldn't help but feel the thrill of the chase.

"It certainly is," Tuppence drawled, "especially with old man Rysdale's backing. But don't worry, kid. If this pans out, you'll be in from the beginning." With that assurance, she said goodbye to her new partner and strode energetically away from South Audley Mansions, pleased with her morning's accomplishments. However, time was of the essence. She headed straight back to the Ritz and penned a brief message to Mr. Carter. After sending it off, and with Tommy still not back, which was no surprise, she embarked on a shopping spree that included a break for tea and various creamy pastries, keeping her busy until well past six o'clock. By the time she returned to the hotel, she was weary but content with her acquisitions.

"Are you joining me?" Tommy shook his head. "What's the point? One of us should be sufficient. I'll stick around here a bit longer and snoop. You never know what might pop up." "Alright then. See you soon. I'll return shortly with some inspectors. I'll make sure to choose the sharpest and most skilled." However, events did not unfold as Julius had anticipated. Later that day, Tommy received a telegram: "Meet me at Manchester Midland Hotel. Urgent news JULIUS." At 7:30 that evening, Tommy got off a sluggish train from the countryside. Julius was waiting on the platform. "Figured you'd take this train if you didn't receive my telegram in time."

Poirot spent only a brief moment at each stop, yet his confidence seemed to grow with each one. He exchanged a few words with Norman, who pointed towards a side road saying, "They are waiting by the bridge if you go left." As we veered off onto the side road, I noticed a second car parked along the roadside in the dwindling light. Two men in civilian clothing sat inside. Poirot stepped out and conversed with them briefly before we set off towards the north, with the other car trailing closely behind.

I reached my destination early the next morning, where I was greeted by a mysterious Dutchman with a short black beard. Without a word, he ushered me into a waiting car and we sped off. In the distance, a strange booming sound echoed through the air, prompting me to inquire about its origin. "Guns," was his curt reply. The realization that there was conflict in Jo'burg sent a thrill through me. Our target, it seemed, lay hidden somewhere in the city's suburbs. With each turn and detour we took, the sound of gunfire grew louder, heightening the tension. Finally, we came to a stop in front of a rundown building.

"She entered the building, and I chatted with the lady at the front desk, acting as if I was accompanying her. Eventually, I made my way inside as well." He paused, the room filled with an uneasy quiet. "You have to trust me, Anne. I swear on my life that everything I'm about to tell you is the truth. I followed her into the building with vengeance on my mind, only to discover her lifeless body! I stumbled upon her in that upstairs room, it was a sight straight from hell. Lifeless, and yet I had barely missed her by mere minutes. And there was no trace of another soul in sight! I instantly grasped the dire situation I found myself in."

The doctor repeatedly pressed the doorbell, but there was no response from inside. Frustrated, he turned to the lift attendant and inquired about a pass-key. The attendant mentioned one being in the porter's office downstairs. Poirot suggested calling the police, which the doctor agreed with. After a short absence, the attendant returned with the manager, who demanded an explanation for the commotion. The doctor explained that they had received a distressing call from Count Foscatini, claiming he had been assaulted and was in critical condition.

"I couldn't believe my eyes as I examined the thick paper in front of me. It didn't seem like the usual notepaper at all. A sudden realization hit me like a ton of bricks. "Poirot!" I exclaimed. "This is a piece of a will!" "Precisely." His response caught me off guard. "You're not shocked?" "No," he replied seriously, "I anticipated it." Handing over the fragment, I observed as he meticulously stored it in his case, just as he did with everything else. My mind was racing with questions."

The wind howled outside, sending chills down my spine. With a creak, the door to the room swung open, causing her to gasp in fear. "This door must be cursed!" exclaimed Poirot, frustration evident in his voice. He rose to shut it firmly, securing it with a key. "I will lock it like this!" "Please don't," she whispered, her voice filled with dread. But before she could finish, the unthinkable occurred. The locked door creaked open slowly, as if moved by an unseen force.

As the men gathered in the hall for breakfast, their voices echoed up the stairs, causing me great unease. I knew I had to remain patient in order to find a way out of the house without being caught. After breakfast, I heard the sounds of Chichester leaving, and to my relief, the Dutchman followed suit. Waiting anxiously, I took note as breakfast dishes were cleared and the household chores commenced. Finally, as the commotion subsided, I cautiously emerged from my hiding spot and stealthily made my way down the staircase.

The gun was yanked out of his grasp, and Julius Hersheimmer's voice drawled: “Looks like you've been caught red-handed with the loot.” The K.C.’s face flushed, but he maintained his composure, shifting his gaze between his two captors. His eyes lingered on Tommy. “You,” he muttered. “You! I should have guessed.” Sensing his lack of resistance, they loosened their hold. In a swift motion, his left hand, adorned with a large signet ring, moved to his lips. “‘Hail, Caesar! Those who are about to die salute you,’” he said, still staring at Tommy.

"The length of a clue, my friend, holds significance regardless of its size - a two-foot clue is just as crucial as one that measures two millimeters! It is a misconception that only tiny clues are important. As for the lead-piping, dismissing its relevance simply because Giraud said so is a mistake. Let us not discuss this further. Let Giraud continue his investigation, while I pursue my own thoughts. The case appears to be clear-cut, and yet, my friend, I am not convinced. Do you know why? It all comes back to the wristwatch that is two hours ahead. Additionally, there are a number of peculiar details that do not quite align."

"No, it wasn’t the paper. By the way, do you happen to have it on you? I would quite like to take a look at it." I had brought along the paper as Exhibit A, and I passed it to her. She examined it closely, her brow furrowed. “There’s a dot after the number 17. Why isn’t there a dot after the 1 as well?” “There's a gap,” I observed. “Indeed, there is a gap, but” Suddenly, she stood up and leaned over the paper, bringing it as close to the light as possible. There was a barely contained thrill in her demeanor. “Anne, that’s not a dot! It’s a defect in the paper! A defect in the paper, do you understand? Therefore, you must disregard it and focus solely on the spaces, the spaces!” I rose to my feet and stood beside her.

How much did Poirot really know? Was he aware that my fellow passenger on the train and Bella Duveen were one and the same person? What was the reason for his visit to the Hôtel du Phare? Was it truly on my behalf, as I had initially believed? Or was I simply being naive, and was there a more sinister motive behind his actions? Regardless, why was he so determined to locate this young woman? Did he suspect her involvement in Jack Renauld's murder? But that couldn't be possible! She had no reason to harm the victim, no motive for his death. So why did she return to the scene of the crime? I meticulously reviewed all the details.

The accusation was outrageous! To think that she would be implicated in stealing from Madame! The authorities were notoriously incompetent! However, Monsieur, a Frenchman "A Belgian," Poirot interjected, but Célestine ignored the correction. Monsieur refused to let her be wrongly blamed, especially when that scandalous chambermaid was walking free. She always distrusted her, a brazen, rosy-cheeked woman, clearly a thief. From the beginning, she had a feeling that she was untrustworthy.

"The audacious audacity of that diminutive fellow! Who but Poirot would have considered a murder trial as a means to reconcile a troubled marriage! "I can see the skepticism in your eyes, my friend," Poirot remarked with a grin. "Only Hercule Poirot could have concocted such a scheme! And you are mistaken in your disapproval. The joy of a single man and a single woman is the most precious treasure in the world." His statement triggered a wave of memories. I recalled Mary, pale and drained, reclining on the couch, her ears strained for every sound. Suddenly, the doorbell rang. She jolted upright. Poirot answered the door, exchanging a silent, reassuring glance with her."

"The master detective has not failed us yet," Hawker remarked, patting him on the back. "There is always something to ponder." "Indeed, there is," he replied. "Take, for instance, the door." "The door? But it was locked. No one could have entered or exited through it. I made sure of it." "And why were you so certain?" The doctor appeared confused. Poirot quickly clarified. "I am referring to the keyhole. It was not covered. Quite peculiar. And then there was the tea. It was exceptionally bitter." "So what?" "Exceptionally bitter," Poirot emphasized.

"Oh, what a beauty she is, cellela!” The elderly woman exclaimed with a hint of disdain. “Madame Daubreuil,” whispered the police commissioner in disbelief. “Inconceivable.” “Well, there you have it,” grumbled Françoise. “That's what happens when you speak the truth.” “Not necessarily,” the judge interjected calmly. “It was unexpected, that's all. So, Madame Daubreuil and Monsieur Renauld, they were...” he paused tactfully. “Ah? Was it truly them?” “Who's to say? But what can you do? Monsieur was a very wealthy English lord and Madame Daubreuil, despite her humble lifestyle, was quite elegant,” expressed the examining magistrate thoughtfully.

The Flemmings observed the Daily Budget, which was experiencing a day that resonated deeply with its essence. SHOCKING CONTINUATION OF SUBWAY TRAGEDY. FEMALE DISCOVERED FATALLY WOUNDED IN SECLUDED RESIDENCE. My eyes devoured the words. "An astounding revelation unfolded at the Mill House, Marlow yesterday. This very Mill House, belonging to Sir Eustace Pedler, M.P., is available for rent without furnishings, and a prospectus for touring the premises was discovered on the person initially presumed to have taken his own life by throwing himself onto the electrified track at Hyde Park Corner Tube Station."

"We need more information." "How so?" Poirot leaned back in his chair, adjusting a box of matches I had carelessly tossed on the table. I could tell he was gearing up to lecture. "Listen, Hastings, we are up against four opponents; four distinct personalities. We've never met Number One face-to-face, we only know him through his thoughts. And let me add, Hastings, I am starting to grasp his thoughts quite clearly - a cunning and Eastern mind. Every plan we've faced has come from Li Chang Yen's brilliant brain."

The room was adorned with curtains and portière in a muted green hue, perfectly complemented by the matching carpet. Poirot carefully surveyed the space, running his hand over the leather chairs, inspecting the magazine on the table, and lightly touching the oak sideboard. A look of satisfaction crossed his face. "No dust?" I teased. He smiled warmly, acknowledging my understanding of his preferences. "Not a speck, my friend! Though, perhaps, a bit unfortunate this time." His keen eyes scanned the room before he exclaimed, "Ah!" in a tone of relief.

"Suzanne carefully carved out a space, concealed the diamonds using cotton wool to muffle any noise, and sealed it back up.” Sir Eustace stared at me intently. His response was typical: “I've always despised that cursed giraffe,” he muttered. “It must have been an instinctual feeling.” We were stranded that evening, unable to make our way back to Johannesburg due to the relentless shelling. It seemed we were trapped, as the rebels had taken control of a new section of the city. Our sanctuary was a remote farm about twenty miles from Johannesburg, situated in the open veld. Exhaustion weighed heavily on me."

"Rarely do you visit us these days," Poirot scolded. "It has been almost a month since the incident with the Yellow Jasmine."   "I've been traveling up north. How have things been for you? The Big Four still causing trouble?" Poirot wagged a finger reproachfully. "Ah, you may jest, but the Big Four is real."   "Oh, I have no doubt about that. But they're not as significant as you think."   "My friend, you are mistaken. The Big Four are the epitome of evil in the world today. Their end goal remains a mystery, but there has never been a more formidable criminal organization."

"You must trust your gut instincts," I exclaimed. "It may sound ludicrous, but I have a hunch that Miss Howard is hiding something!" "Miss Howard?" "Yes, I know it may seem far-fetched," I stammered, "but I can't shake the feeling that we may have overlooked her as a suspect just because she was out of town. Yet, she was only fifteen miles away. A quick car ride could easily get her back in half an hour. Can we really be certain that she wasn't at Styles on the night of the murder?" Unexpectedly, Poirot replied, "Yes, my dear friend, we can."

"Then it's settled on the maid,” declared the inspector, satisfied, before resuming his search. Moving on to the maid’s bedroom next door, Poirot furrowed his brow in thought. Abruptly, he turned to Mr. Opalsen with a pointed question. “Was this necklace insured, no question about it?” Mr. Opalsen appeared slightly taken aback by the inquiry. “Yes,” he replied with hesitation, “that is correct.” “But why does it matter?” Mrs. Opalsen interjected tearfully. “I want my necklace back. It was one of a kind. No amount of money could replace it.” “I understand, madame,” Poirot reassured her. “I understand completely.”

Célestine vehemently denied the accusations, claiming she never saw the pearls. The inspector, however, remained suspicious and decided to search her. Despite finding nothing, Poirot proposed a little experiment. Célestine reluctantly agreed and repeated her actions of fetching a reel of cotton and scissors from her room. Poirot observed closely, making notes in his pocket-book. After the experiment, Célestine was cleared of suspicion, leaving the inspector to search the room thoroughly to find the missing pearls.

But, during lunch-time, a new revelation emerged - the absence of evidence. We had tirelessly searched for the missing fourth letter penned by Mrs. Inglethorp on the fateful night before her demise. Despite our fruitless endeavors, we eventually ceased our pursuit, holding onto the hope that it would resurface on its own accord someday. And indeed, fate intervened as a correspondence arrived via the afternoon mail from a French music publishing company. They acknowledged Mrs. Inglethorp's payment but expressed their regret at being unable to locate a specific collection of Russian folk songs.

"Inglethorp and Miss Howard,” she said, giving me a disconcerting look. “Would it really be such a catastrophe if they were to cross paths?” I was slightly caught off guard by her question. “Don’t you think so?” I asked. She smiled quietly. “No, I don’t. I would enjoy seeing some sparks fly. It might help clear the air. Right now, everyone is thinking so much, but saying so little.” “John disagrees,” I pointed out. “He wants to keep them apart.” “Oh, John!” The way she said it sparked something in me, and I blurted out, “John is a really good guy.” She studied me for a moment, then surprised me by saying, “You are a loyal friend.”

I was taken aback by the sudden appearance of the mysterious woman in my compartment. She was young, with a face covered in powder and lips painted an impossibly bright red. Her impudent demeanor and shocking language made me frown, but her infectious laughter soon broke through my reserve. Despite her unconventional behavior, I found myself unable to resist her charm. With a toss of her head, she declared us friends and demanded an apology for her missing sister. I obliged, feeling strangely drawn to this rebellious stranger.

As we approached the excavation site, a man with a grey beard, dressed in white and a helmet, approached us. "Monsieur Poirot and Captain Hastings? We got your message. I apologize for the absence of a welcoming party in Cairo. A sudden turn of events messed up our plans." Poirot's face lost color. His hand reached for his clothes-brush but halted. "Another fatality?" he whispered. "Indeed." "Sir Guy Willard?" I asked. "No, Captain Hastings. My American colleague, Mr. Schneider." "And the reason?" Poirot inquired. "Tetanus." I felt my blood drain from my face.

"John greeted us with a tired expression as we approached the house. "This situation is quite dire, Monsieur Poirot," he stated. "Hastings has made it clear that we wish to avoid any unwanted attention." "I understand completely." "At this point, it's only a suspicion. We have no solid leads." "Exactly. We're just being cautious." John then turned to me, pulling out a cigarette and lighting it. "You're aware that Inglethorp has returned?" "Yes, I've seen him." After casually tossing the match into a nearby flower bed, Poirot couldn't help but intervene. He picked it up and discreetly disposed of it. "It's quite tricky figuring out how to handle him."

"I don't know," I murmured. "I have this uneasy feeling that something terrible is on the horizon." Suzanne shook her head firmly. "Ridiculous," she scoffed. "Let's shift our focus. Anne, those jewels..." "What of them?" I inquired. "I fear they may not be secure in my possession any longer. Previously, it was inconspicuous, but now that our close relationship is common knowledge, I may come under scrutiny." "But no one suspects they're concealed within a roll of film," I countered. "It's a brilliant hiding spot, and I doubt we could find a better one."

Julius’ narrative style was nothing short of captivating, even if it did stray from the truth at times. As the chauffeur slowed down, he informed Julius that they were approaching Gatehouse. Julius instructed the Russian to guide them to the house, planning to drive directly to their destination. Knowing that Little Willie would not accept any mistakes, Julius made it clear to Kramenin that failure was not an option. After the intense journey, Kramenin was completely under Julius' control, feeling utterly defeated. The car glided up the driveway and came to a stop in front of the porch.

"My dear friend, do not let your mind wander. Recall the partially torn cheque and the name Bella Duveen, faintly recognized by Stonor. It is safe to say that Bella Duveen is the full name of Jack's mysterious correspondent, the one who visited Villa Geneviève that fateful night. I caught my breath at the sight before me, a hunger for the unknown swelling inside. The Kilmorden drew closer, like a dream. Another figure appeared, familiar yet distant after the events of the previous night. His warning of danger lingered, leaving me unsettled. As we parted ways, his footsteps echoing, I knew our paths would not cross again. The next hours were a blur of bureaucracy and relief, until I found myself at the Mount Nelson, surrounded by sunshine and flowers. Suzanne's indifference contrasted with my excitement, but I reveled in the beauty around me. This is not a story of South Africa, with no promise of local color. My inability to provide italics of authenticity is clear, but the essence of the tale remains.

(Continuation of Anne's Story) I doubt I will ever forget my initial view of Table Mountain for as long as I live. I woke up incredibly early and stepped out onto the deck.

"Then it’s off!” Tuppence rose. “It’s both or neither. Sorry but that’s how it is. Good morning, Mr. Whittington.” “Wait a minute. Let us see if something can’t be managed. Sit down again, Miss ” He paused interrogatively. Tuppence’s conscience gave her a passing twinge as she remembered the archdeacon. All the geniality had faded out of Whittington’s face. It was purple with rage, and the veins stood out on the forehead. And behind it all there lurked a sort of incredulous dismay.

At the stroke of eleven, a telegram arrived from Poirot: "Instruct Japp to detain housekeeper at once." I was shocked, but wasted no time in delivering the message to Japp. He muttered a curse, acknowledging Poirot's reputation. "If he insists, there must be a reason. I barely gave the woman a second thought. I may not arrest her, but she will be closely monitored. Let's head up there now and conduct a thorough search." Unfortunately, it was already too late. Mrs. Middleton, the unassuming middle-aged housekeeper who had seemed so ordinary, had vanished without a trace. Only her abandoned belongings remained.

"Once again, there was no witness to the mysterious entry into the apartment while we were away, and the whereabouts of our deceased companion, Mayerling, remain a mystery.... "No clues left behind by Number Four, he is well aware of that. His initial visit was merely a reconnaissance mission. It is possible he sought confirmation of Mayerling's demise, but more likely, he came to confront Hercule Poirot, the only adversary he truly fears." Poirot's logic seemed self-centered to me, but I chose not to challenge it. "What is the latest on the investigation?" I inquired.

"Back in the day, men and women were equals. Papa used to say they roamed the world together like lions and tigers," Colonel Race chimed in with a smirk, "And giraffes?" I couldn't help but laugh at the mention of giraffes. "Yes, giraffes too. They were nomads, you know. It wasn't until they settled in communities that women's strength waned. Deep down, we're all the same. Women still admire physical strength in men because it's what they once possessed and now lack."

Poirot nodded. “Indeed, my dear friend. That is where I found the crucial ‘last link,’ and I am indebted to you for that very fortunate discovery.” “To me?” “Yes. I could not help but feel unsettled by the encounter with Marthe and Jack Renauld. Their whispered conversation hinted at hidden fears and secrets, leaving me with more questions than answers. As I walked away from the scene, my attention was caught by a peculiar sight near the hedge. What appeared to be a bush turned out to be Giraud, the detective, signaling for silence. With a stern expression, he chastised me for interrupting their conversation, revealing his true intentions. Our encounter left me even more curious about the mysteries surrounding the young couple and the tragic events that seemed to bind them together.

"“Why did you do it?” The nobleman demanded, his voice filled with confusion. Poirot remained calm as he responded, “I simply wanted to force a resolution.” Lord Yardly was taken aback, exclaiming, “To force a resolution! Dear God!” Poirot continued cheerfully, “And the plan worked, my lord. Therefore, I am pleased to return this to you.” With a grand gesture, he revealed a dazzling diamond. “The prized Star of the East,” Lord Yardly whispered in awe. “But I am at a loss for words.” “No matter,” Poirot replied. “Rest assured, the diamond is safe with you. It was necessary for it to be taken. I promised its protection, and I have upheld my promise."

Yes, I was content, yet there lingered a sense of anticipation, as if something awaited me on the horizon. Restlessness tingled beneath my skin. Following our tea, we meandered outside, boarded the tram, and were guided by jovial attendants along the narrow rails to the bridge. The grandeur of the scene unfolded before us - the vast gorge, the tumultuous waters below, and the misty shroud that occasionally parted to reveal the majestic waterfall, only to quickly conceal it once more in enigmatic secrecy. This, I concluded, is the allure of the Falls - their enigmatic nature.

He raged against the porters, the waiters at breakfast, the entire hotel staff. He probably wanted to unleash his fury on Miss Pettigrew too, but even Sir Eustace wouldn't dare. As for our mission, once Sir Eustace withdrew, Miss Pettigrew volunteered to stay behind just in case he needed her.

We proceeded to our destination, a prime target in the affluent northern suburbs of London. Upon arrival at a grand and imposing house set back from the main road, Norman and I remained by the car while Poirot and a detective approached the entrance and pressed the doorbell. A poised parlourmaid answered the door, only to be met with the detective's authoritative declaration of their intent to search the premises. The maid let out a gasp, prompting a sophisticated, mature woman to emerge from the shadows of the hallway. "Quick, Edith, close the door. These must be intruders," she exclaimed. Without hesitation, Poirot wedged his foot in the doorway and blew a sharp blast on a whistle.

"They are merely new acquaintances, I believe. But surely, Poirot, you don’t suspect for a moment” Poirot gestured with his hand. “Hold on, my friend. Have I made any assumptions? All I am saying is it's an intriguing tale. And there is no clue to unravel it; except maybe the lady’s name, eh, Hastings?” “Her name is Stella,” I said firmly, “but I fail to see” Poirot cut me off with a hearty laugh. Something appeared to be greatly amusing him. “And Stella means a star, correct? Brilliant!” “What in the world” “And stars provide illumination! There you have it! Relax, Hastings. Spare me the wounded pride. Come, let us head to Montagu Mansions and conduct a few investigations."

Papa’s friends were all renowned Professors, distinguished by their long beards. One of them, Professor Peterson, once made a rather inappropriate comment about Anne's figure. Anne, yearning for adventure and romance, found solace in the village's lending library and the weekly episode of “The Perils of Pamela” at the Kinema. Her father's sudden excitement over an antique skull found in Northern Rhodesia sparked a new adventure. Unfortunately, Papa's health took a turn for the worse, and he passed away, leaving Anne practically penniless. Mr. Flemming, Papa's solicitor, offered Anne a temporary stay in London, setting the stage for new beginnings and unexpected challenges.

He grabbed Albert's shoulder, pointing towards the house. "Keep an eye on that window when I start singing," he instructed before retreating to the main drive. I glanced over the list of names, my heart pounding in anticipation. The first one jumped out at me - Ernest Luttrell. The son of a North Country parson, with a troubled past. Expelled from school, turned to the stage. A man with a kink in his moral make-up, addicted to drugs. Disappeared to Australia four years ago, leaving no trace behind. Age 32, 5 ft. 10-1/2 in., clean-shaven, brown hair, straight nose, fair complexion, gray eyes. The pieces of the puzzle were finally starting to come together.

Poirot and Japp were discussing the mysterious disappearance of Mr. Davenheim. Japp revealed that they found Mr. Davenheim's clothes near the lake, but not his body. Poirot doubted that Lowen was the murderer, citing lack of evidence. He suggested that the ring may have been removed from the body to divert suspicion. Japp mentioned a lime kiln near the lake where the body could have been disposed of. Poirot then made a startling revelation about Mr. Davenheim's true whereabouts, leaving everyone in shock.

Chichester and Mr. Pagett. "You will let me have it, won’t you?” I always say that sailors are the nicest to women. My purser came to the rescue magnificently. I briefly considered taking charge myself, relishing the opportunity to outsmart Poirot. However, I resisted the urge, knowing I couldn't risk jeopardizing our mission by acting alone. This was a critical operation - we had finally gained an advantage over our adversaries. It was essential that we capitalize on this moment. As much as I hated to admit it, Poirot's intellect surpassed my own. I quickly penned a letter to him, detailing the situation and stressing the importance of eavesdropping on the upcoming meeting.

"Jewel thefts, counterfeiting, espionage (especially lucrative in times of conflict), acts of sabotage, discreet murders - there is barely a crime he hasn't dabbled in. I knew they would eventually show up at the residence in Soho. I used the gun to intimidate Julius, hoping Tuppence would relay the message to Sir James so he wouldn't fret about us. Once the girls disappeared from view, I instructed Julius to speed towards London, recounting the entire ordeal along the way. Upon arriving at the Soho residence, we encountered Mr. Carter outside. After finalizing details with him, we entered and concealed ourselves behind the curtain in the alcove. The officers were under strict instructions to deny any knowledge of anyone entering the house if questioned. That's the gist of it.

Templeton, a charming residence with amiable inhabitants. Mrs. Templeton, the youthful wife, stands in stark contrast to her older husband, who has a son from a previous marriage residing with them. The mysterious nature of Mr. Templeton's illness is evident, with sporadic gastric attacks causing pain and vomiting. Despite my suspicions, the doctor's assurance left me with no room to voice my concerns.

"Poirot's comments on the underexposed interiors were unnecessary, showing his jealousy of my position on the case. His request for clothing details seemed ridiculous, but I complied. Mrs. Havering hired her from Selbourne's Agency, but they had no record of her. The mystery deepened as we realized she must have had a connection to the murder. Poirot instructed us to find out what vehicle took her to Hunter's Lodge. The local garage had no record of her using their services. Mrs. Havering had given her money for transportation, but none of the available options were used."

I meekly agreed to his request for company, though apprehensive of the consequences. Before his departure, I inquired about his name, to which he casually replied, "Harry Rayburn." The sudden onset of seasickness during the journey left me incapacitated and indifferent to my original mission. However, a kind gesture from Mrs. Flemming led to a change in plans, as I decided to embark on a new adventure in South Africa. With a generous parting gift in hand, I set out on my journey, eventually finding some solace on deck and observing the intriguing passengers around me. The arrival in Madeira brought a glimmer of hope, as the scent of violets lifted my spirits and made me consider enduring the remainder of the voyage.

As my rescuer turned towards me, a sense of urgency emanated from him. "You're injured!" His voice held a hint of danger towards whoever had caused me harm. In that instant, I recognized him - the man with the scar. But before he could react, our fallen adversary had already bolted up and fled. Rayburn cursed as he pursued the enemy, leaving me behind. Feeling left out, I reluctantly joined the pursuit, lagging behind. We raced around the deck, finally reaching the starboard side of the ship.

"Miss Pettigrew." "He wasn't exactly singing her praises just now," I observed. Pagett gave me a cold stare. "She's a skilled shorthand typist," he stated firmly. As we arrived at the station, I thought he would depart. Extending my hand, I was surprised when he declined. "I'll accompany you to see you off. He was intent on ensuring that I caught the train.

He was a villain, but a pleasant one. Sir Eustace's escape was not surprising. Colonel Race knew his real name was Harry Lucas, but he was actually John Harold Eardsley. Harry wanted to live a simple life with Anne, away from his father's wealth. In the end, he revealed his true identity to Anne, feeling jealous of Colonel Race.

Unbeknownst to me, I found a twisted satisfaction in witnessing her collapse. It revealed a vulnerability that I had failed to see before. "Wait, you can't venture out alone in this state. It's too dangerous. I must escort you back to Merlinville." "Don't be absurd. I'm perfectly fine now." "What if you fall ill again? No, I will not let you go alone." She fiercely argued against my proposition, her determination shining through.

Poirot greeted the lady warmly, comparing her to a blooming flower in the dull office. Miss Monro blushed at his flattering words. "You Frenchmen are all the same," she giggled.

After returning to the road, I found the waiting car and drove away. While on the train, I couldn't shake the feeling of being watched. A man across from me winked at a woman nearby, sending chills down my spine. Relieved that the papers were safe, I stepped into the corridor for some fresh air, considering changing carriages. However, the woman stopped me, claiming I had dropped something. As I bent down to check, everything went black. The next thing I knew, I was waking up in the hospital, a sharp pain at the back of my head.

Who are you referring to?” “I'm talking about Jane Finn.” “Jane Finn is your cousin?” “Yes, her mother and my father were siblings,” Mr. Hersheimmer clarified. “Oh!” exclaimed Tuppence. “Do you know her whereabouts?” “No!” Mr. Hersheimmer slammed his fist on the table. “I have no idea! Do you?” “We posted advertisements seeking information, not giving it,” Tuppence reminded sternly. “I am well aware of that. I am literate.”

“Well, there's always Sir Eustace Pedler’s property,” the man hesitated. “The Mill House, you're familiar with it.” “Not exactly where,” I stumbled. (Honestly, stumbling is becoming my forte.) “That's right! The scene of the crime. But maybe you wouldn't be interested.”“Oh, I don't believe I'd be bothered,” I responded with a show of confidence. I believed my credibility was now firmly established. “And maybe I could snag a deal under the circumstances.” A stroke of genius, in my opinion. “Well, it's a possibility. Letting it out won't be easy now with servants and all that, you understand.”

"The disappearance of the will, and her carrying its secret to her grave. Cavendish, I am afraid there is more to it than meets the eye. Monsieur Poirot, I believe you will concur that the evidence is quite telling.” “Telling, or not,” John interjected, “we owe Monsieur Poirot a debt of gratitude for clarifying the situation. Without him, we would never have been aware of the existence of this will. May I inquire, monsieur, what initially aroused your suspicions?” Poirot smiled and replied: “An envelope covered in scribbles, and a freshly cultivated patch of begonias."

"The inquiry won't happen until Friday." "Friday, my foot!" Miss Howard let out a disdainful snort. "You're all out of your minds. The man will have left the country by then. If he has any sense, he won't stick around here quietly waiting to be arrested." John Cavendish looked at her with a sense of defeat. "I see what's going on," she accused him, "you've been heeding the advice of the physicians. Never a good idea. What do they really know? Absolutely nothing or just enough to be a threat. I should know, my own father was a doctor. That Wilkins is perhaps the biggest imbecile I've ever come across. Heart attack! The kind of diagnosis he would give."

"The two detectives shifted in their seats. I noticed the official warning “Anything you say can and will be used against you,” practically ready to spill from Summerhaye’s mouth. Poirot pressed on. “Are you comprehending now, sir?” “No. What are you insinuating?” “I am insinuating,” Poirot stated deliberately, “that you are under suspicion for poisoning your wife.” A collective gasp rippled through the room at this blunt accusation. “Heavens above!” exclaimed Inglethorp, leaping to his feet. “What an absurd notion! Poisoning my beloved Emily!” “I don’t believe” Poirot observed him intently “that you fully grasp the damning weight of your testimony from the inquest."

“Absolutely nothing. I’m terrible at dealing with business matters.” “I see. So you have no idea why he suddenly decided to take out a life insurance policy? He hadn’t done so before, is that correct?” “We had only been married for a little over a year. But the reason he got the life insurance was because he was convinced that he wouldn’t live much longer. He had a strong feeling that his death was near. He had already suffered from a hemorrhage, and he believed that another one would be fatal. I tried to reassure him, but he was convinced of his impending death.”

"I was." As always, I admired the man whilst disliking him. He looked me up and down with a sort of contemptuous disfavour. "You didn't help matters by butting in. I might have heard something useful in a minute. What have you done with your old fossil?" I replied coldly, "M. Poirot has gone to Paris. And I can tell you, M. Giraud, that he is anything but an old fossil. He has solved many cases that have completely baffled the English police." Giraud snapped his fingers disdainfully. "They must be on a level with our examining magistrates. So he has gone to Paris, has he? Well, a good thing. The longer he stays there, the better."

I noticed my pencil resting against the closed cupboard door. It struck me that had the door been open, my pencil would have surely found its way inside. Intrigued, I opened the door, allowing the pencil to escape into the shadows of the far corner. As I reached for it, I realized that the dim light and odd structure of the cupboard made it nearly impossible to spot the pencil without touch. Satisfied with the retrieval, I decided to check the cupboard beneath the window on the other side of the room.

"I won't be long," I said in a drowsy state as the landlady informed me of a visitor. Lady Yardly, a well-known figure, entered and we discussed the mysterious blackmail letters regarding a diamond. Lady Yardly revealed that her letters came by post and had an Eastern scent, similar to Miss Marvell's. We tried to make sense of the situation but couldn't. Lady Yardly decided to leave, leaving me to inform Poirot. He returned and was intrigued by the case, deciding to involve Lord Yardly. Poirot believed the diamond was in danger of being stolen, but didn't elaborate. Lord Yardly arrived, puzzled by the situation.

The room was crowded, with patrons searching for an empty table amid snippets of conversation. "She started crying when I told her the flat was no longer available," one voice mentioned. "It was a steal, just like Mabel Lewis' purchase from Paris," chimed in another. Tommy remarked on the random bits of talk they overheard, including a discussion about someone named Jane Finn. As two elderly women left their seats, Tuppence quickly settled into one. Tommy then placed an order for tea and pastries.

Thursday night. Just departed Kimberley. Race retelling diamond robbery story. Anne Beddingfeld revealed as newspaper correspondent. Sent cable from De Aar. Reading articles aloud all night. On track of "The Man in the Brown Suit." Ferreted out identity of Nadina. Deduction in Sherlock Holmes manner. Clever, coaxing ways with invincible determination. Suspect Rayburn heading to Rhodesia. Race uneasy about Anne's pursuit. Anne determined to discover Rayburn. Young women cold-blooded. Race worried Rayburn may be on train. Beddingfeld wants glory of discovery. Mrs. Blair welcomes idea of murder as scoop for Anne. Tomorrow passing through Bechuanaland.

Miss Marvell leaned forward, revealing a stone of white fire in her palm. Poirot examined it closely and advised her to leave it with him. She mentioned a deal with Lord Yardly to film a play at Yardly Chase. Lady Yardly arrived, revealing that she also received blackmailing letters about the diamond. Poirot decided to involve himself in the case and questioned Lord Yardly about his plans to sell the Star of the East. Lord Yardly explained his financial difficulties and the pressure to sell the jewel, despite Lady Yardly's opposition.

Inside the house, a door opened into the scullery where the back door was located, and another led to the bedroom once belonging to Robert Grant. Poirot meticulously analyzed the crime scene, speaking softly to himself. "The body was here, indicated by the large dark stain and surrounding splashes. Confusingly, there are traces of both carpet slippers and 'number nine' boots. Additionally, two sets of tracks lead to and from the kitchen, suggesting that the murderer entered this way. Hastings, do you have the boot? Pass it to me." After examining the boot, Poirot concluded, "These prints were left by the same person, Robert Grant."

"It's game over, Mr. Abe Ryland," he said with a sly grin. In an instant, the room was filled with armed men who quickly apprehended Ryland and his valet. Poirot exchanged a few words with the commanding officer before pulling me aside. Once we were out of earshot, he enveloped me in a tight hug. "You're safe, unharmed. It's truly remarkable. I've been kicking myself for letting you walk into danger." "I'm fine," I reassured him, stepping back. "But I must admit, I'm a bit confused. You saw through their plan all along, didn't you?" "Of course! Why else would I have allowed you to proceed? Your fake identity, your disguise - it was all part of the plan, never meant to fool anyone!" My jaw dropped in disbelief.

I decided against taking that path due to its high level of risk. Instead, I adorned my finest hat and made my way somberly through the town to speak with our understandably furious grocer. The sole young man to visit our home was a reporter from the Daily Budget. At moments, I found myself envious of Emily, our young maid, who would stroll out with a handsome sailor she was engaged to whenever the opportunity arose. And in the meantime, to stay practiced as she put it, she would also go out with the greengrocer's assistant and the pharmacist's aide. It made me melancholic to realize that I had no one to practice my social skills with.

"But he tracked you down again quite easily, didn't he? Even after all those years had gone by?" "Yes, I was fortunate to come across the lawyer's ad." Poirot decided to stop questioning. Our next step was to pay a visit to Dr. Quentin. His recount was much the same as what he had shared during the inquiry, with few new details. We found him in his office, just finished with his appointments. He appeared to be a sharp individual. His demeanor, along with his pince-nez, suggested a certain formality, yet I suspected he would be quite updated in his approach."

What was Poirot's true motive in searching for Bella Duveen? Was it related to the murder of Jack Renauld? The girl seemed to have no reason to wish for his death, but perhaps there was a deeper connection between them. Why did she keep returning to Merlinville? These questions circled in my mind as Poirot and I arrived in London, ready to uncover the truth. Time was of the essence, and Poirot was determined to act swiftly. Our next move was to seek out Joseph Aarons, a theatrical agent with connections that might lead us to the elusive Bella Duveen.

"Ah, we have it! 'Yardly, 10th viscount, fought in South African War' none of that matters 'married in 1907 to Hon. Maude Stopperton, daughter of 3rd Baron Cotteril' um, um, um, 'two daughters born in 1908, 1910. Clubs residences.' Well, that doesn't reveal much. But tomorrow morning we meet this nobleman!" "What?" "Yes. I sent a telegram to him." "I thought you were done with the case?" "I no longer represent Miss Marvell since she won't follow my advice. What I do now is for my own satisfaction and the satisfaction of Hercule Poirot! Clearly, I need to be involved in this matter."

I was immediately suspicious and discovered that he was actually sailing for England on the Kilmorden Castle. I transformed myself into a grave bearded gentleman of middle age to avoid detection. Following him to London, he met Anita Grünberg, whom I hated for ruining my life. She left the agent's office with an order for the Mill House in Marlow. I trailed them to Knightsbridge, where she went to the Hyde Park Hotel. I followed Carton into the Tube station and tried to confront him, leading to a fatal accident. Realizing the danger I was in, I attached myself to Sir Eustace Pedler as his secretary. The identity of the 'Colonel' remained a mystery, but the search for the truth continued.

"The Prime Minister, accompanied by Captain Daniels, was granted an Audience at Windsor. On the way back to town, an attempted assassination took place. Captain Daniels, a linguist who speaks seven languages, is under scrutiny. The Premier's car was held up by masked men, but the Prime Minister escaped with a slight wound. After a brief stop at a local hospital, he proceeded to Charing Cross. The car, found outside a German agent meeting place, was missing the chauffeur. Two disappearances: the Prime Minister in France, and the chauffeur in London. Poirot is granted carte blanche to investigate."

"Suzanne, I believe we've stumbled upon a breakthrough in the case," I exclaimed. "It all revolves around the mysterious appointment in Cabin 17 on the 22nd." Suzanne's eyes widened in realization. "Yes, but what about the connection to Madame Nadina, the Russian dancer?" I paused, struck by a sudden thought. "What if the films that Mrs. Blair received were meant for Nadina? And what if they were a crucial piece of evidence in this whole tangled web of deceit?" Suzanne gasped, her eyes alight with newfound understanding. "It all makes sense now. The answer lies in those missing films. We must find them."

"I never knew the key to the safe was missing," he admitted. "It was just a lucky guess that happened to be right. When I noticed the twisted wire on the handle, it made me think that it had been forcibly removed from a keychain. If Mrs. Inglethorp had lost it and found it again, she would have put it back on her ring. But instead, I found a brand new duplicate key on her ring, which made me suspect that someone else had used the original key to open the safe."

"Quiet," he shouted, his hand trembling with anxiety. "I can't talk until the arrest is made and I know everything is in order. My intuition has let me down. Hastings, if a man leaves a dying message, it must be significant. Everyone dismisses 'Yellow Jasmine? There's yellow jasmine near the house, it's meaningless.'" "And what if it's not? Maybe it's literal. Hear me out." He displayed a small book. "I thought it might be worth looking into."

I was welcomed by Mrs. Cavendish in a warm, inviting tone, as I settled into a comfortable chair. I was grateful I had agreed to join John. Mrs. Cavendish served me tea, and her subtle comments only confirmed my initial impression of her as captivating. As I shared amusing stories from my time at the Convalescent Home, I could see my hostess thoroughly entertained. Unlike John, who, while a nice guy, lacked the spark in conversation.

He needed to fake his death, escape to a different country with his wife, and change his identity. To make sure his wife had control of the money, he altered his will. A rough tramp intruded into their garden, leading to an unexpected opportunity for the couple. They quickly devised a plan to shift the blame onto the tramp's body, dressing it in the man's clothes and stabbing it with an aeroplane dagger. The husband would then bury the body, ensuring it was found later to divert suspicion. In the meantime, he would disguise himself as the tramp and quietly leave town. However, their carefully laid out plan faced unexpected challenges when a girl named Bella showed up at their door, threatening to unravel everything.

"Have you ever heard of the deadly poison cuare? South American tribes use it on their arrows, causing certain death. I have a blow-pipe that looks like a cigarette, concealing its lethal function. Just a puff and.... Ah! I see you are alarmed. Do not move, madame. This cigarette's mechanism is quite clever. A puff sends a dart flying, like a fishbone seeking its target. You do not want to die, so I urge you to free my friend Hastings from his restraints. Though my hands are tied, my gaze remains fixed on you, madame."

Moreover, what am I to occupy myself with in Pretoria? Marvel at the design of the Union buildings and catch the reverberations of gunfire in Johannesburg? I would likely be confined there for an unknown duration. Rumor has it they have sabotaged the railway line already. To make matters worse, one can't even find a decent drink there. The entire area has been placed under martial law since two days ago. "My dear friend," I interjected, "it seems you fail to grasp that I am investigating the situation on the Rand. How in the world am I expected to do so from Pretoria? I appreciate your concern for my well-being, but rest assured, I will manage just fine."

After having tea, he mentioned to his wife that he needed to walk down to the village to mail some letters. He also informed her that a Mr. Lowen was expected for business. In case Mr. Lowen arrived before his return, he should be directed to the study to wait. Mr. Davenheim left the house through the front entrance, strolled down the driveway, exited through the gate, and mysteriously disappeared. He was never spotted again after that moment. "Quite intriguing, a delightful little mystery," whispered Poirot. "Please continue, my dear friend."

"As we rushed to the Magnificent in a taxi, I pondered the intricacies of the plan. The 'full moon' ruse was quite ingenious, diverting our attention to Friday and leaving us vulnerable earlier. Poirot seemed unfazed, his usual composure returning swiftly. I couldn't help but feel sympathy for him - failure was not something he took lightly. 'Don't worry,' I reassured him. 'There's always another chance.' Upon arrival at the Magnificent, we were promptly led to the manager's office."

Poirot eagerly opened the sheet of paper and let out a satisfied exclamation. He then placed it on the table and called Hastings over. "Take a look at this, my friend. Desjardeaux leaped up from his seat, his face flushed with anger. "Madame Olivier! Preposterous! Ridiculous! What you're saying is an outrage!" Poirot simply shook his head, offering no response. Desjardeaux stared at him in disbelief for a moment. Then his expression softened, and he looked towards the Home Secretary, tapping his temple knowingly. "M. They may see shadows of conspiracies where none exist. It's a well-known fact."

I inquired about when he had firmly decided on this matter. "That's the issue. I am uncertain. I can't be certain. My friend, I would do anything to find out. As long as you remember that I will be watching your every move. I have the skill to shoot from unconventional angles. A simple signal to the hotel staff and there will be consequences. The American kept his promise. Upon reaching the car, Julius felt a wave of relief. The threat had been averted.
