"Did you forget about the letter?” “No, I didn't forget. But why do you believe that letter was intended for M. Renauld?” “Well, it was discovered in his pocket and...” “That's it!” interrupted Poirot. “There was no indication of a recipient's name on the letter. We assumed it was for the deceased because it was in his overcoat pocket. But, my friend, something about that overcoat seemed odd to me. I measured it and commented on how long it was. That should have sparked some thoughts in your mind.” “I thought you were simply making an observation for the sake of it,” I admitted.

We raced to Cape Town as soon as possible. Suzanne greeted me there, and together we dismantled the giraffe. Colonel Race suggested we move into Sir Lawrence Eardsley's villa at Muizenberg. Plans were made for me to return to England with Suzanne, getting married in London with the trousseau from Paris. Suzanne loved planning, but the future felt unreal. The night before we sailed, Harry appeared, urging me to run away with him to Rhodesia. I followed him, feeling like a lunatic in love. It's been two years since then, living on the island. Suzanne wrote a letter, calling us lunatics. Another letter arrived from Bolivia, offering me a diary to use as I please. I may now be Lady Eardsley, but the past still haunts me.

Poirot tapped my knee urgently, his voice hushed with excitement. "Hastings, look closely. The bread trick - Number Four!" I turned my gaze to the man at the adjacent table, his complexion ghostly and his movements mechanical as he toyed with the bread. His bloated, smooth face was sickly pale, shadowed by under-eye bags and creased with age. It was impossible to pinpoint his exact years, somewhere between thirty-five and forty-five. Not a single feature bore resemblance to the previous identities of Number Four.

"As Graves feared being caught eavesdropping, he quickly went to carry out his employer's task. The two men had arrived promptly at eight that evening. Over dinner, they engaged in casual conversation about politics, weather, and the theater. After serving port and coffee, Graves' master unexpectedly granted him the rest of the evening off. The inspector inquired if this was a common occurrence with guests, to which Graves replied, 'No, sir; it was not.'"

I wasn't expecting that the seemingly unimportant note would lead to such a shocking discovery. The body of a woman found in a lonely house, strangled to death, added a whole new layer of mystery to the case. As the details unfolded, it became clear that there was more to this story than initially met the eye. The new development only heightened my curiosity, pushing me to delve deeper into the dark secrets that seemed to be lurking beneath the surface.

I collected all the necessary information from Mrs. Havering and we quickly discovered that the mysterious housekeeper, Mrs. Middleton, had connections to the crime. She seemed to have disappeared after the murder. It was evident that she had played a crucial role in providing an alibi for Mrs. Havering during the time of the crime. The murderer had arrived and escaped in a car, which also brought Mrs. Middleton to her new position. The revolver found at Ealing was a diversion tactic, and the true culprits managed to evade justice. It was a complex and well-executed plan, leaving us no choice but to accept the hand of Fate in this matter.

As Japp's men hurried over at the sound of Poirot's whistle, they discovered four unconscious Chinamen in the hallway. However, the man who had previously threatened me was conspicuously absent. Recalling the moment I was pushed onto the doorstep to lure Poirot inside, I realized that this man had deliberately stayed out of sight. It appeared that he had cleverly avoided the gas bomb and escaped through one of the numerous exits we later uncovered. Despite questioning the four individuals we apprehended, they revealed nothing of value. Even the most thorough police investigation failed to uncover any connection between them and the notorious Big Four.

"Why are you insinuating, Poirot?" "I have been pondering the purpose of our visitor this morning. Was the intention truly to bribe me? Or perhaps, to instill fear and deter me from my investigation? It appeared unlikely. So, why did he pay a visit? And now, I comprehend the scheme entirely - the facade of bribery or intimidation, the deliberate confrontation he did not bother to evade, leading to the conveniently dropped pocket-book, and ultimately, the trap! Rue des Echelles, 11:00 a.m."

“Perhaps it has been here for quite some time. However, it holds no interest for me.” “On the contrary, I find it quite intriguing,” Poirot replied with a touch of sweetness. I suspected he was simply trying to provoke the Paris detective, and if that was his goal, he certainly achieved it. The other man turned away abruptly, stating that he was not willing to waste any more time. He then bent down to continue his thorough search of the area. Meanwhile, Poirot, as if struck by a sudden inspiration, stepped back across the boundary and tested the door of the small shed. “It's locked,” Giraud remarked without looking. “But it's only where the gardener stores his junk.”

Poirot took the lead as we left the town, making our way towards the Villa Geneviève. However, upon reaching the Villa Marguerite, he stopped abruptly. "I must ensure that Jack Renauld is safe. Hastings, accompany me. Perhaps Mademoiselle should stay outside. Madame Daubreuil's words may be hurtful." We opened the gate and proceeded up the pathway. Turning the corner of the house, I pointed out a window on the first floor to Poirot. Projected on the blind was the silhouette of Marthe Daubreuil. "Ah!" exclaimed Poirot.

Poirot examined the spade and gloves that belonged to Renauld, the victim of the crime. He noted the attention to detail in the planning of the murder, with the killer using Renauld's own dagger and spade to avoid leaving traces. Giraud, the Paris detective, was focused on the ground while Poirot took interest in a piece of lead-piping nearby. Despite Giraud's dismissal, Poirot found it intriguing. As they continued their investigation, Poirot questioned the significance of a whitewashed line around the grave, revealing his unique approach to solving the case.

I was struck by the unflappable demeanor of Poirot. His composure was truly remarkable. Eagerly, I anticipated his next inquiry, only to be underwhelmed. "When you entered Mrs. Inglethorp's chamber, was the entrance to Miss Cynthia's quarters secured?" "Indeed, sir; it always was. It had remained unopened." "And the doorway to Mr. Inglethorp's room? Did you observe if it was fastened as well?" Annie paused. "I cannot say for certain, sir; it was closed but I cannot confirm if it was bolted." "Upon your departure, did Mrs. Inglethorp lock the door behind you?" "No, sir, not at that moment, but I presume she did so later. Typically, she would secure it at night. The entryway to the corridor, that is."

"Anne, do you recognize that man over there?" I inquired casually. "Oh, is he your new secretary?" she responded, a hint of curiosity in her voice."Yes, that's Mr. Rayburn. Unfortunately, he hasn't been feeling well lately," I revealed."Interesting. How long has he been working for you?" Anne probed further, her eyes fixed on me."Not too long, actually. I hired him right before my trip," I disclosed, trying to be vague.Anne didn't miss a beat. "And who recommended him to you?" she asked, her tone direct.I hesitated slightly before answering, "An old friend put in a good word for him."After that, Anne fell silent, lost in her own thoughts.

“Feel free to inquire about anything, Monsieur Poirot,” Willard stated. “We are completely bewildered by this odd string of events, but we truly believe it is simply a series of coincidences.” Despite his words, there was a noticeable nervousness in his demeanor. Poirot carefully observed him. “Are you truly dedicated to this task, Sir Guy?” “Absolutely. Regardless of what may occur, the work will continue. Rest assured of that.” Poirot turned to the doctor. “And what is your stance on the matter, monsieur le docteur?” “Well,” the doctor drawled, “I have no intention of giving up.” Poirot responded with one of his characteristic expressive grimaces.

At the trial, the prisoner Renauld sat nervously next to his lawyer, Maître Grosíer. A stern guard, armed with a gleaming sabre, stood watch by the door, while the diligent greffier busied himself at his desk. The magistrate wasted no time. "Renauld," he interrogated, "do you still claim you were in Cherbourg on the night of the crime, despite all evidence pointing to Merlinville?" Jack hesitated, his voice trembling as he repeated, "I told you, I was in Cherbourg." Maître Grosíer's expression darkened, a mix of frustration and disappointment.

“Inglethorp's dying words were an accusation against her husband,” Poirot explained. I nodded in understanding. “It's good to see John and his wife reconciled,” I remarked. “Yes, thanks to me,” Poirot replied confidently. I raised an eyebrow in confusion. “The trial brought them together,” he continued. “John still loved his wife, and she loved him, but they had drifted apart due to a misunderstanding. She had married him without love.”

Taxis were abundant in the area, and as one departed, another arrived at the curb in response to Tommy's firm gesture. "Follow the taxi ahead," the young man instructed. The elderly driver seemed indifferent, simply grunting before lowering his flag. The journey was quiet. Tommy's taxi stopped at the departure area right after Whittington's. Tommy followed closely behind at the ticket counter, purchasing a first-class ticket to Bournemouth. Boris noted, checking the time on the clock: "You're ahead of schedule. You still have almost thirty minutes."

As the morning sun rose, a startling piece of news arrived in the form of a telegram. It was a plea for help, urging immediate action in the wake of a tragic event. Without hesitation, we embarked on a journey to a remote location, guided by the grim reality of a murder that had taken place the night before. The desolate surroundings only added to the mystery and sense of foreboding that hung in the air. Despite the uncertainty and lack of details, one thing was clear - the need for a skilled detective to unravel the truth behind this heinous crime.

New York police report a highly mysterious disappearance. The missing individual is approximately 33 years old, with brown hair, fair complexion, and gray eyes. Standing at a height of 5 ft. 10-1/2 in. "Fascinating," I murmured, setting the newspaper aside. "After months of investigation, these four names are all they have to show? Which one do you find most suspicious?" Poirot responded with a meaningful gesture. "My friend, at this juncture, it remains uncertain. Note that Claud Darrell has recently traveled to both China and America, a detail that may hold significance. However, we must not allow ourselves to be swayed too heavily by this. It could simply be a coincidence." "What should be our next course of action?" I inquired eagerly.

"Japp always had a way of surprising me with his antics, prompting a chuckle from deep within. Meanwhile, Poirot remained composed as he sifted through his mail. A request to speak at the local boy scouts event, a visit from the Countess of Forfanock - most likely about her pampered lap-dog. But then, a shift in Poirot's demeanor caught my attention. With a sense of urgency, he passed me a particular sheet of paper. 'This is quite unusual,' he remarked. Taking the paper, I began to read."

"Before he left, the countess approached us and carefully examined my companion. Then, with a mocking tone, she complimented M. Achille Poirot on his cleverness. "Let's get down to business, Madame," she continued. "Luckily, we have been given some privacy. What do you want in return?" Confused, Poirot asked, "What do you mean by 'price'?" The countess, still laughing, revealed her true intentions: "Madame, you hold the key to our escape. You know the secret passages of this place. I ask again, what is your price?" And once more, she burst into laughter."

It was nearly dark when we finally reached our destination, the village bathed in the fading light of the summer evening. We pulled up to the edge of town and sought directions from a weathered local. "Granite Bungalow," he mumbled, scratching his head, "you're after Granite Bungalow, aye?" Confirming our destination, the man gestured towards a modest stone house at the far end of the road. "That's the Bungalow. Are you here to speak with the Detective?" Startled, Poirot interjected, "Detective? What Detective?" The man's eyes widened, "You haven't heard about the murder then? Gruesome affair, they say. Blood everywhere."

"That leaves us with two options: either he had prior knowledge of the event or he had his own motive for being absent." "And what might that motive be?" I inquired, doubtful. Poirot simply shrugged. "Who can say? Likely unsavory. Mr. Inglethorp appears to be a bit of a rogue, but that doesn't automatically make him a killer." I furrowed my brow, not entirely convinced. "We seem to be at odds, don't we?" Poirot remarked. "Let's agree to disagree for now. Time will reveal the truth. Let's now focus on other angles of the investigation."

"He will reveal everything he knows." "I appreciate it." Tuppence experienced a surge of excitement. This newfound courage drove her to take even bolder actions. "But there is one more thing." "Go on." Leaning in, Tuppence spoke in a hushed tone. "Who exactly is Mr. Brown?" A flicker of fear flashed across the woman's face. Mrs. Vandemeyer struggled to compose herself and regain her composure, but it was a feeble attempt. She nonchalantly shrugged. "You must not have done your homework if you are unaware that Mr. Brown is a mystery to all." "Except you," Tuppence remarked calmly.

She was standing there with her eyes cast down, a faint enigmatic smile on her lips, filling me with a sense of fear, like one might feel towards a beautiful but deadly snake. Poirot, always polite, inquired about M. Stonor and Mrs. Renauld, to which Madame Daubreuil responded calmly. As we made our way to the Villa Geneviève, Poirot kept a watchful eye on the lighted window. Suddenly, a cry for help shattered the silence, prompting Poirot to take swift action. With Cinderella's acrobatic skills, a dangerous rescue mission unfolded. The tension mounted as the true identity of the murderer was revealed, leaving us all in shock. The night was filled with chaos and danger, but in the end, justice prevailed.

"My initial plan was to spend a few days exploring the Falls, a sight I have yet to witness despite this being my third trip to Africa. Afterwards, I intended to travel to Jo’burg to analyze the state of affairs on the Rand. Back in my country, I am regarded as an expert on South African politics. However, based on what I have been told, Jo’burg will soon become a rather inhospitable destination. I have no desire to investigate the situation amidst a potential uprising." Race responded with a condescending smile. "I believe your concerns are unfounded, Sir Eustace."

"Who could have known?" Tommy added. "Can't fault him for that. Thanks to his quick move, I get to meet you all in person." The group seemed unsettled by his words, but the German leader calmed them with a simple gesture. "No one will spill the beans," he stated calmly. "But I'm still breathing," Tommy retorted. "Not for long," the German replied. The group murmured in agreement. Despite his racing heart, Tommy remained cool. "I beg to differ," he insisted. "I have no interest in meeting my demise."

Maltravers, a man with a young and beautiful wife, seemingly gathered all his available funds to pay for a life insurance policy for her before taking his own life. This scenario, although tragic, is not unheard of in our society. A friend of mine, Alfred Wright, who happens to be a director at Northern Union, has urged me to look into the details of this case. However, I must admit that I am not particularly optimistic about uncovering the truth. If the cause of death had been listed as heart failure, I might have been more hopeful. The term "heart failure" often serves as a convenient cover-up in such situations.

"Harry smirked. “We’re in a sticky situation, darling. Concerned?” “Not when I’m with you.” “Ah, but going out in a blaze of glory isn’t ideal. We can do better than that. Looks like they’re splitting into two groups this time. Landing in different spots. Now for my little dramatic touch.” Just then, a bright flame erupted from the cabin. Its glow revealed two mysterious figures huddled on the rooftop. “Using my worn-out clothes stuffed with rags as decoys. They won’t catch on right away. Come on, Anne, we must resort to extreme measures.” Holding hands, we sprinted across the island."

"Keep a close eye on the man-servant, Ivan. Do not let him escape. This is crucial," he slammed the receiver and faced me. "Do you understand now, Hastings? Let me clarify. Wilson did not die from poison, but from electrocution. A metal rod hidden in a chess piece conducted the fatal current through him when it touched a specific square on the floor. Wilson, being left-handed, had the electric burn on his left hand as the only clue."

Philips gestured subtly towards the prisoner, who remained oblivious to the implication. The motivation behind the deceased's decision to create a new will, despite the existence of the previous one, was a mystery to him. Perhaps the old lady had simply forgotten about the original will, or maybe she believed it had been invalidated by her marriage - there had been discussions on the matter. It was not uncommon for women to lack knowledge in legal matters. Notably, she had drafted a new will in favor of the prisoner a year prior. He intended to present evidence demonstrating that it was the prisoner who had served his stepmother coffee on the night of her demise.

"But why the delay? What is holding you back?” “I am awaiting the arrival of the Olympia. She is scheduled to return from New York on Tuesday.” “But if you already know the identity of the bond thief, why the hesitation? He might elude capture.” “Escape to a remote South Sea island with no extradition laws? No, my friend, life would be far from pleasant for him there. As for the reason behind my waiting, well, to the keen intellect of Hercule Poirot the solution is crystal clear, but for those less astute like Inspector McNeil, it may be prudent to conduct some inquiries to confirm the details. It is important to show compassion for those who lack the same level of insight.”

"Would you like to join me at the mortuary to inspect Wilson's body before the examination begins? Perhaps his tie-pin is out of place, offering a crucial clue to unravel the mystery." "My dear Japp, I've been tempted all evening to adjust your own tie-pin during dinner. May I? There, much better. Absolutely, let's head to the mortuary." Poirot seemed fully engrossed in the case, sparking a level of enthusiasm I hadn't seen in him for quite some time. I was glad to see him back to his usual self.

"As he rose, his hand found its way to my shoulder, his expression shifting entirely. Glistening tears welled up in his eyes. “Throughout this entire ordeal, my thoughts are consumed by the late Mrs. Inglethorp. She may not have been adored by many, but she showed great kindness to us Belgians. I am indebted to her.” I attempted to interject, but Poirot forged ahead. “Listen closely, Hastings. It would crush her spirit to know that I stood idly by while her husband, Alfred Inglethorp, faced arrest when a mere utterance from me could spare him!” In the days leading up to the inquest, Poirot maintained an unwavering pace. He held private discussions with Mr. Wells on two occasions and embarked on lengthy strolls through the countryside."

… I barely had time to entertain the chilling thought that had crossed my mind before Jack Renauld entered the room. Poirot greeted him with a professional demeanor. "Please, have a seat, sir. I apologize for the inconvenience, but you must understand that I find the atmosphere of the Villa quite unpleasant. M. Giraud and I have differing opinions on several matters. His lack of courtesy towards me has not gone unnoticed, and I have no intention of sharing any findings with him." "Of course, M. Poirot," replied the young man.

The appearance of ‘the Western Star’ on the date coincided with Lord Yardly preparing to settle down. The possible sale of the diamond posed a threat, leading to a double robbery plan by Gregory Rolf. Lady Yardly, fearing exposure, stages a robbery herself. Hercule Poirot uncovers the truth by observing the facts. The lady's deception is exposed, revealing a well-orchestrated scheme. Poirot's clever manipulation forces Rolf to hand over the stolen diamond. Mary Marvell's innocence is highlighted, while Lady Yardly is exposed as the true culprit. The complex web of lies and deceit is unraveled, leaving no stone unturned.

"Approximately fifteen minutes later, a tall man with a thick black moustache arrived at the front door claiming to have an appointment with Mr. Davenheim. Identifying himself as Mr. Lowen, he was escorted to the study per the banker's request. Nearly sixty minutes elapsed with no sign of Mr. Davenheim. Frustrated, Mr. Lowen rang the bell, indicating his need to depart in order to catch his train back to town. Mrs. Davenheim, puzzled by her husband's absence despite expecting the visitor, apologized for the situation."

"It slipped out of my grasp once, and I made sure not to reveal that I had it until a photographer produced a dozen copies of it!" "We all have our secrets," Tuppence remarked. "I reckon spy work does that to you!" During the silence that followed, Mr. Carter produced a worn-out brown book from his pocket. "Beresford just mentioned that I wouldn't have thought Sir James Peel Edgerton was guilty unless there was solid evidence. And he was right. It wasn't until I examined the contents of this small book that I could truly believe the unbelievable reality."

"I guess," I said, "that as usual, you won't provide any explanations?" "Actually, yes. No. 1 belonged to Monsieur Lawrence. No. 2 to Mademoiselle Cynthia. They're not crucial. I got them just for comparison. No. 3 is a bit more complex." "Oh?" "It's highly enlarged. You might have seen a hazy area across the image. I won't go into the details of the specific tools and techniques I used. It's a common method among law enforcement, and it allows for a quick capture of any object's fingerprints."

"What do you mean by ‘vanish’? To which category of vanishing are you alluding?” “Are vanishings organized and categorized, then?” I chuckled. Japp grinned as well. Poirot scowled at us both. “But of course they are! They are divided into three groups: First, and most frequent, the deliberate vanishing act. Second, the often falsified ‘amnesia’ scenario, uncommon, but occasionally legitimate. Third, homicide, and the more or less effective disposal of the corpse. Do you consider all three as unattainable?” “Almost certainly, I would say. You may lose your own memory, but someone would surely identify you particularly in the instance of a prominent figure like Davenheim.”

“It was inevitable that suspicion would fall on him, but concrete evidence, like the purchase of poison, was needed to seal his fate. Given Mr. Inglethorp’s distinctive appearance, acquiring such proof was not a challenge. Despite never directly interacting with Mr. Inglethorp, young Mace harbored no uncertainty that the man before him, clad in his attire and bearing his facial hair and spectacles, was anyone other than Alfred Inglethorp.” “Perhaps,” I replied, captivated by Poirot’s persuasiveness. “Yet, if that were true, why doesn’t he account for his whereabouts at six o’clock on Monday evening?” “Indeed, why?” Poirot pondered, his demeanor now composed.

Asking for a search, the chambermaid leaves the room unblemished. The fake necklace hidden in the French girl's bed was a masterstroke. Poirot reveals his trip to London to show a card with fingerprints. The thieves were caught, their method failed. Mrs. Opalsen mentions her pearls, and Poirot suggests a return visit. The author reflects on Poirot's role in averting a national crisis. Poirot and the author discuss the attempted assassination of the Prime Minister. Poirot deals with a charlady's case before receiving important visitors - Lord Estair and Mr. Bernard Dodge.

"Listen up, Tommy, what do you say we team up? Start a business together?"  "A business for the heisting of high-end jewelry?"  "Just a hypothetical. How about setting up some sort of financial operation?"  "Not sure. I'm not familiar with that world."  "I am, but I always got confused. Mixing up credits and debits got me the boot. But what about a collaboration? Sounds so adventurous. Like something out of a history book. A collaboration!"  "Operating as the Young Explorers, Incorporated."

"She should have known better than to put it in writing, but I refrained from pointing that out. You carried out her instructions, visited the antique store, were led through the concealed passage from the rear chamber, and suddenly found yourself at the mercy of your foes!” Harry shot me a glance. I caught his meaning and subtly moved closer to Sir Eustace. “Indeed,” Sir Eustace murmured, “it seems luck is not on your side! Let me think, this marks, the third confrontation.” “You're correct,” Harry acknowledged. “This marks the third confrontation. Twice you have outsmarted me - have you not heard that luck changes on the third attempt? Now it's my turn - protect him, Anne.” I was prepared."

Suzanne looked at me with a mixture of excitement and determination. "Anne, we're onto something big here," she said. "Nadina, the diamonds, Colonel Race...it's all connected." I felt a shiver run down my spine as I realized the implications of her words. This was no ordinary mystery we were unraveling. Suzanne leaned in closer, her eyes gleaming with anticipation. "We need to dig deeper, Anne. There's more to this than meets the eye." With a newfound sense of purpose, I nodded in agreement. It was time to uncover the truth behind the tangled web of secrets that lay before us.

He stared at me with a smile, suggesting I had erred. I denied it vehemently. “This roll is unexposed,” he pointed out. I left with a shred of dignity. It’s a humbling experience to realize one’s own foolishness. Yet no one savors that revelation. Suddenly, a model of the “Kenilworth Castle” caught my eye at the shipping office. An idea struck. I entered and inquired about the “Kilmorden Castle.” The ticket was exactly the amount of my inheritance. I opted for first class, sealing my fate on this adventure.

"Would you dare to ask me that question once more, mademoiselle?" "What are you implying?" "If the question were posed again, my response would differ. Someone is under suspicion, but they are not Chilean." "Who?" The question slipped quietly through her lips. "Jack Renauld." "What?" She exclaimed. "Jack? That's impossible. Who would even dare to suspect him?" "Giraud." "Giraud!" Her face turned pale. "I fear that man. He is ruthless. He will he will " She hesitated. But then a sense of bravery and resolve overtook her. In that moment, I recognized her as a fighter. Poirot, too, observed her closely.

"Ivan was the one who welcomed you in," she explained. "He confided in me, revealing his belief that Gilmour Wilson's death was not natural, but the result of a mistaken poisoning intended for my uncle."  "Mistaken?"  "Yes, the poison was never meant for Wilson."  Her initial suspicion had dissipated, and she spoke with fervor.  "Why would anyone want to poison Dr. Savaronoff?"  Shrugging, she admitted, "I'm clueless. My uncle doesn't confide in me much, understandably so. He barely knows me."

“You were right, Miss Tuppence. I have been certain of his identity for a while now, starting from the night Mrs. Vandemeyer died.” “Ah!” Tuppence gasped. “We are faced with the logic of facts. There are two possibilities. Either she took the chloral herself, which I completely dismiss, or ” “Yes?” “Or it was in the brandy you gave her. Only three people touched that brandy - you, Miss Tuppence, myself, and Mr. Julius Hersheimmer!” Jane Finn stirred and sat up, looking at the speaker with wide eyes.

I had my suspicions about him, particularly his unwavering insistence on Cabin 17. Maybe it was just his stubborn nature shining through. Stubbornness can be quite the trait. It wouldn't hurt to have a chat with Mr. Chichester, I thought to myself. After a quick fix to my unruly hair, I made my way back up to the deck, determined. Luck was on my side. I spotted my target by the rail, sipping on beef tea. Stepping closer, I addressed him. "I trust you've let go of the Cabin 17 issue," I ventured, flashing a smile. "I believe holding grudges goes against the grain of true forgiveness," Mr. Chichester replied, his tone chilly.

I am certain of Mrs. Renauld's innocence in this case, as her fainting was genuine and her anguish real. She did not need to fake her grief, as she had already shown true emotion upon hearing of her husband's death. The open door at the crime scene puzzled Poirot, who believed that the culprit must have left through the window. This theory was supported by the lack of footprints in one of the flower beds, which had been smoothed over with a rake to erase any trace of the intruder's presence. Despite initial doubts, I began to consider the possibility that the murderer had indeed escaped through the window, opening up a new avenue of investigation.

Poirot had humiliated me completely. It was time to teach him a lesson. I planned to wait before forgiving him. He had led me into making a complete fool of myself! After being away for a few days, I returned to find Poirot preparing to leave. "Good timing, Hastings. I was worried you wouldn't make it back in time to join me." "Are you leaving for a case?" "Yes, although I must say, this one doesn't seem very promising at first glance. The Northern Union Insurance Company has requested that I look into the death of a Mr. "

"I overheard the conversation." "What did you hear?" "It was rather heated. Shortly after, there was a commotion. Running into the hallway, I nearly bumped into Mrs. Middleton. That's when the gunshot rang out. The entrance to the gun-room was barricaded from the inside, so we hurried around the house to the window. By the time we made it inside, the killer had already fled. Unfortunately, my uncle," she hesitated, "was found with a fatal gunshot wound to the head. I immediately instructed Mrs. Middleton to contact the authorities. I made sure not to disturb anything in the room, leaving it undisturbed as I discovered it."

Her cheeks were crimson, and she let out a series of yawns. “Cynthia is absolutely petrified,” Mrs. Cavendish murmured with a steady voice. She herself was clad in a pristine white gown. I realized then that it was later than I had initially thought. A faint glimmer of daylight peeked through the window curtains, while the clock on the mantelpiece indicated it was nearly five o’clock. Suddenly, a muffled scream erupted from the bed, causing me to jump. The elderly woman was overtaken by a new wave of agony, her convulsions so intense they were horrifying to witness.

It was clear that Madame Beroldy was involved in a complicated web of lies and deceit, leading to a shocking murder. Despite her initial acquittal, the truth eventually came to light. Madame Beroldy's manipulative nature and hidden motives were finally exposed, revealing a dark and twisted tale of betrayal and revenge. The case was a tangled web of secrets and lies, shrouded in mystery and intrigue. The shocking revelation of Madame Beroldy's true intentions left everyone stunned, proving that sometimes the most innocent-looking faces hide the darkest hearts.

I glanced at the paper in my hand, the key to the mystery. The numbers and words held a secret waiting to be unraveled. Kilmorden Castle, a place shrouded in intrigue and possibilities. A buried treasure, a missing heir, a claimant to a title. The numbers, a cryptic message or a mere diversion? I needed to get to the bottom of this, to explore every avenue until the truth revealed itself. The journey ahead was fraught with obstacles, but I was determined to see it through to the end. The pieces of the puzzle were scattered, waiting for me to put them together and reveal the hidden truth.

“You know?” “Certainly I know. The subject of the quarrel was Mademoiselle Marthe Daubreuil.” Renauld sprang round, startled. The magistrate leaned forward. “Is this so, monsieur.” Jack Renauld bowed his head. “Yes,” he admitted. “I love Mademoiselle Daubreuil, and I wish to marry her. When I informed my father of the fact, he flew at once into a violent rage. Naturally I could not stand hearing the girl I loved insulted, and I, too, lost my temper.” M. Hautet looked across at Mrs. Renauld. “You were aware of this attachment, madame.” “I feared it,” she replied simply. “Mother,” cried the boy. “You too! Marthe is as good as she is beautiful. What can you have against her?”

"Mace, did you recently provide strychnine to someone without authorization?" "Yes, sir." "When did this occur?" "Last Monday night." "Monday? Not Tuesday?" "No, sir, Monday, the 16th." "Can you disclose the identity of the buyer?" The room fell silent. "Yes, sir. It was Mr. Inglethorp." All eyes immediately turned towards Alfred Inglethorp, who remained stoic. A sense of disbelief washed over his face as the accusation was made. There was a moment where it seemed he might stand up, but he stayed in his seat, though his expression betrayed his shock. "Are you absolutely certain of your statement?" questioned the Coroner firmly. "Absolutely, sir."

“But, my goodness! What will happen to Bella?” “If I were in your shoes,” Poirot advised, “I wouldn't worry too much. The French legal system tends to be forgiving towards young and beautiful individuals involved in crimes of passion. A skilled attorney could argue for mitigating circumstances. It won't be easy for you” “I'm not concerned about that. You see, M. Poirot, in a sense I do feel responsible for my father's death. If not for me and my relationship with this woman, he would still be alive. And then my foolish mistake in taking the wrong coat.

"Was the man pleased or chagrined? It was unclear. He simply asked Marchaud: “Do you have the other one?” “Yes, sir.” “Then bring her in.” “The other” referred to Madame Daubreuil. She entered angrily, vehemently protesting. “I object, sir! This is an outrage! What is my involvement in all of this?” “Madame,” Giraud said harshly, “I am not investigating one murder, but two! You could be responsible for both for all I know.” “How dare you?” she exclaimed. “How dare you accuse me with such a baseless claim! It is scandalous.” “Scandalous, you say? And what about this?” Bending down, he once again picked up the hair, displaying it. “Do you recognize this, madame?” He moved closer to her."

The roots of the tree in question extended all the way to the rear of the bed, making it necessary to step on the bed in order to reach them. The commissary pointed out that due to the dry weather, no footprints would be visible on the paths or driveway, but they would be noticeable on the soft soil of the flower-bed. Poirot carefully inspected the smooth surface of the bed, confirming Bex's observation that there were no marks or indentations. Satisfied, Poirot abruptly shifted his attention to the neighboring flower-bed for further examination.

On a blood-stained outgoing footmark, an ingoing one is found. I ponder, did he return for the jade figures as an afterthought? It's utterly absurd." "Well, he has unmistakably exposed himself." "Isn't it? I must say, Hastings, it defies logic. It disturbs my little gray cells. Let's investigate his bedroom ah, indeed; there is a blood smear on the lintel and just faint footmarks stained with blood. They belong to Robert Grant, and only him, close to the victim Robert Grant the sole individual who approached the house. Undoubtedly, it can be no one else.

"Apologies, Hastings, I need a brief walk." Upon his return, after roughly an hour, his eyes sparkled with an unusual excitement. He placed his cane on the table, meticulously tending to his hat's nap before speaking. "Luckily, my friend, we have no pressing matters. Let us focus entirely on this current inquiry." "And what inquiry might that be?" "The astonishing affordability of Mrs. Robinson's recent apartment." "Poirot, you can't be serious!" "Oh, but I am deadly serious."

Hurriedly releasing his grip on me, he quickly adjusted a set of candlesticks, muttering under his breath: “Yes, that changes everything, everything.” Suddenly, he appeared to reach a conclusion. “Let's go!” he exclaimed. “We need to take action immediately. Where is Mr. Cavendish?” John was found in the smoking-room. Poirot approached him directly. “Mr. Cavendish, I have some urgent business in Tadminster. A new lead. Can I borrow your car?” “Certainly. Are you leaving right away?” “If you don't mind.” John summoned the servant and instructed him to bring the car around. Within ten minutes, we were speeding through the park and onto the main road to Tadminster.

"Vandemeyer is dining out tonight, did you know?" "Yes, I believe so, but she won't be out late. Otherwise, she would have brought the latchkey." "Good. I'll visit her around ten o'clock. What time are you expected to be back?" "Around nine-thirty or ten, but I could return earlier." "Under no circumstances should you do that. It might raise suspicion if you didn't stay out until the usual time. Be back by nine-thirty. I'll come at ten. Mr. Hersheimmer will wait downstairs in a taxi, maybe." "He just purchased a new Rolls-Royce car," Tuppence mentioned with pride. "Even better. If I manage to get the address from her, we can go there immediately, bringing Mrs.…"

Poirot, Bex, and Giraud were gathered in the room, discussing the disappearance of a dagger from the glass jar. Hastings then admitted his grave fault of showing a young lady the body, leaving the door unlocked for twenty minutes. The commissary found it deplorable, but Giraud surprisingly called it admirable, suggesting that the assassin or an accomplice had been near the Villa recently. Poirot noted that the assassin wore gloves, ensuring no fingerprints were left on the dagger. The magistrate's clerk began gathering the papers as M. Hautet announced the end of their work in the room.

The main reason we moved to Little Hampsly was the proximity to Hampsly Cavern, a hidden cave containing artifacts from the Aurignacian culture. In the village, we had a small Museum where the curator and my father would spend their days excavating remains of woolly rhinoceros and cave bear. After a persistent cough, my father fell ill with a fever and quickly deteriorated. Despite the doctor's efforts, he succumbed to double pneumonia just four days later.

I trailed behind him, silently mimicking the Barotsi woman I had once observed near the Falls. Unlike her, I wasn't balancing a frying-pan on my head. His pace was so brisk, it proved challenging to keep pace. "Harry," I finally spoke up, my voice meek, "are we trekking all the way to Rhodesia?" Abruptly, he turned, bursting into laughter as he swept me off my feet. "I'm crazy, my love, I admit it. But I adore you so much." "We're both insane. And, Harry, you never asked, but I'm not sacrificing anything! I wanted this journey!" That was a couple of years back. We're still residing on the island.

As Giraud laid his hat on the table and prepared to deliver his lecture on detective work, Poirot settled in to listen attentively. Giraud confidently outlined his case against Jack Renauld, detailing the motives and means that led to his arrest. But Poirot, with a glint of mischief in his eye, interjected with a crucial detail that Giraud had overlooked. The two men engaged in a battle of wits, each trying to outsmart the other with their theories and deductions. As they walked towards the sea to review the case, Poirot guided Hastings towards the truth with his characteristic cryptic remarks. It was a challenging and exhilarating intellectual exercise, where every detail mattered, and every clue led them closer to unraveling the mystery.

Tommy was taken aback when he saw the note in Tuppence's handwriting, offering him ten shillings. He quickly realized her cleverness in using a different name to protect his identity. Without hesitation, he reached for the money, but the man hesitated. After a moment of tension, Tommy handed over a ten-shilling note and finally got hold of the message. As he read it, his heart sank - Tuppence was in danger, and they were being moved. Wales, Holyhead - the words echoed in his mind as he carefully folded the note, knowing he had to act fast to protect her.

I hadn’t meant to disturb him by advertising my presence. But suddenly I heard a light footfall behind me, and his voice broke the silence: “Miss Beddingfeld.” “Yes?” I turned around. “I want to apologize. I behaved like a boor last night.” “It was a peculiar night,” I replied. “You may not know, but you are in danger,” he warned. “They are ruthless. Your only chance is to persuade them they’re mistaken. Be careful, always be on the lookout for danger. If you fall into their hands, tell the whole truth.” “Why warn me?” I asked. “It may be the last thing I can do for you,” he said. “Goodbye,” he said as he left, his footsteps echoing along the deck. I was left alone, wondering about the danger that lay ahead.

His cohorts may have incapacitated him with a cloth and chloroform, but I fail to see what their goal was. He is unlikely to be of any help to them now, as he will be closely monitored until the situation with the Prime Minister is resolved. It's possible that he intended to mislead the police? However, he claims that something was placed over his nose and mouth, and he recalls nothing beyond that. This does not lead the investigation astray; it sounds remarkably truthful. Let's head to the station. France may reveal more clues. Although I have my doubts. It's astonishing that the Prime Minister hasn't been found in such a confined area. If the military and police of two nations haven't located him, how can I?

"Dogs followed 'Rita', probably. And I guess that's who Annette meant by Marguerite. I didn't catch on then." The idea saddened him slightly, as it suggested that Mrs. Vandemeyer and the girl were close. The cab stopped at the Ritz. Tommy entered the esteemed establishment eagerly, but his excitement was short-lived. He was told that Miss Cowley had left fifteen minutes earlier. PERPLEXED momentarily, Tommy wandered into the dining area and requested a meal of exceptional quality. His recent four-day confinement had reminded him of the importance of good food.

"People are always curious about my activities." "Not in this bustling city. Everyone is too preoccupied to even take notice of you." "You seem to have a knack for making such comments. But no matter, I'll let it go. It will be quite an adventure. What are your plans for this afternoon?" "Well," Tuppence pondered. "I was considering hats! Or maybe silk stockings! Or perhaps..." I wiped away my tears, feeling the lingering weakness in my body. Gripping his hand tightly, I wished for a peaceful death in that moment, under his watchful gaze. I drank without hesitation, listening to his comforting words, spoken in a gentle, coaxing tone. "Rest now, don't worry. Let your strength return. No need for questions." And with that, I drifted back into slumber, feeling reassured by his presence.

Tommy pondered his next move. He was determined to seek revenge on Mr. Brown, but beyond that, his plans were uncertain. He observed me quietly for a moment before getting down to business. When I caught sight of myself in the mirror thirty minutes later, I was taken aback. “No. 13 on Deck D?” I exclaimed in horror. “Absolutely not, I refuse to stay in that cabin.” Superstition had always been my weakness, and the thought of being in cabin 13 sent shivers down my spine. However, since the gentleman hasn’t moved in yet, he might not mind switching.” Eagerly, I accepted the offer and the steward went off to seek approval from the purser.

"Come on, Poirot," I insisted, "let's get moving." "Excellent, my friend, excellent! Where to, and against whom? Give me specifics, if you please." "Against the Big Four, obviously." "That goes without saying. But how do you propose we do it?" "The authorities," I suggested tentatively. Poirot chuckled. "They would accuse us of daydreaming. We have no evidence to go on absolutely none. We must bide our time." "Wait for what?" "Wait for them to make a move. Consider this, in England you all understand and appreciate boxing. If one fighter doesn't act, the other will, and by allowing the opponent to initiate the attack, one gains insights about him."

We walked around the deck three times before settling into adjacent deck chairs. The night was silent, with no one else in sight. Colonel Race was a man of few words, a Rhodesian with a stern demeanor that intrigued me. As we sat there in silence, I couldn't help but wonder if he could be more than just a dance partner. I entertained the thought of marriage, even though he hadn't proposed. It was always best to be prepared, as the Boy Scouts say. In the dim light, I found myself considering the possibility of a future together, a future that seemed both thrilling and dangerous.

"Can you believe it, Poirot? The chambermaid was the culprit all along," I exclaimed, shocked at the revelation. Poirot merely chuckled, his eyes twinkling with amusement. As we left the scene of the crime behind us, I couldn't help but marvel at the brilliance of my quirky little friend. Our next adventure awaited, and I knew that with Poirot by my side, there was no puzzle we couldn't solve.

"He meticulously adjusted his mustache, pondering each detail. 'Let's see! One clue connects to the next, guiding us forward. Does this piece align with the puzzle? Yes, perfect! Onward we go. I was trapped by my captor, a man who clearly had been following my every move. Despite my attempts to reason with him, he seemed determined to keep me captive. I found myself bound and gagged in a dusty attic, completely at his mercy. As the night wore on, I struggled against my restraints, desperate for a way out. And then, in the dim moonlight, I spotted a glint of broken glass in the corner. An idea began to form in my mind. Despite the pain and stiffness, I knew I had to try. Slowly, I started to roll towards the glass, inching closer with every agonizing movement. It was a risky plan, but it was my only hope of escape.

"It would greatly annoy me if anyone dared to make a fool of you." "Understood. But I feel obliged to inform you " "I am well aware of everything. You are my adversary! So be it. It doesn't bother me in the slightest." "As long as it's all fair and transparent, I have no objections." "You possess the quintessential English love for 'fair-play!' Now that your moral concerns have been met, let us leave without delay. Time is of the essence. Our time in England has been brief yet adequate. I have uncovered what I sought to discover." The tone was nonchalant, yet I detected a hidden threat in the statement. "However " I started, then fell silent. "Nevertheless, as you wish! Undoubtedly, you are content with the role you are performing."

Her chest rose and fell with each breath, her eyes widening in disbelief. "You're involved in this?" I simply nodded, knowing I had hit the mark. The intensity of her emotions was clear as day. A brief silence followed, her gaze fixed on me. Then, with a firm nod, she spoke. "Well, paint me surprised! Show me everything. I want to witness the darkness." "What do you mean?" I inquired. "Exactly what I said. Believe me, I have a fascination for crimes. Why else would I risk my feet in these high heels, trudging through this mess?" Hours had been spent scouring the area, searching for clues.

As she ascended the stairs, Mrs. Inglethorp requested, "Just bring my despatch-case up for me, dear. I'm heading to bed." The wide door leading to the hall provided a clear view. Standing up alongside Cynthia, I noticed John nearby. Thus, three witnesses could confirm that Mrs. Inglethorp carried her untouched coffee. Dr. Bauerstein's presence throughout the evening dampened my mood. It felt as though he would never depart. Finally, he stood up, bringing me a sense of relief. "I'll accompany you to the village," Mr. Inglethorp mentioned. "I need to meet with our agent regarding the estate accounts." Addressing John, he added, "There's no need for anyone to stay up."

Upon unraveling the mystery, it became clear that de Castina, or whoever she truly was, had arranged to rendezvous at the Mill House. The pieces fell into place as I deduced their clever tactic of obtaining simultaneous house viewings to avoid suspicion. The sudden encounter between the "doctor" and the Moth Ball man indicated an unforeseen and unsettling turn of events. With the disguise discarded, the "doctor" discreetly trailed the woman to Marlow, leaving a trail of unanswered questions in their wake.

Depression had settled heavily upon him, a burden impossible to shake. He was certain of the futility of their mission, the enemy far ahead by over three hours. As the clock struck seven, a young boy pointed them towards "t’ Moat House" around the corner. A decrepit iron gate creaked open, leading down a path obscured by fallen leaves. An eerie sensation enveloped them as they proceeded up the deserted driveway.

I believed I was being clever as I followed him through the swaying portières. Suzanne put up a fight, but eventually agreed to carry out my plan. Eventually, we arrived at a rundown building and I was ushered in to see Mr. Harry Rayburn, who seemed to recognize me. He questioned why I had fallen into the trap again, but I remained composed. Mr. Chichester-Pettigrew tried to get down to business, but I insisted on speaking with Sir Eustace Pedler. After a brief exchange, I was led to Sir Eustace, who greeted me warmly and admitted to being the 'Colonel'.

In some mysterious manner, I found myself in a perilous situation. There was a piece of information, real or perceived, that made others desperate to eliminate me, and it was somehow connected to the valuable diamonds. I was convinced that one individual, The Man in the Brown Suit named Harry Rayburn, held the missing puzzle piece. However, he had disappeared into the shadows, evading capture. It was unlikely that our paths would cross again. Shaking off sentimental thoughts of Harry Rayburn, I refocused on the present circumstances.

A large settee covered in chintz sat against the wall, the window seats also upholstered in the same faded fabric. Poirot, with his small cigarette in hand, discussed their plan of action. The key to their investigation, he believed, lay within this room. They would carefully examine the desk's documents for any hidden clues. After some questioning, it was revealed that Mr. Marsh had a second will and had hired workmen from Plymouth to create a secret compartment in the fireplace. With this new lead, they set off to Plymouth to uncover the truth.

"And, really, he may be for all we know against him. Well, to continue my surmises. Rayburn is the ‘Man in the Brown Suit.’ He had read the paper he dropped. On the way there somebody knifes him” “Who?” I interpolated. “Chichester. Yes, it all fits in. Cable to Lord Nasby that you have found ‘The Man in the Brown Suit,’ and your fortune’s made, Anne!” “There are several things you’ve overlooked.

Marthe Daubreuil had a plan, but it was thwarted by a struggle with Madame Renauld. Although Marthe tried to make it look like suicide, she was checkmated by another woman with strong hands. Poirot suspected Marthe from the start, based on her anxious eyes. Madame Renauld's son, Jack, was kept in the dark about his father's past until Poirot revealed the truth. Jack decided to start a new life in South America with his mother. Poirot advised him to be honest with his love interest, Bella, and to ask for her forgiveness. In the end, Poirot received a visit from a film star, Mary Marvell, who was being threatened over a valuable diamond. Poirot advised her to keep the diamond safe until the threat had passed.

‘Instruct them to arrange a taxi for me,’ she demanded, hastily adjusting her hat in front of the mirror. Within moments, she was gone, descending the steps and slipping into the waiting taxi. Just then, Julius returned holding an unfolded letter. "Hersheimmer," he addressed Tommy, "Tuppence has embarked on a solo investigation." "Oh, bother!" Tommy exclaimed. "Indeed she has."

Flemming and her friends appeared to be incredibly mundane to me. Their conversations revolved around themselves, their children, and the struggles of procuring quality milk for their little ones. They would then transition to discussing the challenges of finding reliable servants, recounting their interactions with the staff at the Registry Office. It was rare to see them engage with current events or show any interest in the world beyond their comfort zone. They harbored a distaste for travel, finding everything abroad too unfamiliar compared to their beloved England.

In the Sunday papers there was a brief notice regarding the unexpected passing of the renowned K.C., Sir James Peel Edgerton. The following day's paper provided a detailed account of the deceased man's successful career. The specific circumstances surrounding his sudden death remained undisclosed to the public. Tommy's earlier prediction of the events had proven to be accurate. The entire operation had been orchestrated by a single individual. With their leader gone, the group quickly disintegrated. Kramenin hastily returned to Russia, departing from England at dawn on Sunday. The criminal gang fled Astley Priors in a state of panic, leaving incriminating evidence behind in their rush, ultimately sealing their own fate.

"It was a beautiful day!” I exclaimed. “Poirot, you must be joking!” “Not at all. The temperature was a balmy 80 degrees in the shade. Remember that, my friend. Her face was elongated and pallid, with captivating deep eyes that blazed with an almost zealous intensity. She resembled more a ancient priestess than a contemporary woman from France. Greeting us with a distant formality, she stated, "I have been interrogated by the authorities numerous times, gentlemen."

He confidently approaches the village pharmacist, buying strychnine using his own name and a fake tale involving a dog. It's hard to believe anyone would be so foolish, only a madman would act in such a way, risking being hanged. "I don't understand," I started to say.

The Chinaman's eyes fluttered rapidly, seemingly agreeing, and he uttered another Italian term, "carrozza." A few more whispered Italian words reached my ears before he suddenly collapsed. The doctor motioned for me to step back. It was done. The man was gone. I exited, feeling utterly confused. "Handel's Largo," and a "carrozza." If memory served, a carrozza was a carriage. What could possibly be the significance of those seemingly simple words? The man was Chinese, not Italian, so why speak in Italian? If he was truly Ingles's servant, wouldn't he know English? "There," he said, "although I can produce no proof that would count in a court of law, I speak from my own knowledge. "Poirot, I believe you were the last person to see the dagger. Is that correct?" Inspector Giraud's piercing eyes bore into Poirot's. "Oui, it is true," Poirot replied calmly. "But I did not touch it, I did not take it." "Then who did?" Giraud pressed, his tone accusatory. Poirot's gaze remained steady. "That, my friend, is the question, is it not?" The room fell into a tense silence as everyone pondered the implications of the missing dagger. It was a crucial piece of evidence, now vanished into thin air. The investigation had just taken a sharp turn, and the truth seemed more elusive than ever.

"Pedler was deceived into thinking Rayburn was his new secretary, not Mr. Pagett," Suzanne whispered anxiously, her hand squeezing mine under the table. "But where is Rayburn now?" Later that day, we were interrupted from our nap by a note delivered by a page-boy, providing us with a chance to hear Sir Eustace's perspective on the situation.

“Excuse me, Monsieur Poirot?” My little friend tapped himself gently on the chest. “Please, have a seat. You got my message. I am determined to solve this puzzle. You can help me in some way. "He was securely locked up for the night in an upper-story room of one of the farms roundabouts which the Military have taken over, but this morning the room was empty and the bird had flown.” Secretly I was rather pleased. "To see those two brought to justice, that is a different story. Japp will do his best, but I fear we may have to leave it to Fate, or le bon Dieu, whichever you prefer." Poirot raised an eyebrow, "M. Stonor, how long has the English chauffeur, Masters, been with M. Renauld?" Stonor replied confidently, "Over a year." I never knew what bêche-de-mer was, and I probably never will. I've made guesses before and they've always been wrong. I mistook it for a bad melon at first, but a Dutch waitress set me straight. Lemon juice and sugar made it much more palatable. I was glad to finally meet a pawpaw.

Nadina, the Russian dancer, took her final bow on stage, accepting praise from the Manager.
