I almost died at the sight of her wicked face, but I managed to muster a hesitant smile and asked in French about my whereabouts. She seemed confused and summoned the man she was conversing with. He lingered by the screen, his face obscured in shadow, and addressed me in French. Though his voice was unremarkable and hushed, for some reason, he instilled more fear in me than the woman did. It was as if he could see into my soul, yet I continued to act my role.

"Where was it eventually located?” “Atop a wardrobe.” “On the prisoner’s wardrobe?” “Yes, that’s correct.” “Did someone else find it?” “No, I found it myself.” “So, you know where you found it?” “Yes, it was on the prisoner’s wardrobe.” “Good.” An employee from Parkson’s, Theatrical Costumiers, stated that on June 29th, they had provided Mr. L. Cavendish with a black beard as requested. The order was made by letter, along with a postal order. They did not retain the letter. All transactions were recorded in their records.

CARTER, "I've come across something that has caught my attention. It's possible that I am completely mistaken, but I highly doubt it. If my deductions are accurate, the girl in Manchester was a decoy. The entire situation was orchestrated, including the fake package, in order to throw us off the trail. It seems to me that we were getting close to the truth.   I believe I have identified the real Jane Finn, and I have a hunch about the whereabouts of the documents. It's purely speculative, but I have a gut feeling that it will prove to be correct. In any case, I have placed it in a sealed envelope, take it for what it's worth."

"After the bonds went missing from the trunk, a thorough search of the ship was conducted but yielded no results. It was discovered that the stolen bonds were sold in small parcels shortly after the ship docked in New York. This led to suspicions falling on Mr. Ridgeway. He was then searched and questioned, but the mystery remained unsolved. Determined to get to the bottom of this, Monsieur Hercule Poirot and his friend Captain Hastings decided to pay a visit to the Bank. Upon arrival, they were escorted to a small office where they met the joint general managers, Mr. Vavasour and Mr. Shaw, both of whom had dedicated their lives to the service of the Bank."

I need to get a full grasp of this Rand situation. The dancing was quite intense. I had a couple of dances with Anne Beddingfeld and she had to act like she was enjoying herself. There was one dance with Mrs. Blair, who didn't bother pretending, and I also danced with a few other ladies who caught my eye. Afterwards, we headed to supper. I had requested champagne; the steward recommended Clicquot 1911 as the top choice on the ship and I agreed. It turned out to be the key to getting Colonel Race to open up. Instead of his usual reserved self, he became surprisingly chatty.

"And what about Number Four?" I inquired. "I am starting to grasp his methods now. It may seem amusing, Hastings, but understanding a man's character and predicting his actions is crucial. It's a game of wits between us, with him inadvertently revealing his thoughts to me while I keep mine hidden. He operates openly, while I lurk in the shadows. Let me tell you, Hastings, my deliberate inaction only serves to increase their fear of me each passing day.

In the meantime, Jane Finn was suddenly struck with dread. What if they found her dead, a victim of Mr. Brown's hand? But then he chuckled at his own melodramatic thoughts. The doctor ushered them into a room. There, on a white bed with bandages wrapped around her head, lay the girl. The scene felt surreal, almost too perfectly staged. With wide, questioning eyes, the girl gazed at them. Sir James addressed her first. “Miss Finn,” he began, “this is your cousin, Mr.…”

Poirot glanced at me with a raised eyebrow. "Here we go!" he whispered. "You've already spotted a goddess!" "But, come on, wasn't she?" I pressed. "Possibly. I didn't take notice," Poirot replied calmly. "You must have seen her?" I insisted. "My friend, two people hardly ever perceive the same thing. You, for example, saw a goddess. I," he paused. "Yes?" "I only saw a girl with worried eyes," Poirot stated seriously. Just then, we arrived at a large green gate, and both of us gasped in unison. Standing before it was an imposing police officer. He signaled us to stop. "You can't go through, gentlemen.

After receiving a tempting job offer in Argentina, Tommy Beresford decided to accept it without hesitation. This brought a strange smile to Julius's face, who promptly tossed the letter aside in annoyance. "What a fool," he muttered under his breath.   Following a call to Sir James, Tommy made his way to South Audley Mansions. Upon arrival, he met Albert, who was diligently carrying out his duties. Tommy wasted no time in introducing himself as a friend of Tuppence's, causing Albert to relax and express his longing for some excitement in the quiet surroundings.

I struggled against the grip on my throat, biting and scratching in the most approved feminine fashion. The man had to keep me from crying out, hindering his movements. Despite my efforts, I felt myself weakening. Sensing this, my assailant put out all his strength. Suddenly, another shadow appeared, running on swift noiseless feet. With one powerful blow, he sent my opponent crashing to the deck. Finally released, I fell back against the rail, feeling sick and trembling.

Despite the excruciating pain and my inability to shield my face, I struggled to maintain a specific course. I found myself spinning in all directions except the one I desired. Eventually, I reached my target, nearly brushing it with my tied hands. Yet, the task was far from simple. It required an eternity to maneuver the glass into a suitable position against the wall to rub against my restraints. The painstaking process nearly broke my spirit, but I persevered until I finally managed to cut through the ropes binding my wrists.

Upon discovering the Countess Rossakoff's connection to the Big Four, I immediately launched an investigation into her background. It was uncovered that she had a child who was believed to have perished, but inconsistencies in the tale made me question if the child could still be alive. After an exhaustive search, I managed to locate the boy and secured his custody by offering a hefty sum. The child, in a pitiful state of malnourishment, was sheltered with caring individuals, where I discreetly captured a photograph of him in his unfamiliar environment.

Poirot carefully surveyed the room, running his hand over the furniture and inspecting the cleanliness with approval. Suddenly, he straightened a crooked hearth-rug and discovered a small piece of paper hidden beneath it. Upon closer examination, it was revealed to be a torn fragment of a cheque, signed by M. Renauld to someone named Duveen. The commissary, flustered by his oversight, quickly turned to Madame Renauld for answers. With a renewed sense of determination, they left the room, leaving behind the mystery of the unexpected guest from the night before.

"Japp noted, 'Turned away for a moment, and the other fellow snatched up a revolver and shot him. The one Mrs. Havering handed over to us was fully loaded and I suppose the other one was also. Curious what darn fool things people do. Fancy keeping two loaded revolvers hanging up on your wall.' I inquired about his thoughts on the case as we exited the gruesome chamber. 'Well, I’d got my eye on Havering to begin with. Oh, yes!' he said, acknowledging my astonishment. 'Havering has one or two shady incidents in his past.'"

His whole demeanor shifted when he chuckled. His face took on a youthful, joyful, almost unrecognizable appearance. I savored my soup, gently reminding him that he had yet to offer me his counsel. "Ah, indeed, what I meant to suggest was this: If I were in your shoes, I would lay low here until you have fully recuperated. Your foes will assume you perished. They will not be surprised by the absence of your body. It would have been shattered against the cliffs and swept away by the current." A chill ran down my spine. "Once you have regained your strength, you can discreetly travel to Beira and secure passage on a ship bound for England." "That sounds dreadfully dull," I scoffed. "That remark betrays a lack of wisdom."

"Will you promise it?” “Yes, absolutely,” replied the other eagerly. “I promise it.” Tuppence reached out a quivering hand towards the glass. “Alright.” Her lips parted obediently. Mrs. Vandemeyer breathed a sigh of relief, momentarily caught off guard. In a sudden movement, Tuppence lifted the glass with force. The liquid inside splattered onto Mrs. Vandemeyer’s face, causing her to gasp, and in that moment, Tuppence swiftly grabbed the revolver from the edge of the washstand with her right hand.

"Mr. Carter sat silently, his tired demeanor evident. Occasionally, he would brush his lips, masking a hidden smile. After she had spoken, he nodded solemnly. “Not a lot to go on. But intriguing. Very intriguing. If I may be so bold, you two are an interesting pair. Who knows, maybe you'll accomplish what others could not. I've always believed in luck, you see.” He stopped briefly before continuing. “So, what do you say? Are you up for some excitement? How does the idea of working with me sound? Nothing official, of course."

I had to find a way to enter the room unnoticed, carefully observing my surroundings. A branch extending from the nearby tree caught my attention, offering a potential solution. Despite the uncertainty of its strength, I made the risky decision to crawl along it. As I inched forward, the branch groaned and wavered, heightening the danger of the situation. Ignoring the ominous drop below, I persevered until I reached my intended destination.

“Renauld? Someone who was lurking near the Villa just before midnight that evening, someone who stood to gain from his demise – the shoe seems to fit Jack Renauld all too perfectly. The murder may not have been planned in advance. Ah, but then there’s the matter of the dagger!” My attention was suddenly piqued; I had overlooked this detail. “Indeed,” I mused. “The additional dagger discovered on the vagabond belonged to Mrs. Renauld. Two daggers in play, it seems.” “Indeed, and given that they were identical, it follows that Jack Renauld possessed the other. However, that aspect does not overly concern me. In fact, I have a notion or two regarding that.”

"He managed to get the case dismissed, but it ruined two young men and left them to face the world as thieves. It devastated the old man, leading to a bitter confrontation with his son. The son, silent and proud, enlisted in the war with his friend, who ended up losing his life due to recklessness. The old man, revealing his bitterness towards a woman, took on a new identity and lived a numb existence on an island. But when he encountered a man who recognized him, he was stirred back to life. The man revealed his involvement in the robbery, his marriage to the woman, and the hidden diamonds. The old man, determined to clear his name, followed the man to England on a boat."

I caught a glimpse of her true nature - a proud, untamed creature, untouched by the constraints of society. She let out a cry, revealing the torment she endured in this despicable place. "You have no idea," she exclaimed. "I understand," I replied, urging her not to act impulsively. "Impulsive?" She scoffed at my caution. And then, to my regret, I blurted out, "Dr. Bauerstein has been taken into custody." Her face turned cold, devoid of emotion. "John already informed me," she stated, her voice devoid of feeling.

"Is he a small guy? Talks with his hands? A Belgian from the village?” “Yeah,” I replied excitedly. “He’s been around, huh?” “Oh, yeah, he’s been here, more than once. A friend of yours, eh? You Hall folks are a sight!” And he grinned even more playfully. “So, do the Hall people visit here a lot?” I inquired casually. He winked knowingly. “One does, sir. No need to say who. And quite generous too! Oh, thank you, sir, much obliged.” I continued on my way quickly.

As we embarked on our journey, I couldn't contain my excitement. The fresh air filled me with joy and anticipation for the trip ahead. Despite my cheerful outlook, my companion reminded me of the impending task awaiting us at our destination. I waved off his concerns, confident in his ability to unravel the mysteries that lay ahead. With Hercule Poirot by my side, success was surely within reach. But as I teased him about his renowned skills, he simply gazed at me solemnly, sensing something amiss. It seemed as though he saw through my facade, recognizing a sense of foreboding lurking beneath my optimistic demeanor.

"Pagett, my dear," I exclaimed, "why must the unfortunate fellow be shadowed every time he steps on deck? Some individuals even endure the discomfort of sleeping outside. I've always found it rather unpleasant. The crew hoses down the deck, along with anyone on it, at five in the morning." The very thought made me cringe. "In any case," I added, "if you insisted on disturbing some unfortunate soul suffering from insomnia, it's no surprise he lashed out at you." Pagett appeared understanding. "Allow me to explain, Sir Eustace. I was certain the man had been lurking near your cabin, where he had no legitimate reason to be."

She appeared more confused than ever. "Are you suggesting that I stay at Madame Colombier's? And for how long?" "It could be as long as three months," he replied. "Are there any other stipulations?" she inquired. "Absolutely none. You would pose as my ward and must refrain from contacting anyone you know. I must insist on complete secrecy for the time being. By the way, you're English, correct?" "Yes," she confirmed. "But there's a hint of an American accent," he pointed out. "I spent a lot of time with an American girl in the hospital. I must have picked it up from her. But I can easily shed it," she explained. "Actually, it might be easier for you to pass as an American," he suggested.

“Sorry old pal, I held back on purpose. What a shame. Money down the drain.” He let out a sigh. “But oh well. The ad’s out, only two responses!”  “Tommy, you sly dog!” Tuppence nearly yelled. “Hand them over. That was low!”  “Watch it, Tuppence. They’re strict at the National Gallery. Government gig. And don’t forget, like I’ve said, as a clergyman’s daughter...”  “I should be an actress!” Tuppence cut in abruptly.

"Good day, gentlemen. Yesterday, you questioned me regarding the vanishing of Mr. Halliday. I have since discovered that you revisited the residence for a second time, inquiring about my assistant, Inez Veroneau. She accompanied you from the premises and has not been seen since." "Is that all, madam?" "No, sir, it is not. Last evening, the laboratory was burglarized, and numerous valuable documents were pilfered. The intruders attempted to access something even more precious, but fortunately, they were unable to crack the large safe." "Madam, these are the details of the situation. Your former assistant, Madame Veroneau, was in reality the Countess Rossakoff, a skilled thief, and it was she who orchestrated Mr. Halliday's disappearance."

I climbed the stairs, determined to locate the room where the tragedy had unfolded. The rain from the day the body was found had left muddy footprints all over the uncarpeted floor. I doubted the police would have found any clues the day after, given the fine weather. The room itself was unremarkable, with white walls and a bare floor. Despite my thorough search, I found nothing of interest, until my pencil rolled under a window seat. Opening the cupboard underneath, I discovered a roll of Kodak films that piqued my interest. The films smelled strongly of mothballs, leading me to believe they belonged to the man killed in the Tube. This discovery gave me a new lead to pursue in the case.

“Rome.” “Ah!” exclaimed Tuppence reflectively. Silently she mused: “I can't imagine my father being happy about this. Mr. Smith doesn't strike me as the type to deceive.” “Absolutely,” Smith added. “Isn't it just perfect? Going back in time, just a little bit, to revisit one of those lovely boarding schools for girls that Paris is known for.” Tuppence interjected. “A boarding school?” “Precisely. Madame Dubois' on Rue de la Paix.” Tuppence was familiar with the establishment. It was renowned for its exclusivity. She had a few American acquaintances who attended there.

I wonder what motivated him to act in such a way. Was it for the sake of those small jade figures? Or could he possibly be working for the notorious Big Four? Personally, I am inclined to believe the latter. No matter how precious the jade may be, it is unlikely that a man of his social standing would fully comprehend its value, let alone resort to murder for it. (One would think that this would have been obvious to the Inspector.) He easily could have taken the jade and fled with it instead of carrying out such a savage and senseless killing. It appears that our acquaintance from Devonshire may not have engaged his little gray cells in this matter.

"The depth of his intellect is well hidden, but undeniable," I remarked. Harvey nodded in agreement, his expression turning somber. "The pieces are falling into place," Poirot declared, his tone grave. "Are all the necessary preparations in place?" "Your instructions have been followed to the letter. The support of Italy, France, and England has been secured," I assured him. "It appears we have forged a new alliance," Poirot mused dryly. "Desjardeaux has finally come around. Well then, it is time to begin, or rather, for me to begin."

"As the Prime Minister and his secretary, Captain Daniels, traveled back to town after an Audience in Windsor, the car deviated from the main road and was ambushed by masked men. Shots were fired, narrowly missing the Prime Minister, who downplayed the incident as a scratch. The car was later found abandoned outside a suspicious restaurant in Soho, with the chauffeur, O'Murphy, missing. Poirot, asked to investigate, is granted carte blanche to do so with the assistance of a Military officer and a C.I.D. man. The urgency of the situation is evident as uncertainties arise about the loyalty of those involved."

"He's an invalid." "I'm sorry to hear that, but can you assist me instead? You're Mademoiselle Daviloff, correct?" "Yes, I'm Sonia Daviloff. What do you need?" "I'm investigating the incident from two nights ago - the death of M. Gilmour Wilson. What do you know about it?" The girl's eyes widened. "He passed away while playing chess due to heart failure." "The authorities suspect it may not have been a heart failure, mademoiselle." The girl's expression turned fearful. "So it's true," she exclaimed. "Ivan was right."

He was aware of it. He's a man with a sensitive side, he wouldn't push himself on her if she wasn't interested. And when he backed off, her feelings for him grew. But they both have a strong sense of pride, keeping them apart. He got involved with Mrs. Raikes, while she pursued a friendship with Dr. Bauerstein. Do you recall the day John Cavendish was arrested, when I was contemplating a major decision?" "Yes, I understood your dilemma." "Forgive me, my friend, but you didn't understand it at all.

Blair was obsessed with capturing unique photographs as we journeyed higher and higher up the mountain. She insisted on snapping shots of the train's front from the back, claiming it would look dangerously thrilling against the mountain backdrop. Anne Beddingfeld expressed relief at traveling during daylight, marveling at the magnificent scenery. Colonel Race informed her that they only had three trains a week to Rhodesia, leading to a discussion about their plans at the Falls and Johannesburg. Race's assurance about the safety of Jo'burg prompted a skeptical response from Sir Eustace, who suspected Race had ulterior motives involving Anne. The dynamic between the characters hinted at underlying tensions and unspoken desires.

As I pondered my grim situation, a sudden strategy formed in my mind. The concept of memory loss was a fascination of mine, a topic I had extensively researched. With determination, I decided to put my knowledge to the test. Taking a deep breath, I feigned confidence and began speaking rapidly in French. The effect was immediate - Mrs. Vandemeyer emerged from behind the screen, intrigued by my unexpected linguistic display.

“Do you have another plan up your sleeve? Let me take a wild guess. Are you planning to sell the Star of the East?” Lord Yardly nodded. “That’s correct. It’s been passed down through the family for generations, but it’s not tied to any inheritance. However, finding a buyer isn’t as simple as it seems. Hoffberg, the Hatton Garden dealer, is in search of a potential customer, but time is running out.” Lady Yardly interjected with one more question, “Which plan does she agree with?” “She strongly objects to selling the jewel,” Lord Yardly replied.

"Rage coursed through me at the sight of the lifeless woman. I felt the urge to end her existence right then and there. But how could he have ever loved her to feel such intense emotions? I composed myself and calmly spoke, 'It seems we have nothing left to discuss. Good night.' 'Good night and farewell, Miss Beddingfeld.' 'Until we meet again, Mr. Lucas.' The mention of his name caused him to recoil. He approached me. 'Why do you say we will meet again?' 'Because I have a feeling our paths will cross once more.' 'Not if I have a say in it!' His words were forceful, but I remained unfazed."

She made it clear to me that Sir Eustace lived his life with a strong focus on feeling secure and at ease. His self-preservation instinct was sharp. The death of Nadina removed some of his inhibitions. His actions were driven by his intense fears for his own safety, rather than his feelings towards me. I believe Suzanne is correct. As for Nadina, she was the type of woman who brought death upon herself. While men may resort to questionable means to become wealthy, women should not feign love for hidden agendas. I can pardon Sir Eustace quite easily, but I will never be able to forgive Nadina.

John was once a barrister, but eventually embraced the quieter life of a country squire after marrying two years ago. He brought his wife to live at Styles, although it was clear he would have preferred his mother to increase his allowance so he could have his own home. Mrs. Cavendish, however, preferred to make her own plans and expected others to comply, holding the purse strings firmly in her grasp. John couldn't help but notice my astonishment at the news of his mother's remarriage and simply smiled in response.

"Shall we go down together, Hastings, and lend an ear to our guest's particular issue? Please extend my apologies." Roger Havering, a man in his forties, stood tall with a sharp appearance, yet his face betrayed signs of distress. "Captain Hastings? You are Monsieur Poirot’s associate, correct? It is absolutely crucial that he accompany me to Derbyshire today." "I'm sorry, but that's not feasible," I responded. "Poirot is bedridden with the flu." Havering's expression darkened. "Oh dear, that is a significant setback for me."

After my friend was cruelly killed, I couldn't simply return to South America without seeking justice for his death. I expressed my determination to Ridgeway, who listened intently. "Despite that," he responded after hearing me out, "I still believe Poirot himself would advise your return. For his sake, I implore you, Hastings, let go of these reckless notions and head back to your ranch." There was only one response I could give, and with a solemn shake of his head, Ridgeway fell silent. It took a month for me to recover fully from my injuries.

The threat we face is clear and direct. The Revolutionaries claim to possess it and plan to reveal it soon. However, they are mistaken about certain details. The Government dismisses it as a bluff, but there are signs suggesting otherwise. Hints and allusions point to the legitimacy of the danger at hand.

There it would be impracticable and impossible so the Prime Minister vanishes. The police of this country rush across the Channel, and no one bothers to investigate the details of the first attack. "Brown really amuses me!” “The concept wasn't their own,” Mr. Carter added seriously. “It was proposed, and the poison expertly injected, by a seasoned pro in the field. The article in the New York magazine influenced his strategy, allowing him to create a trap that almost led to your demise.” “I never trusted him,” Julius remarked. “I had a hunch from the start that there was something off about him, and I suspected he was the one who silenced Mrs. Vandemeyer so effectively."

"Poirot checked the time on his oversized pocket watch. “It's almost nine o’clock.” “Twenty-four hours,” Mr. Dodge mused. “And a quarter,” Poirot corrected. “Don’t overlook the quarter, sir, it might be important. Upon arrival in Boulogne, he was greeted by a car from General Headquarters and one of the Commander-in-Chief’s A.D.C."

"Then again, he must be a fairly young man, certainly not over thirty-five. You see, we are making progress. A man between thirty and thirty-five, of average height and coloring, skilled in the art of disguise, and with very few or no natural teeth." "What?" "Certainly, Hastings. As the janitor, his teeth were chipped and stained, in London they were straight and pearly white, as the dentist they jutted out slightly, and as Smith they had abnormally long canines. Nothing transforms a face quite like a different set of teeth. Do you see where all of this is taking us?" "Not quite," I replied tentatively.

"Miss Hastings has both intelligence and compassion," Poirot remarked. I remained silent. "Instinct is a remarkable thing," he continued. "It defies explanation and cannot be disregarded." "You and Miss Howard appear to be well-informed," I remarked icily. "Perhaps you are unaware that I am still clueless." Poirot scrutinized me before firmly shaking his head. "No, my dear friend." "Why not enlighten me?" I pressed. "Two people are sufficient to keep a secret," Poirot replied. "It is unfair to withhold information from me," I protested.

“Good Lord! You have a heart that is easily swayed!” “Hastings,” I said, “do you recall the aftermath of the Styles Case when ” “When you were entangled with feelings for two delightful women simultaneously, yet neither reciprocated? Yes, I recall.” “You comforted me by suggesting that one day we would collaborate on a case once more, and that then ” “And then?” “Here we are, collaborating again, and ” I hesitated, chuckling somewhat awkwardly. To my astonishment, Poirot vehemently shook his head. “Ah, my friend, do not become attached to Marthe Daubreuil.

Tommy stood across the street, watching as Tuppence entered the building. He took a leisurely stroll to the end of the street and back, finally reaching the building just as Tuppence emerged. "Tommy!" she called out. "Yes, what's wrong?" Tommy inquired. "The place is closed. I couldn't get anyone's attention," Tuppence explained. "Strange. Let's go up together and try again," Tommy suggested, following her lead. On the third floor landing, a young clerk stepped out of an office. After a moment of hesitation, he approached Tuppence. "Are you looking for the Esthonia Glassware?" he asked. "Yes, please," Tuppence confirmed.

We shared a passion for South Africa and a mutual interest in exploring remote corners of the globe. Following his departure from Cambridge, Eardsley had a falling out with his father over financial matters. Sir Laurence, having already bailed out his son twice before, refused to do so again, leading to a heated confrontation. Determined to make it on his own, Eardsley and his companion embarked on a diamond prospecting venture in South America. The details of their expedition are not relevant at the moment, but our time in that exotic land was truly unforgettable.

“Let’s discuss salary, how about three hundred a year? And the same for Mr. Beresford, naturally.” Tuppence smiled. “That sounds wonderful. You're so kind. Money truly is my love! I'll meticulously track all our expenses, ensuring the debits and credits are in balance, with a red line separating them and matching totals at the bottom. I'm quite skilled at it when I put my mind to it.” “I have no doubt. Farewell, and best of luck to you both.” He shook their hands, and within moments they were walking down the steps of 27 Carshalton Terrace feeling dizzy. “Tommy! Quickly, who is ‘Mr.

I observed Detective Inspector James Japp of Scotland Yard, known as Jimmy Japp, alongside another man from the same institution. The pace of events was rapid, my friend." I scrutinized the two individuals closely. There was nothing typical about them that would suggest they were law enforcement. The pronouncement of "Wilful Murder against some person or persons unknown" caught my attention, pulling me out of my thoughts. Exiting the Stylites Arms, Poirot subtly guided me away, clearly waiting for the Scotland Yard officers.

Poirot instructed the boy to ask at the cloak-room about the valise left by two foreigners on the night of the murder. The boy agreed to do so, and Poirot advised him to go straight to the station without returning to the Villa. Poirot then questioned Jack Renauld about his whereabouts on the night of the crime, pointing out inconsistencies in his story. Renauld hesitated before admitting he was in Merlinville. Poirot followed Renauld discreetly, realizing that Renauld fell for his trick about the mythical valise.

"But M. Giraud could not be deceived," whispered Poirot. "You may try to deceive me, but I have one final undeniable piece of evidence. Madame Renauld's entire story was a lie, crafted from the very beginning. Despite her supposed love for her husband, she lied to protect his killer. A woman will lie for herself, for the man she loves, or for her children. This is the undeniable truth. You cannot deny it." Giraud stopped, looking pleased with himself. Poirot met his gaze calmly. "That is your argument," Giraud stated. "What do you have to say in response?" "Only that there is one crucial detail you have overlooked.

"I recalled the 'dressing-up box' that John and Lawrence, still known as the 'young gentlemen' to Dorcas, mentioned. It is located in the front attic, sir, a large chest filled with old clothes, fancy dresses, and more. Suddenly, I thought there might be a green dress in there. Please inform the Belgian gentleman." "Of course, Dorcas," I assured her. "He is a very pleasant gentleman, quite distinct from those two London detectives who snoop around asking questions."

“Of course,” Dr. Bauerstein replied. “What do you mean by that?” “That neither Dr. Wilkins nor I could issue a death certificate given the circumstances,” John nodded in understanding. “In that case, I see no other choice but to comply,” he conceded. “Thank you,” Dr. Wilkins interjected crisply. “We suggest that it should occur tomorrow night, or rather tonight,” he added, glancing at the fading daylight. “Unfortunately, an inquest seems inevitable under these circumstances. These formalities are necessary, but please try not to be too distressed,” he reassured them. After a brief silence, Dr. Bauerstein produced two keys from his pocket and handed them to John. “These are for the two rooms.”

I met Japp at the Matlock Arms and he led me straight to the body of Harrington Pace. Pace, an American, had been shot in the head at close range. Japp suspected Mrs. Havering's husband, but his alibi checked out. The murder weapon was found, but the killer remained at large. I sent a detailed report to Poirot, including a new clue - a revolver found near the crime scene. A wire from Poirot arrived the next morning, revealing that the black-bearded man was not Mr. Havering. More investigation was needed to crack the case.

"Seems like she received a sudden warning from someone." "Mr. Brown, I assume," Julius said mockingly. The attorney stared at him intently for a moment or two. "Why not?" he replied. "Don't forget, you were once defeated by him." Julius blushed with irritation. "I get so angry when I remember how I handed Jane's photo to him without a second thought. If I ever get my hands on it again, I won't let go of it for anything." "That scenario is unlikely," the lawyer remarked dryly. "I suppose you're right," Julius admitted. "Either way, it's the original I'm determined to retrieve."

I informed him that my expert opinion would be available once the facts were presented to me, however, he claimed he was unable to do so. The details were to be revealed upon my arrival at the location. Typically, this would have been the end of the discussion. Attempting to give Hercule Poirot instructions is simply impertinent. However, the amount of money offered was so substantial that, for the first time, I found myself enticed by the sheer monetary value. It was not just a sum, but a significant fortune! Additionally, there was another aspect that caught my attention - you, my dear friend. As of late, I have been a solitary individual, yearning for companionship.

"You're not thinking of turning Madame Olivier in to the authorities?"  "I doubt they would believe me. She's practically a national treasure. And we have no evidence. We'll be lucky if she doesn't report us."  "What do you mean?"  "Consider this. We're caught on her property at night with keys she'll deny giving us. She catches us at the safe, we restrain her, and then flee. Don't be naive, Hastings. The tables are turned, isn't that how you put it?"  Following our ordeal at the villa in Passy, we hurried back to London. Poirot had a stack of letters waiting for him. A sly grin crossed his face as he read one, then passed it to me.

"But, considering it's all in the past and the conflict has ended, why does it still hold importance?" "History has a way of coming full circle, Jane. There was an uproar about those documents, then it faded away, and now the whole situation has resurfaced for entirely different reasons. Can you deliver them to us immediately?" "I'm afraid I can't." "What do you mean?" "I don't have them." Julius emphasized each word with brief pauses. "I don't have them?" "No, I concealed them." "You hid them?" "Yes. I became anxious. It felt like someone was monitoring me. It frightened me deeply." She reached for her head.

"He never wavered, always steady. It was like watching a master magician at work. “Your hand is remarkably steady,” I noted. “I can only recall one instance of it shaking.” “Undoubtedly in a fit of anger,” Poirot calmly remarked. “Yes, indeed! You were furious. Remember? When you found the despatch-case in Mrs. Inglethorp’s room had been tampered with. You stood by the mantel, fidgeting with the items on it as usual, hand trembling uncontrollably! I must admit ” But I abruptly cut myself off."

"Listen, my friend, I understand your feelings on this dreadful matter. I have not handled it well! If you were in my position, you might have handled it better! Fine! Let's move on from it and grab some lunch." By the time we arrived at Poirot's place, it was around four o’clock. A man stood up from a seat near the window. It was Lord Yardly. He appeared worn out and troubled. "I received your message and hurried here. I went to Hoffberg, but they deny any knowledge of their employee from last night or the telegram. Could it be that" Poirot interrupted him. "I apologize! I sent that telegram and recruited the man in question."

Hunter’s Lodge is managed by a housekeeper who efficiently handles all our needs during our occasional weekend visits. When the shooting season arrives, we bring along some of our own servants from Newmarket. My uncle, Mr. Harrington Pace (my mother was a Miss Pace of New York), has been living with us for the past three years. He never had a good relationship with my father or my elder brother, but I suspect that my somewhat rebellious nature only strengthened his fondness for me.

As we were leaving the room, I leaned in towards Poirot and asked quietly, "Will there be an inquest?" Poirot, lost in thought, absentmindedly nodded in response. His preoccupation piqued my curiosity, prompting me to press further. "What troubles you? You seem distracted." "It is true, my friend. I am greatly concerned." "And why is that?" "Mademoiselle Cynthia does not take sugar in her coffee." "What? Are you serious?" "Quite serious. There is a mystery here that eludes me. My initial hunch was correct." "What hunch?" "The one that led me to inspect those coffee cups."

I gasped in horror at the sight of the airplane dagger. Maître Grosíer immediately interjected, insisting on speaking to his client before any questions were answered. Jack Renauld, however, disregarded Grosíer's pleas and calmly confirmed, "Yes, I recognize it. It was a gift from me to my mother, a reminder of the War." When asked about the possibility of a duplicate dagger, Jack confidently stated, "To my knowledge, there is none. The design was unique to me." The magistrate was taken aback by the audacity of Jack's response.

"Maybe," she replied before swiftly exiting the small clearing, leaving John frozen in place. I casually approached, crunching dead branches beneath my feet. John spun around, assuming I had just arrived on the scene.   "Hello, Hastings. Did you make sure the little guy got back to his cottage safely? Quite an interesting fellow! But is he truly any good?"   "He was renowned as one of the top detectives of his time."   "Well, I guess there must be some truth to it then. But what a miserable world we live in!"   "Do you really think so?" I inquired.

We must act quickly if we hope to catch the culprit," the manager declared, swiftly producing the key. Without hesitation, we made our way into the apartment. Our first stop was a compact square lounge. A partially open door on the right caught the manager's attention. "The dining area," he muttered, gesturing towards it. Dr. Hawker took the lead, with us close behind. Stepping into the room, I couldn't help but gasp. The table at the center still held the remnants of a meal, while three chairs were pushed away, as if their occupants had only just departed.

"I've always heard that he acquired his wealth in a secretive manner," mused Suzanne. "But that doesn't necessarily imply criminal activity. It could be something as mundane as selling office supplies or beauty products!" I responded with a hint of regret. "Perhaps," Suzanne hesitated, "we're on the wrong track? What if we're being misled by suspecting Pagett's involvement? What if he's truly an upright citizen?" I pondered this briefly before shaking my head. "I find that hard to believe." "He does have an explanation for everything." "True, but they lack credibility."

"I was preparing for a lengthy journey, unsure when I would return. It was important for me to see her one last time, to make sure she knew my feelings were unwavering." Poirot maintained unbreakable eye contact as he questioned Renauld's actions. After a significant pause, Renauld finally responded, confirming that he did see her. "What happened next?" Poirot pressed. "I missed the final train, so I trekked to St. Beauvais and managed to secure a car from a nearby garage to transport me back to Cherbourg." "St. Beauvais? That's quite a distance to walk, M. Renauld." "I needed the time to think." Poirot nodded in understanding as Renauld made his exit, grabbing his hat and cane before disappearing into the night.

In late April, I managed to secure a meeting with the Home Secretary. Mr. Crowther's demeanor echoed that of Dr. Ridgeway. It exuded calmness and reservation. Despite acknowledging my offer to help, he politely refused. The documents mentioned by Poirot were now in his possession, and he assured me that every possible measure was being taken to address the looming threat. With that bleak reassurance, I had no choice but to accept. Mr. Crowther concluded our conversation by advising me to go back to South America. The whole situation left me deeply dissatisfied. I should have probably included Poirot's burial at the appropriate time.

I noticed careful footsteps approaching, causing me to writhe in helplessness. As they neared, Poirot emerged, tilting his head and scanning the darkness. Suddenly, Ryland triumphantly growled as he aimed his gun and demanded, "Hands up." Deaves swiftly seized Poirot from behind. The trap was set. "Nice to see you, Mr. Hercule Poirot," the American said sternly. Poirot remained unfazed, maintaining his composure without hesitation.

"Looking down at the body, he furrowed his brow. "Would you classify this individual as Spanish?" he inquired abruptly. Studying the features intently, I finally replied, "No, without a doubt I would identify him as French." Giraud expressed his dissatisfaction with a grunt. "I concur." After a brief pause, he motioned for me to step aside with authority and resumed his meticulous search of the shed floor on all fours. His attention to detail was exceptional. Methodically, he combed through every inch of the area, scrutinizing pots and inspecting old sacks."

And the woman disappeared into thin air. Her box was left behind, containing only ordinary apparel. Mrs. Havering hired her through Mrs. Selbourne’s Agency with impeccable references. Mrs. Middleton's sudden disappearance raised suspicions, leading to an investigation. It was discovered that no woman named "Mrs. Middleton" had ever been registered with the Agency. Poirot deduced that Zoe Havering, a former actress, had orchestrated the whole scheme. She had disguised herself as the housekeeper to provide an alibi for her mistress. The clever and daring Zoe had fooled everyone with her quick changes and deception.

"It shatters my hypothesis; it devastates everything... no!" He suddenly halted, hitting his chest. "It's inconceivable. I can't be mistaken! I must be correct, therefore this recent homicide is implausible unless unless oh, hold on, I beg of you. Don't say a word." After a brief pause, he returned to his usual demeanor, speaking calmly and confidently: "The deceased is a middle-aged man."

She placed her small hand gently in mine. "Please, be a dear," she whispered. Reluctantly, I agreed. Deep down, I knew that I might actually enjoy playing the role of a showman. The girl's moral stance was not my concern. Despite some nerves about the examining magistrate's reaction, I consoled myself with the thought that no real harm could come of this. Our first stop was the location where the body was found. A guard stood watch, offering a respectful salute upon seeing me, without questioning my companion. Evidently, he assumed she was under my protection.

"In that instant of frigid rationality, I berated myself for being overly theatrical, longing for the quiet monotony of Smallington. These thoughts raced through my mind in a mere moment. Instinctively, I inched backwards, searching for the door handle. The man holding me captive smirked. "You're here now, and here you will remain," he said jokingly. Trying to appear brave, I stated, "I was brought here by the curator of the Cape Town Museum."

"The situation was undeniably perplexing. Although it was evident that the woman herself was not the perpetrator of the crime, as Mrs. Havering was with her in the hall when the gunshot rang out, there was undoubtedly a connection to the murder, given her sudden decision to flee. I immediately sent a message to Poirot and proposed heading back to London to investigate at Selbourne’s Agency. Poirot’s response came swiftly: “No point in checking at the agency, they won’t have any information on her. Discover which vehicle transported her to hunters lodge upon her initial arrival.”"

"We won't be needing it at the moment." "But what if he tries to run away?" Poirot chuckled. "He won't." I quickly fetched the taxi that was waiting. The stranger's scarf was removed from his face, and I was taken aback. "He's not Japanese," I whispered to Poirot. "You always had a keen eye for observation, Hastings! You don't miss a thing. No, he's not Japanese. He's Italian." We entered the taxi, and Poirot instructed the driver to go to an address in St. John's Wood. I was now thoroughly puzzled.

His situation was dire. When he heard the key turn at eight o’clock, he immediately leaped up. The girl stood before him. "Close the door," he ordered. "I need to talk to you." She complied. "Listen, Annette, I need your assistance to escape this predicament." She shook her head. "It's impossible. There are three individuals on the level below." "Ah!" Tommy was inwardly thankful for the insight. "But you would aid me if you could?" "No, sir." "And why is that?" The girl paused. "I believe they are my associates. You've been spying on them. It's only right for them to detain you."

"I stood outside waiting, but they never emerged. Eventually, I ventured inside. Sir Eustace, the shop was deserted! There must be an alternate exit," I informed him. "Upon my return to the hotel, I inquired about Miss Pettigrew." Pagett leaned in, his voice hushed and breath heavy with the weight of confidentiality. "Sir Eustace, a witness saw a man exiting her room last night." Arching my eyebrows, I commented, "And I had always believed her to be a woman of impeccable reputation." Ignoring my remark, Pagett continued, "I proceeded directly to her room and conducted a thorough search."

"A man facing his fate often seeks solace in a final smoke," I remarked, reaching for my cigarette case. "May I?" I inquired, glancing at my restraints. "Ah, I see!" she chuckled. "You wish for your hands to be free, don't you? You are quite astute, M. Hercule Poirot, I must admit. I won't release your hands, but I can offer you a cigarette." As she knelt beside me, she retrieved a cigarette from my case and placed it delicately between my lips. "Now, a match," she stated as she stood up. "It's not needed, madame." There was a certain edge in my tone that caught her off guard. "Please remain still, madame. I implore you. You will not like the consequences if you don't."

"Well, I'm shocked! If that's the case," Julius quickly interjected. "Hold on now, let's not rush. I don't mean what you think. I believe Americans value morality even more than you do. What I meant was that the French approach marriage in a methodical manner, finding compatible partners, managing finances, and handling the entire situation practically, with a business mindset." "In my opinion," Tommy remarked, "we're far too focused on business these days. Everything is about profit. The men are problematic enough, and the women are even worse!" "Calm down, my boy. Don't get so agitated.

Colonel Race stood up. “Good morning Lucas,” he greeted. Harry suddenly blushed deeply. “Yes, I suppose it’s time to use your true name,” I joked. But Harry's attention remained fixed on Colonel Race. “You recognize me, sir,” he finally admitted. “I have a good memory for faces. I remember seeing you when I was a child.” Confused, I interjected, trying to understand the tension between them. Colonel Race prevailed. Harry shifted his gaze. “I guess you’re right, sir. Go ahead and tell her my real name.” “Anne, this man is not Harry Lucas. Harry Lucas died during the War.”

"Now, my dear Suzanne, we must act quickly and decisively. Pagett will remain here, which means you have the perfect opportunity to join us in Rhodesia," I said, gripping Suzanne's hand tightly. "If you were there when he arrived, everything would fall into place naturally. And let's not forget about Colonel Race and Sir Eustace entirely." Suzanne dimpled and replied, "Surely you can't suspect them?" "I suspect everyone," I said mysteriously. "In detective stories, the most unlikely person is often the culprit. Cheerful fat men like Sir Eustace have been known to be criminals." Suzanne agreed to keep an eye on Sir Eustace and promised to send a telegram if he showed any suspicious changes.

"Unbelievable! I can't wrap my head around it! Kids playing, picnics, crowds of people everywhere! No way it's there! The odds are a million to one against it! It defies all logic!" The sheer impossibility of it all weighed heavily on him, especially considering the failures of so many before him. It seemed too simple, too easy to be true. The hole had to be empty. Julius grinned at him, amusement dancing in his eyes. "Looks like you're feeling the pressure now," he said, drawing out the words. "Well, let's find out!" With a confident motion, he reached into the crevice, a faint grimace crossing his face.

He entered through the same entrance, murdered the elderly gentleman, then returned to the kitchen. You can clearly see the traces of blood he left behind. Or was there some incriminating evidence he had overlooked? "Maybe he committed the murder during his second visit," I proposed. "No, you're not paying attention.

As the time approached for my departure, a sense of melancholy overcame me. Would he release me without a word or gesture? His brooding silences and sudden outbursts of restlessness kept me on edge. The breaking point arrived one evening as we sat outside the hut, the setting sun casting long shadows. My hair, lacking the confinement of hairpins, cascaded down my back in a dark, straight curtain. Lost in my thoughts, I pondered my next move.

"I never trusted you," she said sharply. "It's not that simple," he replied. "I had grown cynical and suspicious, always searching for hidden agendas. And then she realized, when he said "my friend," he wasn't referring to Eardsley, but to Lucas. It was Lucas, the unassuming one, who had been in love with Nadina all along.

I had been learning Spanish, and my professor mentioned a need for assistance in a clinic in Madrid. I reached out and my offer was promptly accepted. With no immediate family to consider, making arrangements was a simple task.   Following the sinking of the Titanic, a stranger approached me. His apprehensive demeanor had caught my attention earlier, leading me to believe he was running from someone or something. In a hushed tone, he inquired about my patriotism to America and revealed he was in possession of crucial documents for the Allies. He implored me to safeguard them until a specific signal was given. Should the signal fail to materialize, I was to deliver the documents to the U.S. Embassy.

"That's the alternative and you won't like it, I can tell you! I can be very rough if I choose. So drink this down like a good girl, and you'll be none the worse for it." In her heart of hearts Tuppence believed her. The arguments she had adduced rang true. It was a simple and effective method of getting her out of the way for the time being. Nevertheless, the girl did not take kindly to the idea of being tamely put to sleep without as much as one bid for freedom. She felt that once Mrs. Vandemeyer gave them the slip, the last hope of finding Tommy would be gone. Tuppence was quick in her mental processes.

I couldn't believe my luck when I saw my target casually sipping beef tea by the rail. I approached him with a friendly smile, hoping to smooth things over after the cabin mix-up. Mr. Chichester, however, was not so forgiving. As we exchanged words, I couldn't help but notice that his skin was surprisingly fair for someone who claimed to have spent two years in the depths of Africa. His reaction to a dropped paper only deepened my suspicions. It was clear that Mr. Chichester was not to be trusted. Later, during a conversation about Italy, the strange behavior of Mr. Pagett only added to my growing list of suspects. The more I observed, the more I realized that any one of them could be hiding something sinister.

"I doubt anyone has come through here. Just look at the dust. Thick. No footprints anywhere," Julius remarked as they explored the abandoned building. Dust coated every surface, undisturbed. Julius expressed his disbelief that Tuppence had ever set foot in the house. Tommy suggested they revisit the next day in daylight for a closer look. The following day, they resumed their search and reluctantly agreed that the house had been untouched for quite a while. Just as they considered leaving the village, Tommy made a fortunate discovery that changed their course.

Upon investigating, we notice three instances where M. Renauld's behavior shifts dramatically, indicating three crucial psychological turning points. The first occurs upon his arrival in Merlinville, the second following a heated argument with his son, and the third on the morning of June 7th. The reasons behind these changes are as follows: the influence of Madame Daubreuil is to blame for the first, the impending marriage between Renauld's son and Daubreuil's daughter for the second, but the root cause of the third remains elusive, requiring deduction on our part.

"It's a tight squeeze. Jane's hand must be a few sizes smaller than mine. I don't feel anything, no sir, what's this? Oh my goodness!" And with a dramatic gesture he held up a small discoloured packet. "It's the real deal. Wrapped in oilskin. Hold onto it while I grab my pocket knife." The impossible had occurred. Tommy cradled the precious packet delicately in his hands. They had prevailed! "It's odd," he muttered absentmindedly, "you'd think the seams would have decayed. They look brand new." They sliced them meticulously and peeled off the oilskin. Enclosed was a tiny folded piece of paper.

“Mr. Hersheimmer,” he said at last, “that is a very large sum.” “I guess it’ll have to be. Maybe you think I’m talking through my hat, but I can deliver the goods all right, with enough over to spare for your fee.” Sir James flushed slightly. “There is no question of a fee, Mr. Hersheimmer. I am not a private detective.” “Sorry. I guess I was just a mite hasty, but I’ve been feeling bad about this money question.

"I was quite fond of the young woman, she possessed an air of genuineness and simplicity that I found refreshing. It was clear that she had something weighing on her mind, and eventually she revealed it to me. "Major Neville," she began, "I have been contemplating resigning from my position here." I was taken aback by this revelation, and she continued with urgency. "You see, as grateful as I am for this opportunity, I simply cannot tolerate being verbally abused. It is utterly intolerable to me. No true gentleman would behave in such a manner." "Has Ryland been the one to mistreat you?" She silently confirmed this with a nod."

Poirot listened intently as Marthe revealed a shocking revelation. She described a confrontation between M. Renauld and a tramp in the garden, hinting that they might be the same person. Poirot pondered over the implications of her story, considering the possibility that Jack Renauld might have murdered his own father for money. As they made their way back to the Villa, Poirot's mind raced with new suspicions and clues. Suddenly, a car pulled up outside with Giraud, Jack Renauld, and two gendarmes. Poirot hastily searched through Jack Renauld's belongings, finding a crucial piece of evidence hidden among ties and handkerchiefs. With a triumphant cry, he pocketed the item and hurriedly left the room before Giraud could interfere.

Mr. Lowen expressed his apologies and bid farewell. "Everyone is aware that Mr. Davenheim never came back. The police were notified early Sunday morning, but were baffled by the situation. Mr. Davenheim appeared to have disappeared without a trace. He had not visited the post office, nor had he been spotted in the village. Authorities confirmed he had not left by train. His personal vehicle remained in the garage. If he had arranged for a car to meet him in a remote location, it is likely that the driver would have come forward by now, given the substantial reward for any information."

As Mrs. Vandemeyer's eyes scanned the room, she reclined in her seat. "Bah!" she exclaimed. "You're missing something." Tuppence conceded, "Yes, I may be, but I know someone who isn't." "Who might that be?" inquired Mrs. Vandemeyer skeptically. "A close associate of mine," replied Tuppence. "He happens to be quite wealthy," Mrs. Vandemeyer remarked doubtfully. "Indeed, he is a millionaire. An American, to be precise. He will provide the payment without hesitation. Trust me, it's a legitimate offer." Mrs. Vandemeyer sat upright once more. "I am inclined to trust you," she said slowly. After a period of silence, Mrs. Vandemeyer lifted her gaze.

"Oh, every detail! The location of the incident, the murder weapon, the victim, any fingerprints or other intriguing evidence. What had society come to, with women finding excitement in such gruesome events? The girl's morbid enthusiasm made me feel sick to my stomach. I had heard of the crowds of women gathering outside courtrooms during capital trials, but I never understood who these women were until now.

As they retraced their path back to the gate, a sudden cry escaped him. Bending down, he retrieved an item from the ground and presented it to Julius. She made it this far, at least. Let’s establish the pub as our base, and turn this area upside down until we locate her. Someone must have spotted her.” And so, the search commenced. Tommy and Julius conducted their investigations individually and together, yet the outcome remained unchanged. No one resembling Tuppence had been sighted in the vicinity. "I am at your disposal,” the woman stated, her gaze filled with suspicion. “I expect your full cooperation.” “I will gladly assist in Alfred's demise,” she growled. “Hanging is too kind a fate. I suggested they may have departed on the midnight train, but he firmly dismissed the notion. He was confident he would have noticed two foreigners among the twenty or so passengers that left. I couldn't pinpoint what triggered my suspicion, perhaps the anxious tone of Marthe Daubreuil. Suddenly, I inquired: "Young M. Renauld, he didn't board that train, did he?" "No, sir. I couldn’t shake the memory of her close proximity on the Lusitania when Mr. Danvers handed me the packet. She had attempted to engage him in conversation more than once. Fear began to creep in, but I was unsure of the best course of action. A fleeting thought of stopping at Holyhead instead of continuing on to London crossed my mind, but I quickly dismissed it as pure folly. The only option was to feign ignorance and remain vigilant. I believed that if I stayed on guard, they wouldn’t be able to catch me. As a precaution, I had already replaced the contents of the oilskin packet with blank paper and resealed it.

Upon entering the room with Gerald Paynter and the compliant Chinaman, they were met with a horrifying scene. With a peaceful night's rest, the boy could be fully recovered by morning, but any excitement might lead to dangerous brain fever. "Now we must find lodgings for the night," Poirot remarked after finishing our café noir.

"But Poirot's skills surpassed mine. In mere moments, he uncovered the entire tale, his eyes gleaming with amusement. “Ah! A story filled with romance. Journeys conclude with lovers’ reunions, is that not the saying?” “Stop being ridiculous, Poirot.” “Yesterday it was Mademoiselle Daubreuil, today it is Mademoiselle Cinderella! Truly, you possess the heart of a Turk, Hastings! You ought to establish a harem!” “It’s easy for you to mock me."

"But now everything is clear to me." "You have all the answers?""I have unraveled what M. Poirot let out his signature sigh of impatience. "You still don't grasp it. A crime can exist without a murderer, but in the case of two crimes, two bodies are indispensable."

"Monitoring Mr. Inglethorp was part of my strategy, waiting for him to reveal the hiding spot. Unfortunately, he outsmarted me at every turn. "I see that clearly now. But what made you start questioning Miss Howard?" "My doubts arose when I caught her in a lie during the inquest regarding the letter from Mrs. Inglethorp."

Again the color drained from the other person's face. "What makes you say that?" "I'm not sure," the girl replied honestly. "But I just know." Mrs. Vandemeyer gazed ahead silently for a while. "Yes," she finally whispered, "I understand. I used to be beautiful, you know, very beautiful." "You still are," Tuppence complimented. Mrs. Vandemeyer shook her head, a peculiar glint in her electric-blue eyes. "Not beautiful enough," she murmured in a soft, menacing tone. "Not beautiful enough! And sometimes, recently, I've been scared. It's risky to be too knowledgeable!" Leaning in closer, she said, "Promise me that my name won't be mentioned, that no one will ever find out." "I promise."

Arriving in one of London's dreary southern suburbs after a series of bus and train rides, Poirot finally decided to shed some light on the mysterious case we were working on together. I had been eager to discuss the details with him, as I believed he was making a mistake by keeping everything to himself. Despite my efforts to engage him in conversation, Poirot remained tight-lipped and enigmatic, true to his nature. His love for secrecy meant that he would only reveal crucial information at the eleventh hour, much to my frustration.

And the inns suggest subtly that once the provisions run out, they will toss you onto the doorstep! Last evening, I encountered Reeves, my comrade from the Kilmorden. His nerves are shot worse than any other man I've come across. Like the rest of them, he delivers fiery speeches of great length, purely for political gain, only to regret it later. He's now running around claiming he never meant it. When I saw him, he was heading to Cape Town, where he plans to deliver a three-day speech in Dutch, defending himself and insisting that his previous statements had a completely different meaning. I am grateful that I'm not a member of the Legislative Assembly of South Africa.

"Both individuals are currently in a state of suspension. I have shed my skirts and my fabric as well.
