There was something about my demeanor that seemed to puzzle him. “You don’t appear to be bothered by what happened,” he dryly remarked. “Would a dramatic reaction from me make any difference to you?” I inquired.

As he dictated to Miss Pettigrew, her voice droned on monotonously. "I therefore suggest that in addressing this issue of colored labor," she repeated. After a pause, he grunted something angrily. I quietly moved forward. Colonel Race's room appeared vacant, and he was nowhere to be seen in the lounge. He was the one I dreaded encountering the most. Nevertheless, I had no time to spare. Hurriedly, I exited the hotel and headed towards the bridge. Crossing it, I positioned myself in the shadows, ready and watchful. If someone followed me, I would spot them as they crossed the bridge.

"I suspected someone was approaching from behind, but I couldn't confirm it. They wouldn't have been as close as I was," I told the investigator. Mr. Flemming, who accompanied me to the inquest, seemed anxious about my well-being, unaware of my composed facade. The victim, identified as L. B. Carton, had only a house-agent's order in his pockets to view a property near Marlow on the river. The document bore the name L. B. Carton, Russell Hotel.

As she entered the room, Tuppence was struck by the grandeur of the collection of books on crime and criminology that lined one wall. The butler gestured for her to take a seat in one of the deep-padded leather arm-chairs by the old-fashioned open hearth. "Sir James will see you now," he announced, before disappearing from the room. Tuppence couldn't help but feel a sense of anticipation as she waited for the man who held the key to her important message.

As I made my way back down the hall a few minutes later, the item had vanished." Whether or not this assertion was accurate, it didn't appear to bode well for Inglethorp in my opinion. Regardless, he had plenty of opportunity to administer the poison. Just then, Poirot subtly gestured towards two individuals seated by the door. One was a small, sharp, dark man with a ferret-like face, while the other was tall and blonde. Without speaking, I inquired of Poirot. He leaned in and whispered in my ear, "Do you recognize that little man?" I shook my head in response.

Poirot chuckled softly beside me when the doctor mentioned the absence of strychnine. Curious, I asked him how he knew. Poirot simply replied, "Listen." The doctor explained that strychnine's bitter taste could be detected even in a solution of one in seventy thousand, and that it could only be disguised by a strongly flavored substance. Cocoa, he said, would be ineffective at masking it. When asked about coffee, the doctor clarified that its own bitterness would likely cover up the taste of strychnine.

"Upon reaching Paris, we made our way to Gare de l'Est, where Poirot finally revealed our next destination. Our journey was set for Bolzano and Italian Tyrol. While Harvey was away from our compartment, I seized the chance to inquire Poirot about why he credited me with discovering the rendezvous.  "Because it was indeed your doing, my dear friend. I am unsure of how Ingles obtained the information, but he somehow did and had his servant deliver it to us. Our path leads us, mon ami, to Karersee, now known as Lago di Carezza."

"And what about Carton?""Never mind him. He caught us with Nadina in Kimberley that one evening, but he couldn't tell us apart. I convinced him I was Lucas, and Nadina fell for it too. She never feared Lucas, he was too quiet and reserved. But I, I had a fiery temper. If she knew I was back, she would've been terrified.""Harry, if Colonel Race hadn't intervened, what was your plan?""To stay silent. Keep up the charade as Lucas.""And the inheritance from your father?""Let Race have it. He would put it to better use than I ever could."

“Would you mind sharing any information you have regarding Jane Finn?” “Jane Finn? Oh!” Mr. Carter paused, pondering. “The real question is, what information do you possess about her?” Tuppence straightened up. “I fail to see the relevance of that.” “Don’t you? But it's crucial, really.” He flashed a tired smile and contemplated further. “So, let’s get back to the point. What can you tell me about Jane Finn?” “Tell me,” he pressed on, sensing Tuppence's silence. “You must have some knowledge to have placed such an advertisement?” Leaning in slightly, his voice tinged with weariness, he added persuasively.

"Known simply as 'Mr. Brown,' he is widely regarded as the preeminent criminal of our time, commanding a vast and intricate network. Much of the wartime Peace movement was secretly orchestrated and funded by him. His influence is pervasive." Tommy inquired, "Is he a German citizen?" "No," replied the source, "There is strong evidence suggesting he is actually English. His allegiance lies with power, though his ultimate goal remains elusive. His true identity remains a mystery, even to those closest to him."

"I never would have questioned his authenticity for a second. Our time on Dartmoor seemed futile, with no progress made. I expressed my frustrations to Poirot, but he insisted that we were moving forward. 'We are learning more about his mind and tactics with each interaction,' Poirot explained. 'He remains unaware of us and our strategies.' I argued that we were at a standstill, waiting for the culprit to make a move. Poirot simply smiled and remarked, 'You never change, Hastings. Always eager for action.'"

Poirot and Giraud were in deep conversation, surrounded by a crowd of curious onlookers. Suddenly, Giraud produced a surprising piece of evidence - a woman's hair coiled around the handle of the dagger. Poirot's interest was piqued as he pondered over the mysterious discovery. "A woman's hair? Whose could it be?" he mused. As they left the shed, Giraud's suave voice echoed in Poirot's mind. "What game is he playing?" wondered Poirot, intrigued by the unexpected turn of events. Later, over a hearty lunch, Poirot remained lost in thought, his mind clearly preoccupied with unraveling the tangled web of clues before him.

"Was it Sir Eustace who underwent a test, or was the tale crafted for my benefit? I recalled feeling like I was being interrogated that night. Colonel Race seemed wary for some reason. But what was his involvement? "Who exactly is Colonel Race?" I inquired. "That's a loaded question," Suzanne replied. "He's famous as a big-game hunter and, as you heard him mention earlier, a distant relative of Sir Laurence Eardsley. I only just met him on this journey."

"Trust me, I've examined all the details. M. Jack Renauld came in on the train. There was an hour gap before he showed up at the house. It's clear that he saw Captain Hastings and his partner exit the shed, snuck in himself, grabbed the dagger, and stabbed his partner in the shed.""But the partner was already dead!" Giraud shrugged. "Maybe he didn't realize that. Perhaps he thought the partner was just asleep. It's likely they had a meeting planned. Either way, he knew that this second murder would make the case much more complicated. And it did."

"As an afterthought," Poirot inquired, "has M. Stonor visited Merlinville today?" Madame Daubreuil calmly responded, "Not to my knowledge." Poirot continued, "Has he met with Mrs. Renauld?" "I cannot say, monsieur," she replied. With a nod, Poirot concluded, "I was simply curious if you had seen him around. Good night, madame." I started to ask, "Why?" Poirot interrupted, "No questions for now, Hastings. There will be opportunity later on."

As Sir Eustace paused mid-sentence, Miss Pettigrew, though efficient in appearance, startled at his sudden halt. “God bless my soul!” he exclaimed. “What of the man in Durban?” “I choose you,” I murmured. “My dear,” Sir Eustace whispered. “You may hold my hand now.” At once, Miss Pettigrew cleared her throat, causing Sir Eustace to retract his hand abruptly. “Ah, yes,” he continued. “Where were we? Ah, yes. Tylman Roos, during his speech...Why are you not jotting this down?” Colonel Race interjected gently, “I believe Miss Pettigrew's pencil has snapped.”

I adored Falls, a place I cherished deeply. After dinner, Sir Eustace secluded himself with Miss Pettigrew. A mysterious note from Harry Rayburn urged me to the palm gully clearing. Hesitating, I set out, wary of being followed. Suddenly, a figure emerged from the shadows and chased me. Panicked, I tripped and fell into darkness. Awakening in a strange room, I found Harry Rayburn sitting beside me. Grateful for his presence, I wept with relief. His comforting words and a cup of milk eased my fears. As I drifted back to sleep, I knew I was safe in his care.

As we made our way back home, we passed through one of the gates and encountered a young woman with a gipsy-like appearance. She greeted us with a bow and a smile. "She's quite lovely," I commented. John's expression turned cold. "That's Mrs. Raikes." "The one that Miss Howard..." "Yes," John interjected sharply. My thoughts drifted to the elderly woman at the grand estate, juxtaposed with the mischievous smile of the young woman. A sense of unease washed over me briefly, but I pushed it aside. "Styles truly is a magnificent old estate," I remarked to John. He simply nodded, his demeanor somber.

I had survived multiple attempts on my life by him, witnessed him murder an innocent woman, and was aware of his involvement in numerous other crimes unbeknownst to me. Despite this knowledge, I couldn't bring myself to fully comprehend the gravity of his actions. He remained in my eyes as a charming and affable companion on our travels. Strangely, I couldn't muster any fear towards him, despite knowing his capacity to order my execution without hesitation. The only comparison I could draw was to Stevenson's infamous character, Long John Silver.

"Tell me, what has caught your interest?" I asked confidently, although half-expecting him to mock my suspicions. To my astonishment, he nodded in agreement. "You are correct, Hastings. I have always had a feeling that she was withholding something. Initially, I had my doubts about her, suspecting her involvement, if not direct, then at least indirect." "You suspected her?" I exclaimed. "Absolutely! She stands to gain significantly from this new will, being the sole beneficiary. Therefore, she was immediately under my scrutiny. You might have noticed that I made a point of inspecting her wrists early on."

"Mademoiselle, it's fascinating hearing your insights on Mr. Darrell. Women truly are remarkable observers, catching the smallest details that men overlook. I recall a woman singling out a man from a group because she noticed his habit of touching his nose when nervous. Such keen perception is rare in men, wouldn't you agree?" "Absolutely!" exclaimed Miss Monro. "We definitely have a knack for picking up on things."

Hastings was adamant that it was Inglethorp who had destroyed the will, a fact that he had tried to emphasize to Poirot. Despite the overwhelming evidence pointing to Inglethorp's guilt, Hastings found himself doubting whether he was truly the culprit. The more he tried to exonerate Inglethorp, the more suspicious his actions became. It was only when Hastings realized that Inglethorp was actually trying to get himself arrested that he changed his mind. The truth was far more sinister than he could have ever imagined.

I have been a professional in this business since my youth, always employing experts to carry out my schemes. Nadina was an exception, knowing too much for me to trust her. After her death, with the diamonds in my possession, I felt safe. However, I now realize that I made mistakes, especially in involving that fool Pagett. He may have a curious face and a traditional soul, but my sense of humor led me to keep him around. My dear Anne, never let your sense of humor cloud your judgment. I have always known it would be wise to get rid of Pagett, but his work ethic made it hard to find a reason to let him go. As for you, my dear, the question remains: where are the diamonds now?

I glanced up to find her eyes peering mischievously over the edge. Despite myself, a smile crept onto my face, prompting her to chuckle heartily and discard the paper. "I knew you had some wit hidden beneath that facade," she exclaimed. Her laughter was so contagious that I couldn't resist joining in, even though I wasn't fond of being called a "mutt." Although the girl possessed qualities I typically found unappealing, I decided not to be overly serious. I relaxed my stance. In the end, she was undeniably attractive. "See, we're pals now!" she announced with a smirk.

Poirot's calm voice broke the tense silence. "Do as I say, quickly." With trembling hands and a mix of anger and fear on her face, she obeyed his command. I felt a sense of relief. "Your restraints will suffice for her, Hastings. Perfect. Is she secured? Now, set me free. Luckily, her accomplices are gone. If we're lucky, we can escape unhindered." Moments later, Poirot was at my side, addressing the woman. "I'm not so easily defeated, madame. Goodnight." Her eyes held a dangerous glint, silenced by the gag.

"I suspect that room is where we will discover Jack Renauld," I whispered to Poirot. Madame Daubreuil welcomed us in, mentioning that Jack's condition had not changed much, but she thought we might want to check on him ourselves. Up the stairs we went, entering the bedroom. Marthe Daubreuil sat at a table, engrossed in her embroidery under the glow of a lamp. She gestured for silence as we approached. Jack Renauld lay in a restless slumber, his head tossing back and forth, his complexion still unusually red. "Will the doctor return soon?" Poirot inquired softly. "Only if we request it. For now, let him rest," Madame Daubreuil replied.

"Lady Yardly," I said, "I know the reason behind your visit. You have been targeted by blackmailers regarding the diamond." My words hit their mark, evident from the shock on her face. She stared at me, speechless and pale. "You are aware?" she gasped. "How?" I maintained my composure. "It's a simple deduction. If Miss Marvell, with one of the twin diamonds, has received threatening letters," "Miss Marvell? She was here?" "She just departed. So, if she's been warned, it follows that you, with the other diamond, would have also been a target."

Not that she doubted Tommy, but sometimes she questioned if someone as straightforward and sincere as him could truly outwit the cunning arch-criminal. The ultimate goal was to reach Sir James Peel Edgerton safely. But the looming question remained - would they make it to him? Could Mr. Brown's mysterious allies already be closing in on them? Even the image of Tommy with a gun did little to ease her mind. Perhaps he had already been outnumbered and subdued. Tuppence carefully strategized her next move.

The policeman presented a key, signaling for entrance. Sir James was a familiar figure to all, as were the directives regarding Tuppence. However, the presence of the third individual remained shrouded in mystery. The trio proceeded into the residence, closing the door behind them. Ascending the unstable staircase, they reached the worn curtain concealing the alcove where Tommy once sought refuge. Recalling Jane's account as "Annette," Tuppence examined the frayed velvet with curiosity. An eerie sensation crept over her, as if a hidden presence lurked behind the fabric.

What an incredible chance for a skilled thief! Look over there, Hastings, that large woman standing next to the pillar. She is absolutely covered in jewels." I followed his gaze. "Oh my, that's Mrs. Opalsen." "You know her?" "A little. Her husband is a wealthy stockbroker who struck it rich in the recent Oil boom." Later that evening we bumped into the Opalsens in the lounge, and I introduced Poirot to them. We exchanged pleasantries for a short while, and eventually enjoyed coffee together. Poirot complimented some of the more expensive gems adorning the lady's chest, and she immediately perked up. "Collecting gems is a passion of mine, Mr.…"

Poirot. My fondness for jewelry is well known. Ed always surprises me with a new piece whenever things are going smoothly. Do you have an interest in gemstones?” “I have had my fair share of experiences with them, madame. My line of work has led me to encounter some of the most renowned jewels in the world.” He proceeded to recount, using discreet aliases, the tale of the legendary jewels of a royal family, capturing Mrs. Opalsen's undivided attention. “Oh my!” she gasped, after he finished. “It's just like a scene from a play! You know, I possess some pearls with a fascinating backstory attached to them.

"Magnificent, exquisite, magnificent," he exclaimed. "Tonight, you have truly outdone yourself." With a gallant gesture, he planted a kiss on each of her cheeks in a rather casual manner. Madame Nadina gracefully accepted the praise, a routine she had grown accustomed to, and made her way to the dressing room. The room was adorned with bouquets scattered haphazardly, modern garments hanging on hooks, and the air filled with a heady mix of floral scents and luxurious perfumes. Jeanne, the loyal dresser, attended to her mistress, chatting incessantly and showering her with exaggerated compliments. Suddenly, a knock at the door brought an abrupt halt to the conversation.

As the butler entered, a telegram was presented to Lord Yardly on a silver platter. After a quick apology, he opened it and his expression changed. Passing it to his wife, he then turned to Monsieur Poirot. "I believe you should be informed. Hoffberg has a potential buyer for the diamond - an American leaving for the States tomorrow. A representative will inspect the stone tonight. If this deal goes through..." Lord Yardly's voice trailed off, his wife staring blankly at the telegram in her hand.

Poirot and Hastings were deep in discussion, trying to unravel the mystery of the crime that had taken place. Poirot was convinced that the key to the case lay in the details surrounding Mr. Renauld's murder. As they debated various theories, Hastings suggested that perhaps the open door was a clue that had been overlooked. Poirot considered this idea, but shook his head, indicating that there was more to the case than met the eye. He was certain that the solution to the mystery lay elsewhere, and that the truth would soon be revealed.

“You remember when you proposed,” Tuppence hesitated, her gaze fixed on the ground in a way that mirrored the classic Victorian heroines, “and wouldn’t accept no for an answer. I’ve pondered it at length ” “Go on,” Julius prompted. Beads of sweat formed on his brow. Tuppence’s expression softened. “You foolish man!” she exclaimed. “What possessed you to do it? I could tell back then that you didn’t give a damn about me!” “That’s not true. I held, and continue to hold, the utmost regard and admiration for you ” “Hmm,” Tuppence replied.

I first encountered her in the town, a woman with a sharp sense of humor that sets her apart. Despite my enjoyment of our conversations, they are often interrupted by a long-legged, stoic individual who clings to her side like a barnacle. Colonel Race, as he is known, does not strike me as someone who truly entertains her. Handsome, yes, but about as interesting as a wet rag. He fits the mold of those strong, silent types that seem to captivate female writers and young girls alike. As we departed from Madeira, Guy Pagett emerged on deck, his voice hollow as he began discussing matters of work.

I discovered later that the nurse who cared for me traveled to Paris and saw a specialist, pretending to be me. The specialist saw through her fake memory loss, but she memorized his methods and used them on me. I probably couldn't have fooled the specialist, a man who dedicated his life to his work, but I still managed to trick them. Not identifying as Jane Finn for so long helped. Suddenly, I was rushed to London one night and brought back to the house in Soho.

"Afternoon. I'd like a word with you after we finish our tea," she said, her eyes darting towards Mary. A lack of understanding seemed to linger between them. It was the first time I thought about what would become of the young girl. Mrs. Inglethorp hadn't made any arrangements for her, but I suspected John and Mary would want her to stay with them, at least until the war was over. John cared deeply for her and would hate to see her leave. John, who had just stepped back into the house, returned with a rare expression of anger clouding his typically amiable face."

Papa’s circle consisted of elderly Professors, each sporting a lengthy beard. I recall a particular encounter with Professor Peterson, who once complimented my "neat little waist" before attempting to kiss me. His outdated phrasing revealed his true age. I longed for excitement, love, and passion, yet found myself trapped in a mundane existence. The village had a worn lending library, where I indulged in tales of adventure and romance, falling asleep to dreams of bold Rhodesians and men who triumphed effortlessly in combat.

I made sure to thoroughly search the girl's belongings upon her arrival. "Where did you suddenly pull that from? It wasn't there a moment ago," I questioned. "Actually, it was," she responded calmly. "I had it hidden in my stocking." Sir Eustace lamented his lack of knowledge about women, admitting, "I should have paid more attention to them." Harry's patience wore thin as he slammed his hand on the table. "Stop the nonsense. If it weren't for your age, I'd toss you out the window, you scoundrel! Age or no age," he growled, taking a few steps forward while Sir Eustace quickly retreated behind the table.

Engrossed, I found myself slightly uplifted. My focus shifted to the passengers. A woman caught my eye. Around thirty years old, of average height, she had a round face with dimples and striking blue eyes. Her attire, while simple, exuded a certain Parisian elegance. There was a subtle air of authority as she effortlessly commanded the deck stewards. She had a designated deck-chair, along with a never-ending stack of cushions. Despite changing her mind multiple times on its placement, she maintained her allure and grace.

They had delivered the package, as instructed, to “L. Cavendish, Esq., Styles Court.” Sir Ernest Heavywether stood up heavily. “Where was the message sent from?” “From Styles Court.” “The same location where you sent the package?” “Correct.” “And the message originated from there?” “Yes.” Heavywether pounced on him like a predator: “How can you be sure?” “I I am not sure.” “How do you know that message originated from Styles? Did you see the postmark?” “No but ” “Ah, you didn’t see the postmark! Yet you assert with such certainty that it came from Styles. It could have been from any postmark, couldn't it?” “Yes.

Tuppence hesitated, feeling a shiver run down her spine. She opened the door cautiously, peering into the darkness beyond. With a deep breath, she stepped inside. The room was empty, but the air felt heavy with a sense of foreboding. Tuppence scanned the corners, her heart pounding in her chest. There was nowhere for anyone to hide. She scolded herself for letting her imagination run wild. Determined to regain her composure, Tuppence exited the room. Julius and Sir James were engrossed in conversation. As Sir James turned to her, he instructed, “Lock the door from the outside, Miss Tuppence, and keep the key. We can't risk anyone gaining access to that room.”

Robinson, a charming little bride who was there with her husband. I had never met them before, as Robinson was only a recent acquaintance of Parker’s. “Talking of flats,” she said, “have you heard of our piece of luck, Mr. Parker? We’ve got a flat at last! In Montagu Mansions.” “Well,” said Parker, “I’ve always said there are plenty of flats at a price!” “Yes, but this isn’t at a price. It’s dirt cheap. Eighty pounds a year!” “But but Montagu Mansions is just off Knightsbridge, isn’t it? Big handsome building. Or are you talking of a poor relation of the same name stuck in the slums somewhere?” “No, it’s the Knightsbridge one.

On the luxurious estate of Styles Court, he and his wife basked in the care and generosity of his stepmother, their benefactress. The prisoner, known for his reckless spending and scandalous affair with a neighbor's wife, found himself cornered by financial troubles. A heated argument with his stepmother on her final afternoon alive revealed tensions that escalated to a breaking point. The day before her death, the prisoner purchased a deadly poison, with intentions to shift blame onto an unsuspecting man, Mrs. Raikes.

"I hereby grant you permission to take possession of those documents and utilize them as you see fit. Farewell, gentlemen," Desjardeaux nodded slightly, while Crowther enthusiastically shook Poirot's hand. "Your words have persuaded me, M. Poirot. Despite its fantastical nature, I wholeheartedly believe in the veracity of your revelations." Ingles departed alongside us. "The outcome of the meeting does not disappoint me," Poirot remarked during our stroll. "I did not anticipate winning over Desjardeaux, but I have ensured that my knowledge will not perish with me. And I have gained a few followers."

"Ah, I've found it." He stood up and made his way to a beautifully crafted lacquer cabinet, a truly exquisite piece, even to my untrained eye. Upon his return, he held a letter in his hand. "Here you go. A note from an old sailor I encountered in Shanghai. Probably a drunken old man by now, I presume. I initially dismissed it as the ramblings of a drunkard." Reading it aloud, he recited, "DEAR SIR, You may not recall me, but you once helped me in Shanghai. Please help me again. I desperately need money to leave the country."

Julius stood in front of the safe in the apartment, a moment of hesitation before he finally answered, "Nothing." But was it really nothing? Perhaps he had uncovered something he didn't want to share. Tuppence decided to play along, responding casually, "Nothing in particular." She sensed Julius casting a quick glance in her direction. "How about a ride in the park?" he suggested. "Sure, why not," she agreed. As they strolled beneath the trees, a sense of excitement tingled in the air, bringing a fresh energy to Tuppence.

"So, what do we know about Rayburn? He's got a scar, sure, but that could easily be a fake. He fits the height and build profile though. Can you remember the details of the head you described to the police at Scotland Yard?" My heart raced. Suzanne was intelligent and well-educated, but I hoped she wasn't familiar with the technical jargon of anthropology. "Dolichocephalic," I replied casually. Suzanne seemed uncertain. "Are you sure?" "Absolutely. It means long-headed, with a width less than 75 percent of its length," I explained smoothly. There was a moment of silence.

"At that moment, the front door opened and M. Hautet and the commissary descended the steps. "Ah, M. Poirot, we were just about to search for you," the magistrate stated. "Although it is late, I feel compelled to visit Madame Daubreuil. Surely, she will be greatly distressed by M. Renauld's passing, and perhaps we can find a lead from her. The secret he kept from his wife may have been shared with the woman who captivated him. We are aware of our Samsons' vulnerabilities, aren't we?" I found M. Hautet's choice of words quite striking."

We were there the next morning for Jack Renauld's examination. He looked drastically different, with sunken cheeks and dark circles under his eyes. He refused to acknowledge being in Merlinville on the night of the crime, insisting he was in Cherbourg instead. The witnesses identified him from the train, and he recognized the dagger found at the crime scene as his own design. Despite the mounting evidence against him, Jack maintained his innocence, stating he did not kill his father. Suddenly, a lady entered the room and confessed to the murder, revealing the truth behind the tangled web of lies and deceit.

"As I entered the old abandoned warehouse, memories flooded back from my time in Soho. The fear of the unknown gripped me as I scanned the room, but a wave of relief washed over me when I spotted my coat draped over a chair. The magazine, still tucked in the pocket, was a small comfort. However, the nagging feeling of being watched persisted. Despite my thorough search, I couldn't shake the suspicion of hidden eyes. Overwhelmed, I sank onto a nearby table, whispering 'Mon Dieu! Mon Dieu!' into my hands. The slightest sound could send shivers down my spine."

“Where is your assistant now?” “He’s out sick with a stomach issue,” I replied. “Are you certain it’s just a stomach issue?” “Absolutely. He gets them often.” My guest smirked. “It might be more than a stomach issue. Only time will tell. But let me assure you, Sir Eustace, Mr. Milray wouldn’t be shocked if there was an attempt to remove your assistant. Don’t worry about yourself” I must have shown a hint of concern “you’re not in danger. With your assistant gone, it would be easier to reach you. Either way, Mr. Milray wants me to go with you.

"Surely, he's nearby!" She gazed at Sir James, who responded seriously: "Respecting your hunch, Miss Tuppence (and mine too), I fail to see how anyone could be here undetected." The young woman felt a bit reassured by his remarks. "Staying awake at night always gives me the creeps," she admitted. "Agreed," Sir James agreed. "It's like we're conducting a séance. Maybe with a psychic here, we'd witness something extraordinary." "Are you a believer in spiritualism?" Tuppence inquired, her eyes widening.

"Inglethorp’s voice you heard?” “Oh, yes, sir, whose else’s could it be?” “Well, what happened next?” “Later, I came back to the hall; but it was all quiet. At five o’clock, Mrs. Inglethorp rang the bell and told me to bring her a cup of tea nothing to eat to the boudoir. She was looking dreadful so white and upset. ‘Dorcas,’ she says, ‘I’ve had a great shock.’ ‘I’m sorry for that, m’m,’ I says. ‘You’ll feel better after a nice hot cup of tea, m’m.’ She had something in her hand."

"But at what point did their 'strategy' falter?" "My friend, the idea of posing as a maid or butler is sound, but one must not neglect their duties. They overlooked a room in need of dusting; hence, when the man placed the jewel-case on the small table by the connecting door, it left a distinct mark." "I recall that moment," I exclaimed. "Everything became clear." A brief pause followed. "And I have my pearls," Mrs. Opalsen added, like a chorus in a play. "Well then," I remarked, "it's time for dinner." Poirot walked beside me. "This success should boost your reputation," I commented.

"The cabin must have held some secrets," I suggested. "That would make sense of why my belongings were thrown about the following day. Yet, I scoured every inch and found nothing hidden." "Do you think the young man could have planted something in a drawer while you were distracted?" Suzanne proposed. I dismissed the idea. "I would have noticed." "Perhaps they were after your important document?" she pondered. "It's possible, but it had already served its purpose. The time and date had come and gone." Suzanne concurred, "True, of course."

"That wasn’t the usual way. Listen.” So I recounted the incident of the cocoa sample that Poirot had sent for analysis. John cut in just like I did. “But wait, Bauerstein had already analyzed it, right?” “Exactly, that’s the key. It didn’t click for me until now. Do you see? Bauerstein had it analyzed, that’s the trick! If Bauerstein is the killer, it would be easy for him to swap his sample with regular cocoa, and have that tested. Naturally, they wouldn’t detect any strychnine! But no one would suspect Bauerstein, or consider getting another sample except Poirot,” I realized, a bit late.

“Then I shan’t drink it,” declared Tuppence. “I’d much rather be shot. At least that would cause a commotion, and someone might overhear. But I refuse to be eliminated quietly like a lamb.” Mrs. Vandemeyer was furious. “Don’t be absurd! Do you truly believe I desire a murder investigation trailing after me? If you possess any intelligence, you’ll understand that poisoning you wouldn’t align with my plans. It’s just a sleeping potion, nothing more. You’ll awaken tomorrow unharmed. I simply can’t be bothered with tying you up and silencing you.”

Bella's unexpected visit threw off his plans. He quickly got rid of her to proceed with his dark deeds. Binding and silencing Madame Renauld, he corrected past mistakes, leaving subtle clues behind. Disguised in an overcoat, he carried out the sinister act under the cover of darkness. The meticulous arrangement of the crime scene pointed directly at him. The final twist of fate came when he met his own demise. Despite the complex web of lies, Poirot unraveled the truth behind the elaborate scheme. The clever manipulation of evidence by the real culprits posed a challenge, but Poirot's keen insight prevailed. The intricate dance of deception and betrayal left a trail of devastation in its wake.

On my instructions, Mrs. Renauld rejected her son and announced her plan to draft a will the following day that would prevent him from inheriting any of his father's wealth. It was a drastic measure, but a necessary one, and Madame Renauld was willing to take the chance, although she neglected to mention her change of location. I assumed she assumed I was aware. Everything unfolded as predicted. Marthe Daubreuil attempted one final effort to claim the Renauld fortune and was unsuccessful! Had my obsession with the smell of moth balls gone too far? I thought I was imagining things when I detected the familiar scent on the roll of films as well. Poirot pondered over the situation, weighing the facts carefully. “This is a dark and complex case,” he muttered to himself. “We must proceed with caution and method.”

Leaning in close, I whispered, “I suspect she’s been poisoned. And I believe Dr. Bauerstein shares that suspicion.” Mary gasped, her eyes widening in fear. “No, they’re here right enough. One of the two must have hidden them and it’s very unlikely for the chambermaid to have done so.” Poirot calmly pointed out. The inspector was taken aback by his confidence. Poirot then demonstrated his deductions swiftly, proving that the chambermaid couldn't have hidden the necklace. The inspector, satisfied, continued his search and found the necklace hidden in the maid's bed. Mrs. Opalsen was relieved to have it back, even though Poirot suspected it was an imitation. He decided to keep this information to himself, knowing that the true thief had not been caught. Poirot and his companion left the room, but Poirot's mind was already working on the next steps to solve the case.

I realized we were entering the Ardennes, recalling Poirot mentioning a brother in Spa. Despite this, we bypassed Spa and veered off the main road into the hilly forests until we arrived at a secluded hamlet, with a solitary white villa perched on the hillside. The car halted in front of the green door, where an elderly man-servant greeted me in French, confirming my identity as M. le Capitaine Hastings. "Monsieur le Capitaine is expected. If he will follow me," he said, gesturing for me to enter.

"Oh, the world of fishing is diverse. I am tempted to linger and investigate the whereabouts of that young man." "Oh!" Tuppence exclaimed with delight. "Nevertheless, as I mentioned earlier, it's truly unfair of Carter to assign this task to you two youngsters. Now, please don't take offense, Miss " "Cowley. Prudence Cowley. But everyone calls me Tuppence." "Well, Miss Tuppence, since I am certainly going to be a companion. Don't be offended by my perception of your youth. Youth is a flaw that can be easily overcome. Now, let's discuss this young Tommy of yours." "Yes." Tuppence interlocked her fingers. "To be honest, the situation doesn't look good for him."

"You will have a Military officer and a C.I.D. man by your side, ready to assist you in any way. Does that meet your requirements?" "Certainly. Before you go, gentlemen, may I ask why you chose to seek me out? I am but a stranger in this vast city of London." "We were directed to you by a prominent figure from your homeland, based on his strong recommendation." "Ah, my dear old friend the Préfet?" Lord Estair shook his head. "Someone even higher than the Préfet. A figure of great authority in Belgium, whose power will be restored! An oath that England has taken!" Poirot's hand swiftly rose in a dramatic salute.

A few moments later, he returned with Mrs. Renauld. "Madame is here," he announced. Giraud approached with a brief nod. "Follow me, madame." Leading her across the room, he suddenly stepped aside. "Here stands the man. Do you recognize him?" His piercing eyes studied her face intently, searching for any hint of emotion or familiarity. However, Mrs. Renauld remained unnervingly composed, almost too composed in my opinion. She gazed down at the body with little interest, showing no signs of distress or recognition. "No," she replied calmly. "I have never laid eyes on him before."

"And what about Mrs. Ferguson?" inquired Parker. "Let's hear your deductions, Hastings." "It's elementary, my dear Watson," I quipped. "She simply went to the incorrect apartment." "Impressive, Captain Hastings," Mrs. Robinson exclaimed with admiration. In that moment, I found myself yearning for Poirot's presence. At times, I believe he underestimates my abilities. The entire situation was quite amusing, so I presented it as a playful puzzle to Poirot the next day. He appeared intrigued, probing me for details on flat rents in different areas. "An intriguing tale," he mused.

“And yet,” whispered the magistrate, “it seemed so promising at the start, such a simple and beautiful case.” His eyes briefly met Mrs. Renauld's, causing a sudden blush to spread across his face. “Ah, indeed,” he cleared his throat, shuffling through the documents scattered on the desk. “Now, where were we? Ah, yes, the murder weapon. I'm afraid this may be difficult for you, M. Renauld. I believe it was a gift from you to your mother. Quite tragic, very distressing.” Jack Renauld leaned in closer, his complexion turning from flushed to a ghostly pallor. “Are you suggesting that my father was killed with a mere aeroplane wire paper cutter? It can't be! Such a trivial object!” “Unfortunately, M.

Count Foscatini. It appears there has been an incident at his residence,” he said, catching the man off guard. “I was unaware of any such occurrence. Mr. Graves, who works for Count Foscatini, left not long ago and mentioned nothing of the sort,” the man replied. “Is the Count by himself in the apartment?” “No, he is currently dining with two other gentlemen,” the man answered. “What can you tell me about them?” I inquired eagerly as we rode the elevator to the second floor where Flat II was located. “I did not personally see them, sir, but I believe they were foreigners,” he responded. As we arrived at the landing, facing No. II, the doctor pressed the doorbell.

"He retreated and I was left to process this piece of information. Who was the mysterious woman who visited my cabin on the night of the 22nd? My expression darkened as I grasped the cleverness and boldness of my unidentified enemies. Gathering my thoughts, I exited my cabin and headed towards Mrs. Blair's. I rapped on the door. “Who is it?” her voice called out from inside. “It's Anne Beddingfeld.” “Oh, come in, Gipsy girl.” I stepped inside. Various articles of clothing were strewn about, and Mrs. Blair was adorned in a stunning kimono. The colors of orange, gold, and black in the garment made my mouth water as I admired it."

Poirot's brow furrowed in confusion, causing me to lean in and ask softly, "What's wrong?" He dismissed my question with a shake of his head and inquired, "Excuse me, M. Bex, but could M. Renauld have driven the car himself?" The commissary glanced at Françoise, who quickly responded, "No, Monsieur did not drive himself." Poirot's expression darkened. "I wish you would share your concerns with me," I urged. "Don't you see? In his letter, M. Renauld mentioned sending the car for me in Calais." "Maybe he meant a rental car," I proposed. "Probably, but why rent a car when you have your own?"

Tuppence requested tea and toast, reminding the server to bring separate teapots. Tommy joined her at the table, his red hair slicked back perfectly. His face, though plain, had the air of a gentleman and athlete. Despite his well-cut brown suit nearing the end of its life, they made a strikingly modern pair.

It started off like a scene from a love story. But now, stripped of its charm, it appeared to be shifting towards harsh reality. Tommy, that was the only thing that mattered. Throughout the day, Tuppence fought back tears. "Silly girl," she scolded herself, "no need to cry. You care for him, yes. You've been friends forever. But there's no reason to get emotional." Meanwhile, Boris was nowhere to be found. He didn't show up at the apartment, leaving Julius and the car waiting in vain. Tuppence found herself lost in new thoughts.

“I can’t believe how you managed to come up with that plan so quickly,” she exclaimed. Tommy shrugged. “I was desperate and had to think of something,” he replied. After a brief silence, Tommy brought up Mrs. Vandemeyer's death. “They’re saying it was heart failure caused by an overdose, or something like that,” he explained. “We don’t need to worry about an inquest. But I think Tuppence, Sir James, and I all have the same suspicion.” “Mr. Brown?” Tommy suggested. “Exactly,” he confirmed. “But even so,” Tommy added, furrowing his brow, “Mr. Brown can’t fly. I can't figure out how he managed to enter and exit the scene.”

Near the end of the room stood a table with four chairs positioned around it. The first chair was unoccupied, adorned with a vibrant mandarin's cape. Mr. Abe Ryland lounged in the second chair, puffing on a cigar. Madame Olivier, with her intense gaze and austere countenance, reclined in the third chair. Number Four settled into the fourth chair. It was evident - we were face to face with the notorious Big Four. The absence of Li Chang Yen loomed over us, a reminder of his distant yet firm grip on the clandestine organization. A startled gasp escaped Madame Olivier as we entered the room.

Amidst the circumstances, our group was far from jovial. The aftermath of a jolt is always taxing, and it appeared that we were all grappling with it. Etiquette and manners dictated that we maintain our composure, but I couldn't help but question the true challenge of this self-restraint. No teary eyes, no hint of hidden sorrow. I sensed that Dorcas was the one impacted the most by the emotional aspect of the ordeal. I won't dwell on Alfred Inglethorp, who portrayed the grieving husband in a way that I found repulsive in its insincerity.

I shall not be long.” I was half asleep in my chair when the landlady tapped on the door, and put her head in. “It’s another lady to see Mr. Poirot, sir. I’ve told her he was out, but she says as how she’ll wait, seeing as she’s come up from the country.” “Oh, show her in here, Mrs. Murchison. Perhaps I can do something for her.” In another moment the lady had been ushered in. My heart gave a leap as I recognized her. Lady Yardly’s portrait had figured too often in the Society papers to allow her to remain unknown. “Do sit down, Lady Yardly,” I said, drawing forward a chair...

"I truly believe so.” “They might have eloped,” I said, trying to calm the situation, even though I knew it was a foolish suggestion. But in a place like this, where would they go? I kept rambling, unsure of how much longer I could keep it up, until Race suddenly entered the room. I had been somewhat correct - he had been out for a walk, but Anne was not with him. My approach to the situation was completely off. Race quickly had the entire hotel in chaos within minutes.

"The plea was desperate, but I had no other choice. I had to reach out to him, to beg for his help. I couldn't bear the thought of Jack being taken away from me. The pain was unbearable. I needed Poirot by my side, to unravel the truth behind this madness that threatened to consume us. Little did I know that the secrets hidden beneath the surface would soon be brought to light. Poirot's questions pierced through my soul, revealing a tangled web of deceit and betrayal. And as the truth slowly emerged, I found myself on my knees, begging for salvation."

"You see, Anne, Sir Eustace has been cleared of all charges. His guilt is certain, despite some technicalities. There is nothing to prevent you from being together now." His voice was hesitant as he spoke, avoiding eye contact. "I am aware," I responded with relief. "And there is no obstacle to him reclaiming his true identity immediately." "Indeed, there is not." "Do you know his true name?" The question caught me off guard. "Yes, I do. It's Harry Lucas." His silence in response felt unsettling, leaving me with a sense of unease.

“Miss Murdoch also,” I added, “is completely truthful, nothing to hide there.” “Indeed. But it struck me as odd that she didn’t hear a thing, right next door; while Mrs. Cavendish, in a completely different part of the house, heard the table crash perfectly.” “Well, she is young. And she sleeps deeply.” “Ah, of course! She must be an exceptional sleeper, that one!” I found his tone slightly unsettling, but just then a sharp rap sounded, and peering out the window we saw the two detectives standing outside, waiting for us.

"His face, once flushed with shock, turned deathly pale. 'An aeroplane wire paper cutter? That's what killed my father?' 'Yes, it seems so,' replied the detective. 'Sharp and easy to handle.' The tool had been removed from the body, but M. Renauld requested to see it. The commissary was sent to retrieve it. Meanwhile, Poirot noticed a pair of candlesticks out of place. Suddenly, the commissary burst in, alarmed. 'The dagger is gone!' 'Gone?' exclaimed the magistrate. 'Vanished. The glass jar is empty!' Everyone turned to the witness, who admitted to visiting the shed that morning with a young English lady. The magistrate scolded him for the irregularity, but softened at the mention of youth and beauty."

On the pretense of fetching her employer, she rushes upstairs, dons a colorful sweater and a cap adorned with black ringlets which she forcefully pulls over the gray wig. A couple of skillful adjustments, and the makeup is erased, a hint of blush applied, and the captivating Zoe Havering descends with her melodious voice. No one pays much attention to the maid. Why would they? There is no evidence linking her to the crime. She, too, has an alibi.” “But the gun discovered in Ealing? Mrs. Havering couldn't have left it there?” “No, that was Roger Havering’s doing but they made a blunder.

I always associated it with a hula-hula, which, I believe, is a kind of straw skirt that Hawaiian girls dance in. No, I think I am wrong, that is a lava-lava. All these things are very cheering after England. It would brighten our cold Island life if one could have a breakfast of bacon-bacon and then go out clad in a jumper-jumper. Suzanne seemed calmer after breakfast. They had given me a room next to hers with a beautiful view over Table Bay. I gazed at the view while Suzanne searched for some special face cream. Once she found it and began applying it, she was able to listen to me.

"The chauffeur, surprised by the attack, slammed on the brakes. The Prime Minister leaned out of the window. Without warning, two shots were fired. The first one barely missed his cheek, the second, thankfully, missed altogether. The chauffeur, understanding the peril, quickly sped forward, dispersing the group of assailants.""A close call," I exclaimed, feeling a chill. "Mr. MacAdam brushed off the minor injury he sustained. He insisted it was just a superficial cut."

"Every hen lays eggs of different sizes," he grumbled. "No symmetry at the breakfast table. They should sort them properly." Japp interrupted, "Forget the eggs. Tell us where our customer went after leaving The Cedars." Poirot replied, "He went to his hiding place. Monsieur Davenheim's grey cells may have some malformation, but they are top-notch!" Japp pressed, "Do you know where he is hiding?" Poirot confidently responded, "Of course! It's quite clever."

"You and your loved ones will remain unharmed. I assure you of that." I chuckled mockingly. "And what if I choose not to follow your authoritative directive?" "It's more of a suggestion. Let's call it a caution?" His voice held a chilling threat. "Consider this the initial caution," he murmured. "It would be wise for you to take it seriously." Without warning, he stood up and swiftly made his way towards the exit. I leaped up and pursued him instantly, but unfortunately collided head-on with a massively obese man who obstructed my path to the adjacent table.

"Plans are already set in motion. Daily discreet announcements will be made. Acquaintances and family members will be directed to contact my lawyer at his place of business. Perhaps today we might Ah, the telephone! It's likely just a mistake, and they will apologize for the inconvenience, but it's possible yes, it's possible that something has come up." I walked to the other side of the room and answered the phone. "Yes, yes. M. Poirot's residence. Yes, Captain Hastings here. Oh, it's you, Mr. McNeil! (McNeil and Hodgson were Poirot's legal representatives.) I will inform him.

”People from all walks of life have been urging me to tell this tale, from the highest echelons (like Lord Nasby) to the lowest (such as our former maid, Emily, who I encountered during my recent trip to England. “Oh, miss, what a marvelous novel you could craft from these events, just like in the paintings!”). I must acknowledge that I am well-suited for the job. I was involved in this case from its inception, I navigated every twist and turn, and I ultimately witnessed its conclusion firsthand.

“I do not believe so. I felt an immediate connection with him. No, I am quite certain that Dr. Hall is trustworthy.” “Hall, you say?” inquired Sir James. “That is quite interesting, truly very interesting.” “Why?” Tuppence demanded. “Because I actually bumped into him this morning. I have had occasional contact with him over the years, and this morning I happened to see him on the street. He mentioned staying at the Métropole.” He looked at Julius. “Did he not mention that he was coming to the city?” Julius shook his head. “Interesting,” Sir James pondered.

"Poirot agreed to join Lady Yardly and the children, quickly forming a bond with them. They played together and even managed to pull me into the fun. “You are a good mother,” Poirot complimented Lady Yardly, as the children were taken away by their nurse. Lady Yardly fixed her hair and confessed, “I adore them,” her voice filled with emotion. “And they adore you as well!” Poirot remarked. The sound of a dressing-gong signaled that it was time to retire to our rooms."

I followed her lead, purchasing a variety of trinkets for a mere “tiki” (threepence) each. The selection ranged from giraffes and tigers to snakes and a forlorn eland, not to mention comical little black warriors. The thrill was palpable as we reveled in the moment. Despite Sir Eustace's attempts to rein us in, our enthusiasm could not be contained. It's a wonder we weren't left stranded at some remote station along the route. South African locomotives depart without fanfare, silently slipping away as you scramble back on board. Suzanne's astonishment at my last-minute boarding in Cape Town was priceless.

My father passed away when I was a child. A few years later, my mother also died. I was left with only my Uncle Andrew, who took me in and treated me like his own daughter. He strongly believed in practical skills over book knowledge and was against women receiving education. Despite his wishes, I pursued my studies and won a scholarship. When my uncle passed away, I discovered that he had left a challenging will, giving me a year to prove my intelligence. I sought the help of Monsieur Poirot to unravel the mystery hidden within Crabtree Manor. We were welcomed by Mr. and Mrs. Baker, who had worked for my uncle. The next morning, our investigation began in earnest in the late Mr. Marsh's study.

"The crafty 'special table' turned out to be a devious contraption. The table I scrutinized was an exact replica, completely innocuous. It was swapped with the original right after the murder took place. The operation was orchestrated from the apartment below, which, as you may recall, was rented out fully furnished. However, at least one accomplice was present in Savaronoff's residence. The young woman is a mole for the notorious Big Four, scheming to claim Savaronoff's fortune." "And what about Ivan?" "I have a strong suspicion that Ivan is, in fact, the elusive Number Four." "No way!" "Yes. The man possesses an extraordinary talent for assuming different personas."

"Really?" "Did you not hear the news?" "What news?" "There was another murder last night!" "What?" Abandoning my breakfast, I grabbed my hat and sprinted towards the scene. Another murder and Poirot was not around! What bad luck. But who was the victim? I burst through the gate. A cluster of servants stood in the driveway, chatting and gesturing. I grabbed Françoise. "What's going on?" "Oh, sir! Another death! It's awful. There's a curse on this place. Yes, I'm saying it, a curse! They need to call for the priest to bring some holy water. I'll never spend another night under this roof. It could be me next, who knows?" She made the sign of the cross.

“Bauerstein.” “Any more faults to find with the evidence?” I inquired sarcastically. “Mon ami,” replied Poirot solemnly, “when you find that people are not telling you the truth watch out! Now, unless I am much mistaken, at the inquest today only one at most, two individuals were speaking the truth without reservation or deceit.” “Oh, come now, Poirot! I won’t mention Lawrence, or Mrs. Cavendish. But there’s John and Miss Howard, surely they were speaking the truth?” “Both of them, my friend? One, I admit, but both!” His words gave me an unpleasant jolt.

"Fine,” Tommy replied, glancing at the Daily Mirror, “go ahead. I won’t interfere.” “Listen,” Tuppence interjected. “I’ve had an idea…” Her train of thought was cut short by a sudden round of applause. “It’s easy for you to joke around, Tommy. Maybe you should try using your brain for once.” “Sorry, Tuppence, but my contract strictly prohibits me from working before noon.” “Tommy, I swear, I will throw something at you. It’s imperative that we immediately devise a plan of action.” “Agreed!” “Let’s get started.” Tommy folded his newspaper and set it down decisively.

"I'm sorry to say," Crowther began, his voice tinged with concern as he glanced at Poirot, "that I've uncovered the true identity of Number Four. And now, my life is in imminent danger. He's known as 'The Destroyer' for a reason - he'll stop at nothing to eliminate me. Here, take this key and sealed envelope," Poirot continued, handing them over to Crowther. "Inside are all my case notes and strategies to combat the looming threat that could strike at any moment. They're safely stored in a secure location. If anything happens to me, M. Crowther, you must act."

"No, you are right," he said, "it is not as though there was a blood tie. She has been kind and generous to these Cavendishes, but she was not their own mother. Blood tells always remember that blood tells." "Poirot," I said, "I wish you would tell me why you wanted to know if Mrs.   "No," he said. "It's not like there was a blood connection. She's been good to the Cavendishes, but she wasn't their real mother. Blood always tells, remember that." "Poirot," I inquired, "can you please explain why you were interested in Mrs.

"He was a man who once loved me," she said quietly. The Count raised an eyebrow, "In South Africa?" She nodded, confirming it as her native country. As her visitor prepared to leave, he warned her about underestimating the 'Colonel', suggesting he may be more dangerous than a mere disillusioned lover. She scoffed at the idea, confident in her knowledge of him. But as he left, his parting words lingered in the air, "I wonder if you do? I very much wonder if you do."

“Of course, sir. You must understand that if I believed revealing these details would benefit my spouse, I would have done so. However, I did not find it relevant to the matter of his innocence or guilt.” “In a way, that is true, ma'am. But it helped me clear my mind of misunderstandings, allowing me to perceive other details more clearly.” “The will!” exclaimed Lawrence. “So, Mary, you were the one who got rid of the will?” She denied it, and Poirot did the same. “No,” he stated calmly. “There is only one individual who could have potentially destroyed that will, Mrs.…”

“Your Honor,” I began, feeling a weight of guilt on my shoulders, “I must confess to a serious misstep that I deeply regret.” “Please, go on,” the judge urged. “I encountered a young woman, a friend of mine, who expressed a strong curiosity to explore every corner of the crime scene. Against my better judgment, I gave her access to the restricted area,” I admitted. The magistrate's expression hardened. “This is a grave error, Detective Reynolds. Your actions were reckless and completely out of line. Such behavior cannot be tolerated in our line of work.”

Colonel Race was determined to see Sir Eustace face the consequences of his actions. Given Sir Eustace's network of spies and agents in Jo'burg, it was no surprise he had managed to escape. Colonel Race doubted they would ever be able to capture him, especially considering his well-thought-out escape plan. Despite my reservations, I nodded along as Colonel Race discussed the situation. The conversation fell quiet until Colonel Race inquired about Harry, to which I replied that he had left at dawn and I hadn't seen him since.

"If she believes you're interested in getting to know her, she's flattered, and will find a way to make it happen." "You're giving me too much credit," Tommy whispered. "Conversely," Tuppence continued, "my millionaire would likely flee! No relationship is without challenges. The key is to earn money!" "We've attempted that, without success," Tommy pointed out. "We have indeed exhausted all conventional options. But what if we were to explore the unconventional? Tommy, let's become adventurers!" "Absolutely," Tommy responded with enthusiasm. "Where do we start?" "That's the dilemma. If we could establish a reputation, perhaps individuals would enlist our services to carry out illicit activities for them."

"It’s none of my concern. The coffee-cups are a mystery to me, except for those pristine Old Worcester ones that never see the light of day. You wouldn’t appreciate them, would you, Hastings?” I shook my head. “You’re missing out. Handling or even just admiring a piece of exquisite old china is a true pleasure.” “So, what should I inform Poirot?” “Let him know I have no clue what he’s referring to. It’s all Greek to me.” “Fine.” As I started to walk back to the house, he unexpectedly beckoned me back.

Manning set the time at around four-thirty, while William believed it was somewhat earlier. Cynthia Murdoch was the next to arrive, but had little information to offer. She had been unaware of the tragedy until Mrs. Cavendish woke her up. "You didn't hear the table fall?" "No. I was fast asleep." The Coroner chuckled. "A clear conscience leads to peaceful sleep," he remarked. "Thank you, Miss Murdoch, that will be all." "Miss Howard." Miss Howard presented the letter from Mrs. Inglethorp dated the 17th evening. Poirot and I had already reviewed it. Unfortunately, it did not provide any new insights into the tragedy.

"Isn't it rather the case of you being here without him, like a cart without a horse?" His ill-timed jest lingered in the air as I made my way to the house. The door was opened by a middle-aged woman in black. I explained Mr. Havering's delay and my purpose there. She led me inside, closing the door behind us. The events of last night unfolded in her retelling - a mysterious man, a shot, and Mr. Pace left bleeding. The man with the black beard had vanished through the window before help arrived. Mrs. Havering was informed of my presence and descended the stairs promptly. Her vibrant presence was undeniable, even in the midst of tragedy. I introduced myself and she nodded in understanding.

"Ugh, this blasted sand!" "Oh come now, Belgium has plenty of sand," I pointed out, recalling a vacation in Knocke-sur-mer surrounded by "les dunes impeccables" as the guidebook described. "Not in Brussels," Poirot stated firmly. He stared at the Pyramids pensively. "It's true that they, at least, have a solid and geometrical shape, but their uneven surface is rather displeasing. And those palm trees, I cannot stand them. They don't even plant them in straight rows!" I interrupted his complaints, proposing that we head to the camp.

"No way!" "I'm right there with you," Ingles stated. "Oh, by the way, I'll be heading to China as soon as I can." "Is that a good idea?" "Definitely not," replied Ingles sarcastically. "But it's something I have to do. One must take risks." "You're very courageous!" exclaimed Poirot with feeling. "If we weren't in public, I'd give you a hug." I sensed that Ingles seemed somewhat relieved. "I don't think I'll be any more at risk in China than you are in London," he grumbled. "That's probably true," conceded Poirot. "I just hope they don't manage to harm Hastings as well. That would really upset me."

I was always the professional in this business, starting as a youngster with a knack for devising clever schemes. I never made the mistake of carrying them out myself - always employing experts. But Nadina was an exception. She knew too much. My downfall was trusting her. Now, reflecting on my failures, I realize where I went wrong. That imbecile Pagett was a pawn in my game, with his poisoner's face and old-fashioned ways. My sense of humor led me to keep him around, even though I knew it was unwise. But I digress. The focus now is on you. Where are the diamonds? Do you trust Harry Rayburn with them?"

"I am no magician, Madame. But I am a man who can make dreams a reality. I have the means to grant you what you seek, for a price. Your enemies will fall, youth and beauty will be restored, and joy will return to your heart. But remember, everything comes at a cost." The countess eyed him warily, considering his words. "And what price must I pay for such miracles?" Achille Poirot smiled, a glint of mischief in his eyes. "Only your soul, Madame. Only your soul."

Cabin 17 held a mysterious allure, drawing in countless individuals. Despite the superior options available, both men remained fixated on this particular cabin. The number itself seemed to haunt the protagonist, triggering memories of past events. With a sense of urgency, they retrieved a valuable document hidden among rolled stockings. The significance of the number 17 weighed heavily on their mind, especially in relation to a crucial date linked to the Kilmorden Castle's departure. What if their interpretation was flawed?

"Oh, just by inquiring with her," responded Sir James casually. "That's our usual approach, you see." He drummed his fingers on the table, and Tuppence once again sensed the imposing aura that emanated from the man. "And if she remains silent?" Julius interjected abruptly. "I believe she will cooperate. I possess certain influential tools. However, if by some chance she does not, there is always the option of persuasion." "Of course. And that's where I can be of service!" exclaimed Julius, slamming his fist on the table. "You can rely on me, if needed, for a sum of one million dollars. Indeed, one million dollars!" Sir James took a seat and scrutinized Julius intently.

As he entered the room, a tall young man caught everyone's attention. Mrs. Renauld seemed overjoyed to see him, embracing him with tears in her eyes. The young man, Jack Renauld, explained that his voyage was delayed due to engine trouble. He received a telegram from his father instructing him to travel to South America, a journey he knew little about. Despite claims of a good relationship, Jack admitted to a heated argument with his father before his departure. The tension in the room was palpable as the interrogation continued, with Jack defiantly refusing to disclose the subject of their dispute. The atmosphere was charged with suspicion and uncertainty.

"I might have been defamed," "I believe," Julius said, "that humanity would benefit from someone putting you out of commission. But don't fret. I have no plans to end your life this time, as long as you cooperate." The Russian trembled under the intense threat in Julius' eyes. He nervously licked his dry lips. "What do you want? Money?" "No. I want Jane Finn." "Jane Finn? I have no idea who that is!" "You're lying! You know exactly who I'm talking about." "I swear I have never heard of her!" "Well, I think Little Willie here is itching to leave," Julius retorted. The Russian visibly weakened.

I positioned myself on the floor, mimicking the posture of the deceased. Placing a cushion in my place, I painstakingly recreated the movements and actions of the physician from memory. Completing the task, I achieved my objective. Leaning back, I scowled at the walls before me. An article in the evening news mentioned a suspicious death in the subway, raising questions of intent versus happenstance. The course of action became evident to me, and Mr. Flemming concurred upon hearing my account. "You will undoubtedly be summoned to testify at the inquiry."

"It may sound harsh, but my advice is to move on. Time heals all wounds. You'll forget." "Forget about it? Never!" Mr. Smith shook his head. "That's what you think now. It's hard to imagine that courageous little boy! I regret the whole situation deeply regret." Sarah snapped back to reality. "I'm sorry for taking up your time," she said, pushing herself. "There's no need for you to feel guilty. We were naive to take on that task. You warned us. But I wish I had been the one to face the consequences."

"I remember Joseph Aarons, the theatrical agent. I assisted him with a Japanese wrestler. He can help us find what we need to know. It took time to find him. He agreed to help. Aarons knows a young girl named Bella Duveen. She is a performer. The Dulcibella Kids are her sisters. They are in Coventry at the Palace. Poirot booked tickets for the show. The sisters performed well. Bella Duveen, now Cinderella, confessed to taking the dagger. She feared being caught. I comforted her and confessed my love. She was surprised and asked why I wouldn't turn her in. I reassured her of my love and understanding. She was relieved and asked what I knew."

“I must say, that looks like hair,” I observed with a grimace. “It is indeed hair. Those feet of hers were a dead giveaway.” “Well then, it’s settled. Now, Sir Eustace, I need to discuss some personal matters with you. Your subtle hints about my time in Florence have not gone unnoticed.” Finally, the truth about Pagett's time in Florence is about to come to light. “Just come clean, my friend,” I urged gently.

“What do you need?” Spotting Dorcas, the parlourmaid, entering the dining area, she instructed her to bring some stamps to the boudoir. “Yes, ma’am.” Hesitating, the elderly servant suggested gently: “Shouldn’t you retire for the night? You seem quite exhausted.” “Maybe you’re right, Dorcas yes no not now. I have some letters to finish before the mail is collected. Have you lit the fire in my chamber as instructed?” “Yes, ma’am.” “Then I’ll retire right after dinner.” With that, she returned to the boudoir, leaving Cynthia pondering behind her. “My goodness! I wonder what’s happening?” she remarked to Lawrence.

Annette informed me of your escape. Cheer up. “Sincerely, “TWOPENCE.” Tommy called for Albert as soon as he read the letter. “Prepare my luggage! We're leaving!” “Of course, sir.” Albert hurried up the stairs. Was it Holyhead? Tommy was confused. He read further. Albert's footsteps echoed above. Then, a sudden realization hit Tommy. “Albert! I made a mistake! Don't pack that bag!” “Of course, sir.” Tommy pondered over the note. “Yes, I am a fool,” he muttered under his breath.

"Without a doubt, if it weren't for his clever use of the cheese, a habit he seemed completely oblivious to, I could have easily mistaken the man in front of me for a stranger. 'He's onto you,' I whispered. 'You shouldn't have shown up.' 'Oh, my dear Hastings, I've played dead for months just for this moment.' 'To catch Number Four off guard?' 'Exactly. To catch him when he least expects it. And the best part is, he has no idea we know who he is. He believes he's safe in his new identity. I owe a debt of gratitude to Flossie Monro for sharing that little detail with us."

Papa never cared for others' opinions. He lived detached from daily life, eating without concern for payment. His celebrity brought no money, only trouble when a reporter twisted his words. I longed for romance and adventure, envying Emily's suitors. My only excitement came from daydreams and the Kinema. Yet, a discovery in Rhodesia would soon bring real adventure to my doorstep. Papa was ecstatic about the find, convinced it was the ancestral form of the Neanderthal race. We had to leave at once to explore the area for more treasures.

Poirot's revelation left us stunned. It seemed that Mr. Davenheim, the famous financier, had orchestrated his own disappearance to avoid the consequences of his financial misdeeds. The evidence pointed to a carefully planned scheme involving the theft of jewels and the creation of a false identity. As Poirot calmly explained his theory, it became clear that Mr. Davenheim had outwitted us all, hiding in plain sight where no one would think to look - in a prison. This unexpected turn of events shed a new light on the case, leaving us in awe of Poirot's brilliant deductive skills.

That was an undeniable fact. An estate. Perhaps the origin of a noble bloodline. (Lost heir? Title contender?) Or maybe a charming dilapidated building. (Hidden riches?) Indeed, I was leaning towards the notion of hidden treasure. Enigmas always accompany hidden treasure. One step to the east, seven steps to the west, excavate one yard, descend twenty-two stairs. That type of concept. I could develop that later. The priority was to reach Kilmorden Castle promptly. I embarked on a calculated expedition from my quarters and came back loaded with research materials. _Who’s Who_, Whitaker, a Geographical Dictionary, a Compilation of Scottish Ancestral Dwellings, and a Publication on the British Isles. Moments slipped away.

Nadina, the famous Russian dancer, received praise from the audience in Paris. As she left the stage, the Manager greeted her warmly. Later, Count Sergius Paulovitch visited her and they spoke in English about espionage suspicions and the retiring 'Colonel.' The Count mentioned a fortune-teller's prophecy about the 'Colonel's' downfall involving a woman, which intrigued Nadina. She revealed her plan to go to London incognito, leaving everyone unaware of her departure.

"So, based on your knowledge, he didn't have any enemies, and you have no idea about any secrets that might have led to his murder?" "That's correct." "M. Stonor, have you ever come across the name Duveen in relation to M. Renauld?" "Duveen. Duveen." He pondered the name for a moment. "I don't believe so. Although it does ring a bell." "Are you familiar with a woman, a friend of M. Renauld's named Bella?" Once again, Mr. Stonor shook his head. "Bella Duveen? Is that her full name? It's strange! I feel like I've heard it before. But I can't recall the context at the moment."

“Visitors were not allowed below at that time, so, despite my apologies, Mademoiselle Cynthia’s co-worker had to retrieve it for me.” “Did you have an idea of what you would uncover?” “No, not entirely. Tuppence and her companions, Sir James and Julius, escorted Mrs. Vandemeyer to the door. Tuppence fumbled for the key before realizing she had it herself. After unlocking the door, a thought crossed her mind - what if the woman had escaped? Julius quickly dismissed the idea, but Sir James remained silent. Tuppence took a deep breath and stepped inside, relieved to see Mrs. Vandemeyer on the bed. Ignoring the lack of response from the woman, Tuppence set down a cup of tea and went to open the blinds.

Rayburn was taken aback by the sight of Guy Pagett. "Pagett," he mumbled in disbelief. Rayburn seemed shocked by the revelation, but I couldn't help feeling a bit smug. "You look like you've seen a ghost," I remarked. Rayburn's eyes narrowed. "What's your role in all this? How much have you figured out?" I flashed a knowing smile. "Let's just say I know more than you think, Rayburn." His grip on my arm tightened, his voice trembling as he demanded, "Where did you hear that name?"

”Oh, how fleeting these peaceful moments can be! The tranquility of my surroundings was abruptly interrupted by the unwelcome voice echoing through the hall. “Dr. Bauerstein!” Cynthia exclaimed with surprise. “What an unexpected visit.” My eyes involuntarily darted towards Mary Cavendish, but her composure remained unruffled, her complexion unchanged. Within minutes, Alfred Inglethorp had welcomed the doctor, who entered with a laugh, insisting he was in no state to be in a drawing-room. Indeed, he was a sight to behold, covered in mud from head to toe. “What on earth have you been up to, doctor?” Mrs. Cavendish inquired. “I must beg your forgiveness,” the doctor replied.

"Interesting case." "Possibly aphasia?" I proposed. The doctor scoffed immediately. "Aphasia! Aphasia! No such thing. A product of fiction. No; the man has experienced some form of trauma. He's here driven by a persistent urge to locate M. Hercule Poirot, 14 Farraway Street and mindlessly repeats those words." "Psychogenic amnesia?" I suggested hopefully. The doctor's reaction was less dismissive this time. Without a word, he handed the man a piece of paper and a pencil. "Let's observe his response," he commented.

"Poirot was the one to reveal the shocking truth to Jack Renauld, causing a tumultuous reaction. With his mother's support, Jack faced the reality of his father's criminal past. Poirot assured Jack that the truth would remain hidden from the world. Eventually, Jack decided to start a new life in South America with his mother and secretary. Poirot encouraged Jack to seek out the woman who loved him unconditionally, despite his father's history. Meanwhile, Captain Hastings contemplated joining the Renaulds on their new adventure. As Poirot and Hastings watched Miss Mary Marvell from the window, they realized she was simply being followed by adoring fans and not involved in any criminal drama."

Mother will be pleased when father finally passes away so she can wed Dr. Treves. She's not my real mother, you see. I can't stand her. She's just waiting for my father to kick the bucket." The situation was quite unsettling. Fortunately, Poirot didn't get a chance to respond before the doctor returned, forcing us to continue our conversation. Suddenly, Poirot slumped back in his seat, a pained expression on his face. "What's wrong?" exclaimed the doctor. "Just a sudden spasm. I'll be fine. I don't need your help, doctor. I just need to lie down for a bit."

"Ha!” exclaimed the inspector, slamming his hand onto the desk. “You dare play games with the authorities, do you? It was Madame Daubreuil.” The commissioner gasped in shock and leaned in closer. “Madame Daubreuil from the Villa Marguerite nearby?” “Exactly, sir,” Françoise confirmed.

"Would you care for some wine, mademoiselle? Perhaps some champagne?" Miss Monro remained silent, her thoughts a mystery. How I wish he were here with us." "Yes, indeed," sighed Miss Monro. "I often wonder where he has gone." "It has been quite some time since you last saw him, hasn't it?" "Oh, it's been ages, not since the war. Claudie was a peculiar boy, kept his secrets close to his chest, never revealing a thing about himself."

“Who was it that Madame Renauld loved so deeply that upon discovering his lifeless body, she succumbed to a faint?” I was taken aback. “Her spouse?” I uttered. "Anne, do you recall telling me that women often do things they dislike for someone they care about?" "Yes," I replied, curious about his intentions. He embraced me tightly. "Comme ça! A magnificent stone without a flaw," he exclaimed as he examined the jewel closely. "You will leave it with me, n’est-ce pas?" Miss Marvell explained her plan to visit Yardly Chase with the diamond, despite Poirot's suggestion against it. The conversation turned to the famous Star of the East diamond in the Yardly collection, sparking Poirot's interest. "Given his urgent demeanor, I promptly presented his card, identifying him as Mr. Roger Havering," she said, handing me the slip of paper. "I was clearly inebriated when I approached Race. Clearly. Mark my words, Pagett, let your bruised eye serve as a cautionary tale, abstain from excessive drinking in the future." “We need to locate him. However, I’ve been lost in thought ever since this journey began and these thoughts are unproductive. I’m done with them.
