"Do you young people prefer artificial lighting, or do you revel in the twilight?" she inquired. "Cynthia, would you be so kind as to deliver Mrs. Inglethorp her coffee? I shall handle the pouring." "No need to trouble yourself, Mary," Inglethorp interjected. "I will bring it to Emily." With a careful hand, he poured the coffee and exited the room. Lawrence trailed behind him, leaving Mrs. Cavendish to take a seat beside us. The three of us remained in silence for a while. The night was magnificent, warm and motionless. Mrs. Cavendish gently fanned herself with a palm leaf. "It almost feels stifling," she whispered. "A thunderstorm must be on its way."

John's composure in the witness stand was remarkable. With Sir Ernest's expert guidance, he recounted his story convincingly and confidently. The mysterious note he had received was presented to the jury for scrutiny. John's honesty about his financial struggles and his strained relationship with his stepmother added weight to his assertions. As he concluded his testimony, he made a firm declaration: "I want to be clear. I completely reject Sir Ernest Heavywether's accusations against my brother. I am certain that my brother is innocent, just as I am." Sir Ernest simply smiled, observing keenly that John's defense of his brother had made a positive impact on the jury.

I quickly ascended the stairs, my mind heavy with the weight of the tragedy. The room where the body was discovered was eerily silent, the only echo of the past being the muddy footprints left behind by the intruders. The police had already combed through the room, leaving nothing of interest in their wake. As I examined the plain white walls and bare floor, a glimmer of hope emerged when my pencil rolled under a window-seat cupboard. Retrieving it, my hand brushed against a forgotten roll of Kodak films. The fresh red paper hinted at a recent deposit, leading me to wonder who had dropped it - the woman or the man? The familiar scent of moth balls lingered on the films, igniting my suspicions once again.

"I wonder where his plan to deceive me will lead? A woman's hair, hmm!" The meal was satisfying, yet Poirot seemed preoccupied and distant. Later, in our room, I pressed him to share details of his enigmatic trip to Paris. "Of course, mon ami. I journeyed to Paris for this." He produced a faded newspaper clipping from his pocket, displaying a woman's photograph. I gasped. "You know her, my friend?" I nodded, recognizing the unmistakable likeness despite the dated style of the photo.

"He appeared slightly disoriented, but quickly regained his composure. 'Hey, Smith, I need a favor from you,' he said. 'Sure, what is it?' I replied. "The bonds were sold in New York, therefore they were not thrown overboard. Is there any evidence that the package did contain the bonds? The last moment that the bonds are seen as bonds is in the office of the London and Scottish Bank on the morning of the 23rd. All is clear, the case begins to explain itself. The sealed packet is only a dummy, and the moment of its substitution must be in the office in the Bank. The man on board in the cabin next door does his work, pretends to force the lock in an obvious manner so as to draw immediate attention to the theft. Ah, here we are. You permit?”

Curiosity isn’t a good trait for young boys. So, why are you here? Tagging along with the M.P., I presume, playing the carefree youth on the shore.” I disagreed. “Think again. Inglethorp herself!” “Impossible!” I exclaimed. “She had only made it out that very afternoon!” “Nevertheless, mon ami, it was Mrs. Inglethorp. Because, in no other way can you account for the fact that, on one of the hottest days of the year, Mrs. Inglethorp ordered a fire to be lighted in her room.” I gave a gasp. What idiots we had been never to think of that fire as being incongruous! Poirot was continuing: “The temperature on that day, messieurs, was 80 degrees in the shade. As they wandered along the outskirts, they encountered a laborer carrying a bag of tools. Tommy approached him, inquiring about the Moat House. The workman informed them that the house had been vacant for years and directed them to Mrs. Sweeny at the post office for the key. Expressing gratitude, they located the post office, a charming establishment that doubled as a sweet and general store. Knocking on the door of the neighboring cottage, a tidy and welcoming woman answered. Without hesitation, she handed over the key to the Moat House, cautioning Tommy about its poor condition. "Not sure if it's up to your standards, sir. The place is falling apart, with leaky ceilings and all."

M. Hautet bid us farewell, laughing heartily and enchanted with himself. Poirot, on the other hand, called him an old imbecile, showing his disdain. Just as we were leaving the building, we ran into Giraud, looking pleased with himself. Poirot hinted that the end of the case was near, but Giraud was dismissive. Poirot then challenged Giraud to a bet, claiming he would find the real murderer before him. Despite Giraud's initial reluctance, he finally agreed. As we walked, Poirot's determination was evident, causing me to doubt my ability to protect Bella. Suddenly, Gabriel Stonor joined us, expressing his belief in Jack Renauld's innocence. Stonor's words gave me hope in the midst of uncertainty.

"It's clear that you're suppressing your own intuition, denying the truth that lingers beneath the surface," Miss Howard protested with a sudden burst of emotion, waving her hands in distress. "Please, spare me. I can't bear to hear it. It's a lie! How could I even entertain such a horrifying notion?" Poirot inquired if his deductions were correct, to which Miss Howard reluctantly confirmed. "You have an uncanny ability to discern the truth. But it's inconceivable. It has to be Alfred Inglethorp," she reasoned. Poirot silently disagreed. "I can't discuss this further," Miss Howard declared firmly. "I refuse to acknowledge it, not even to myself. I must be insane to entertain such thoughts."

" Tuppence was on the verge of objecting, but as she shifted her gaze towards the bed, she noticed Mrs. Vandemeyer. Her eyes were only partially open, yet the look of sheer terror and malice etched on her face silenced Tuppence instantly. She questioned if the fainting spell and heart attack were all an elaborate act, but the ashen complexion of Mrs. Vandemeyer made that theory hard to believe. In an instant, the unsettling expression vanished, leaving Mrs. Vandemeyer lying still and lifeless once more. Tuppence briefly thought she had imagined it all, but resolved to stay vigilant nonetheless."

As I surveyed the room, it was clear that the boudoir had been neglected that morning. Traces of brown mould and earth surrounded the desk, indicating a recent disturbance. The weather had been uncharacteristically fine, ruling out the possibility of ordinary boots causing such a mess. Walking over to the window, I noticed the freshly planted begonia beds below. The mould in the beds matched the one in the boudoir, a detail you had informed me about - they were indeed planted the day before. It became evident that one, if not both, of the gardeners had trespassed into the boudoir, as evidenced by the distinct footprints in the bed.

"I've taken care of everything. Is Mrs. Blair bringing a maid?" "Mrs. Blair?" I exclaimed. "She said you offered her a spot." I must have, that one night. I even encouraged her to join. Never expected her to actually come though! Lovely as she is, I'm not sure I want to spend the entire trip to Rhodesia and back with Mrs. Blair. Women need so much attention. And they can be quite a bother at times. "Did I invite anyone else?" I asked anxiously. These things happen in moments of excitement. "Mrs. Blair thought you had also invited Colonel Race." I sighed.

"I kept a low profile, biding my time before seizing an opportunity. Luck finally intervened when I eavesdropped on a chat between two older men in the neighborhood, one of whom turned out to be Sir Eustace Pedler. That moment sparked an idea - I decided to insinuate myself into his circle as his personal assistant. The snippet of their conversation provided a vital clue. Doubt began to creep in regarding Sir Eustace Pedler's true identity as the 'Colonel.' Perhaps his residence was chosen as a meeting point by chance, or for a hidden agenda that eluded me."

"In Paris, I arrived with a mission," Jane Finn spoke softly but with determination. "I sailed on the Lusitania, eager to contribute to the war effort." The lawyer nodded, motioning for her to continue as he settled into the armchair across from her. Jane took a deep breath, ready to reveal everything she knew.

“Sorry, that’s not what I meant to say. If you're certain you've experienced the full range of emotions I provided, let's move on to our mail.” Tuppence grabbed the envelopes from him and examined them closely. “This one feels fancy. We'll save it for later and open the other first.” “Agreed. On three, go!” Tuppence tore open the envelope with her thumb and pulled out the contents. “DEAR SIR, “I saw your ad in the paper this morning and may be able to help you.

A man with a history of hunting lions in large numbers possesses an unfair advantage over his peers. It struck me that it was about time I shared a lion-related anecdote as well, albeit of a livelier nature. "Speaking of which," I interjected, "I recall a rather thrilling story I was told. A companion of mine was on a hunting expedition in East Africa. One evening, he exited his tent for a particular purpose and was taken aback by a faint growl. Upon a sudden turn, he found himself face to face with a lion ready to pounce. His firearm was left inside the tent. Acting swiftly, he dodged, causing the lion to leap over him. Irritated by the miss, the lion emitted a growl and readied itself for another leap."

Perhaps this lingering sense of urgency was a remnant of my time on short leave during the war. It had been crucial to claim a spot near the gangway and be among the first to disembark, ensuring no precious minutes of my three or five days' leave were wasted. Standing by the rail on a July morning, watching the white cliffs of Dover approach, I couldn't help but feel amazed by passengers who remained seated, not even glancing up at the sight of their homeland. But maybe their circumstances were unlike mine.

Upon arrival, I immediately noticed the absence of a laurel bush, leading me to believe that its name was simply a product of suburban whimsy. We were escorted inside by a stoic Chinese servant and introduced to the enigmatic Mr. Ingles. His sturdy frame and sallow complexion were overshadowed by his piercing, introspective eyes. As he rose to welcome us, he casually put down a letter he had been reading, only to pick it up again shortly after exchanging pleasantries.

The incident on the Underground, brushed off as mere chance, slipped from the public consciousness. But was it truly random? I harbored doubts. While the Tube mishap held a personal intrigue for me, there appeared to be a link between the two deaths. Both victims sported a sun-kissed complexion, indicating they were English expatriates, among other curious similarities. Intrigued by these peculiarities, I made a bold move. I marched into Scotland Yard, insisting on an audience with the lead investigator of the Mill House investigation.

"I've never seen anyone handle a situation like you did. You were truly remarkable," Jane shook her head, feeling exhausted and homesick. "I don't feel remarkable at all." The man continued, "I overheard the Ambassador inviting you to stay at the Embassy, but I have a different idea. Jane, I want you to marry me. I know it's sudden, but don't say no just yet. You may not love me now, but that can change over time."

"And the key detail, your unwavering faith in the existence of Achille Poirot! Your contribution was immeasurable, the success of our plan greatly owed to you! "But why not deploy a stand-in?" "And leave you to face danger alone? You underestimate me! Plus, I clung to the hope of a solution through the countess."

"The war was won by empty-headed young fools, unsettling me with their victory. Plans progressing smoothly until a meddling girl interfered without full knowledge. The 29th approaches rapidly, Mr. Carter hinted at details of the planned coup involving the three of us. Successfully disarmed the girl by luring her to me voluntarily."

"I must confess, Monsieur Poirot, that I have a rather pressing matter to discuss with you today," the young woman stated with a polite nod as she took her seat. "I assume you are familiar with the recent headlines regarding the theft of Liberty Bonds at the Olympia." Poirot's expression betrayed a hint of surprise, prompting her to elaborate without delay. "You may be wondering what a person like myself has to do with the esteemed London and Scottish Bank. The truth is, Monsieur Poirot, I am actually engaged to Mr. Philip Ridgeway." As the sun began to set, Harry's mood shifted suddenly. "You must leave here tomorrow," he exclaimed, his voice filled with urgency. "I can't bear any more. You must go, Anne. You're not a fool. You know yourself that this can't go on." Surprised by his outburst, I replied calmly, "I suppose not. But it's been happy, hasn't it?" Harry's face grew grim as he spoke of his past, revealing his true identity as Harry Lucas. His story was one of betrayal, theft, and loss, leaving us both haunted by the ghosts of our pasts. The shadows of our intertwined destinies darkened the doorway of the hut as we faced the harsh realities of our shared history.

John left me, and a few minutes later I caught sight of him through my window strolling leisurely across the lawn with Cynthia Murdoch by his side. Simultaneously, a figure emerged from the darkness of a nearby tree and proceeded in the same direction. This man appeared to be around forty years old, with a somber, clean-shaven face. A surge of intense emotion seemed to be consuming him. As he passed beneath my window, he glanced up, and despite the significant change in his appearance over the past fifteen years, I recognized him immediately. It was John's younger sibling, Lawrence Cavendish.

Despite the challenges ahead, I trusted in Poirot's abilities to uncover the truth and bring justice to those involved. As Lord Yardly and I stood in the dimly lit room, a sudden darkness enveloped us. Unsure if she was alive or dead, we hovered over her, waiting for any sign of life. Slowly, her eyes fluttered open, revealing the fear and pain hidden within.

"Don't worry," he said softly, "you're safe. There has been an incident." Panic gripped me as I whispered, "Poirot?" Dr. Ridgeway's eyes met mine, and with a solemn expression, he revealed the truth I dreaded to hear about our dear friend Poirot.

As I strolled through the expansive villa, surrounded by rows of captivating books and picturesque landscapes, I couldn't help but feel restless at the stagnant pace of our days. The unexpected arrival of a car disrupted our quiet reverie, prompting me to hasten downstairs in search of answers. There, I discovered Poirot engaged in conversation with a charming young man, not much older than myself. He proceeded to make the introductions.

The farm was not prosperous, leading the older brother, Andrew, to move to Australia where he found success through land speculation, eventually becoming wealthy. The younger brother, Roger (my father), had no interest in farming and instead worked as a clerk after some self-education. He married up, to my mother, the daughter of a struggling artist. My father passed when I was six, and my mother followed when I was fourteen, leaving my Uncle Andrew as the only family I had left. He had just come back from Australia and purchased Crabtree Manor in our home county.

A big sedan is parked on the deserted street, looking like it's having mechanical issues. The driver waves for O’Murphy to pull over. As O’Murphy decelerates, the stranger comes closer. Daniels sticks his head out of the window, and, likely using a fast-acting anesthetic like ethyl chloride, executes the chloroform scheme once more. Upon meeting Evelyn Howard, a sense of security enveloped the atmosphere. However, that feeling quickly dissipated, leaving behind an unsettling air of suspicion. Dr. Bauerstein's sinister visage haunted my thoughts, casting a shadow of doubt over everyone and everything. A foreboding of impending evil gripped me momentarily. My arrival at Styles occurred on July 5th, leading up to the events of the 16th and 17th of the same month. To aid the reader, I shall now recount those incidents with precision and detail.

The man identified as L. B. Carton from Kimberley, South Africa had arrived at the hotel the day before and booked a room. He seemed to have come straight off the steamer. I was the only witness to the incident. The coroner questioned me, asking if I thought it was an accident. I was certain it was. The man appeared to have been startled by something, causing him to step back unintentionally. When asked what could have alarmed him, I couldn't say for sure. But he did seem terrified, almost panicked. One juryman casually suggested that the man may have been scared of cats, possibly having seen one.

We caught Dr. Bernard during his consulting hour, with no patients in queue at that moment. Dr. Bernard, an elderly man with a slight stoop and genial demeanor, welcomed us. He showed me the modest home he shared with his Belgian colleagues, inviting me to visit him soon.

“Last time we met,” I began, “you were walking back with your sister, such a well-behaved child. Speaking of which, how is she doing?” A gleaming smile was my answer. “Thank you for asking! I turned away in disgust at the girl's ghoulish excitement. It made me wonder about the modern woman's obsession with morbid sensation. Despite her beauty, I couldn't shake my disapproval. The lady challenged me, saying women are no longer the delicate creatures of the past. She convinced me to show her around, hinting at the possibility of a big scoop for the papers. I hesitated, but her soft hand in mine was my undoing. We went first to where the body was found, then cautiously approached the Villa. I led her to the back where the shed was located, hoping to avoid any unwanted encounters. I left her hidden in the shrubbery as I entered the house, the voices inside growing louder.

"There should be a nearby village," the young American suggested. "Let's ask around there. Surely someone will have information about this place and if it's been occupied recently." "Agreed, let's do that." Walking up the road, they soon reached a small cluster of houses.

Lord Yardly was shocked to see the diamond known as "The Star of the East." Poirot assured him that it was necessary for the diamond to be stolen in order to preserve it. But Boris could contain his rage no longer. He lunged forward, arms flailing.   "You despicable spy!" he bellowed.

With quivering hands, they carefully unfolded the mysterious sheet. To their surprise, it was completely empty! Looking at each other in bewilderment, Julius hesitantly suggested, "A decoy, perhaps?" But Tommy was not convinced. Then, a spark of realization hit Tommy, "I know! Invisible ink!" "Do you really think so?" asked Julius skeptically. "It's worth a shot. Heat usually reveals it. Let's start a fire." Within moments, a small fire was crackling with twigs and leaves. Tommy cautiously approached the paper to the flames. As the paper began to slightly curl from the heat, they both held their breath. Suddenly, Julius grabbed Tommy's arm, pointing to faint brown characters slowly emerging. "Wow! It worked! Your idea was brilliant."

Renauld will fly to Paris, where he will lie low until the time comes for him to join his wife in a foreign country under assumed names. Despite being well preserved, she was no longer young, yet her charm transcended age. Dressed in black with fresh white collar and cuffs, hands clasped together, she appeared appealing and helpless. "You wanted to see me, sir?" she inquired. "Indeed, madam," responded Mr. Hautet, clearing his throat.

"Isn’t it true that women worship strength, almost like ancestor worship?” “It’s quite true if we’re honest. You may think you admire moral qualities, but when you fall in love, it’s the physical that matters. Living in primitive conditions would make it acceptable, but that’s not the case. In the end, the other side triumphs. The things that seem defeated always prevail in the end, don’t they? They win in the most important way. It’s like what the Bible says about losing your soul and then discovering it."

"On the evening of his release, Halliday was put up in the room adjacent to ours in the hotel. Throughout the night, his restless murmurs echoed through the walls, evidence of the trauma he had endured at the villa. Despite our attempts the next morning, he remained tight-lipped, only hinting at the immense power wielded by the notorious Big Four and the dire consequences of revealing their secrets. Halliday left for England after lunch to reunite with his wife, leaving Poirot and myself in Paris. While I advocated for swift and forceful action, Poirot's calm demeanor grated on my nerves."

"I'll get the scoop from my contact in Livingstone about the hotel and your pals' whereabouts,” I assured her. “Beira,” I muttered. “That's your destination, Anne. Let me handle this.” Our conversation had provided a brief break from the intensity of the situation, but tension swiftly returned. Without exchanging glances, we reached a silent agreement. “Fine,” I replied, retreating into the hut. Resting on the animal-hide sofa, sleep eluded me as I listened to Harry Rayburn's restless steps outside throughout the night.

We bid you goodnight, Monsieur Poirot. I see the wheels turning in your mind," Poirot smiled. "I would be happy to join you. Hastings, go fetch a taxi," he said. Taxis always seem scarce when you're in a hurry, but we managed to find one and headed towards Regent's Park. Regent's Court, a modern apartment building near St. John's Wood Road, was our destination. The building was equipped with all the latest technology. The hallway was empty. The doctor impatiently rang the bell for the lift, and when it arrived, he interrogated the attendant about the location of Flat II.

In all of France, there exists only one individual who can identify him. This fact represents a lucrative opportunity for Madame Daubreuil, one that she exploits without hesitation. She holds complete power over him and extracts a significant amount of money from him. Eventually, the expected outcome occurs. Jack Renauld develops feelings for the lovely young lady he encounters regularly and desires to wed her. This decision sparks a reaction from his father, who is determined to stop his son from marrying the offspring of this wicked woman. While Jack Renauld remains unaware of his father's history, Madame Renauld possesses full knowledge of the past.

Upon showing Ridgeway’s card, we were escorted through a maze of counters and desks, maneuvering around clerks both taking and giving money, until we reached a small office on the second floor where we were greeted by the joint general managers. These two men were serious individuals, their years of service evident in their grey hair. One of them, Mr. Vavasour, sported a short white beard while the other, Mr. Shaw, was cleanly shaven. “I hear you specialize in discreet inquiries,” remarked Mr. Vavasour. “That is correct. We are also working closely with Scotland Yard on this matter. Inspector McNeil is overseeing the investigation, a highly skilled detective, as I understand it.”

In the small, sealed room with a heavy, soundproof door, he was completely isolated. No matter how loudly he yelled, no one would come to his aid. It felt like a tomb. Tommy forced himself to focus, sitting on the bed to collect his thoughts. His hunger and headache were overwhelming in the oppressive silence. "At least," he thought, "I'll come face to face with the notorious Mr. Brown and maybe even the elusive Jane Finn."

Inglethorp’s bell wire had been expertly severed, leading to a critical discovery. Mademoiselle Cynthia had made plans to stay with friends on Monday evening, leaving Mrs. Inglethorp isolated in the right wing of the estate. With no one to turn to for help, Mrs. Inglethorp's fate seemed sealed. However, an unexpected twist unfolded. Due to Mrs. Inglethorp's eagerness to attend the village entertainment, she neglected to take her medicine. The following day, she dined out, unknowingly delaying the fatal dose by a full twenty-four hours. This unforeseen turn of events proved to be the undoing of the murderer, as the final piece of evidence fell into the detective's possession.

"Mr. Davenheim was known to be out sending a letter, leaving him alone in the study!" "Perhaps he took advantage of the situation," I proposed. "But how about the tools? It's not common for city dwellers to carry burglary tools just in case! And it would be impossible to break into that safe with just a pocket knife, of course!" "What about Suspect Two?" "You mentioned that Lowen harbored resentment towards Mr. Davenheim. What you're really saying is that he had outsmarted him once or twice. And presumably, those dealings were done to benefit himself. Typically, you don't hold a grudge against someone you've outsmarted - it's usually the other way around."

Colonel Race signaled with his hand. Arthur Minks, also known as the Rev. Edward Chichester and Miss Pettigrew, hesitantly stepped forward. Despite his pallor and nervous demeanor, he recounted, “I encountered Nadina in Paris the evening prior to her departure for England. At that time, I was assuming the identity of a Russian Count. She confided in me about her intentions. Although I cautioned her against it, fully aware of the individual she was dealing with, she disregarded my warning. A wireless message lay on the nearby table, which I proceeded to peruse. Subsequently, I contemplated making an attempt for the diamonds myself. However, in Johannesburg, I was approached by Mr. Rayburn."

"The birds have escaped just as we suspected. Let's investigate further." Exploring the abandoned residence felt surreal to Tommy. All the familiar details remained unchanged - the disorderly prison room, the shattered jug in the attic, the spacious meeting area with its extended table. However, any documents had vanished, presumably either eradicated or removed. Annette was nowhere to be found. "Your account of the young woman has left me perplexed," Mr. Carter remarked.

"I forgot that you didn’t know about Tuppence,” said Sir James quietly. The lawyer tapped the table thoughtfully. Something in his voice made Tommy look up, wondering if this man had seen something they had missed. “I wish you’d been there, sir, to go over the house,” Tommy spoke impulsively. Sir James sat in silence for a moment before asking, “And since then? What have you been doing?” Tommy realized the lawyer was unaware of the situation and slowly explained.

"A clandestine rendezvous for instructions!" "Do not hiss in my direction, Pagett," I remarked, taking a step back, "and please regulate your breath. Your suggestion is preposterous. What reason would they have for arranging a covert meeting in the dead of night? If they had anything to discuss, they could easily converse over a cup of tea in a nonchalant and ordinary manner." Despite my arguments, it was clear that Pagett remained unconvinced. "Something definitely occurred last night, Sir Eustace," he insisted, "otherwise why would Rayburn viciously attack me." "You are positive it was Rayburn?" Pagett seemed entirely certain of that detail. It was the one aspect of his account that lacked ambiguity.

“I love you? How is that possible, given everything you know about me?” “I'm not sure,” I replied, feeling a sense of exhaustion wash over me. “Love is a force beyond control. I've attempted to resist it from the moment we first crossed paths. But love, it seems, is more powerful than my will.” Unexpectedly, she collapsed to the ground once more, consumed by uncontrollable sobs. “I can't go on like this!” she wailed. “I'm lost, with no direction. Please, someone, have mercy on me and show me the way!” Once again, I knelt beside her, offering what comfort I could muster.

"Came up against a brick wall at the entrance, but that stubborn French gendarme was not budging. Even if I brought out Helen of Troy, Cleopatra, and Mary, Queen of Scots all at once, it wouldn’t make a difference to him! It’s a stroke of luck running into you like this. Come on, give me the grand tour.” “Hold on a second, I can’t do that. It’s off limits to everyone. They enforce the rules strictly.” “Aren’t you two big shots?” I was reluctant to let go of my sense of importance. “What’s driving your curiosity?” I asked hesitantly. “And what exactly do you want to see.”

"Could there really be two girls with a name like that?" pondered Tuppence. Mr. Whittington slammed his fist on the desk. "Quit playing games! What's your price for the information?" The mention of money caught Tuppence's attention, especially after a meager breakfast and a supper of buns the night before. Though her current role was more of an adventuress than an adventurer, she couldn't ignore the potential opportunities.

"Looks like he made a bet in the servants' quarters that he could pass for the old man in front of you, Captain Hastings, and would give him a bunch of espionage details about a Big Four gang." "No way!" I exclaimed. "Believe it or not. I escorted our gentleman directly to Hatton Chase, and the real Ryland was there in bed and fast asleep, with the butler, the cook, and who knows how many others willing to confirm the bet. Just a foolish prank, nothing more, and his valet is with him." "So that explains why he stayed hidden," whispered Poirot. After Japp left, we exchanged glances. "We understand, Hastings," Poirot finally said. "Abe Ryland is Number Two of the Big Four."

As I finally managed to free myself from the tangle of limbs, my target had already slipped through the doorway. A waiter, burdened with a tower of plates, collided with me unexpectedly, causing yet another obstacle in my pursuit. When I reached the exit, the slender man with the dark beard had vanished without a trace. Despite the waiter's profuse apologies and the composed demeanor of the overweight man at the nearby table, I couldn't shake the feeling that these incidents were anything but accidental. The presence of the Big Four's operatives lurked in every shadow, yet I chose to ignore the cautionary signs that were undoubtedly placed in my path.

"Excuse me, but could you please unlock Mr. Opalsen's room for me?" Poirot asked the chambermaid. She led the way to the room, unlocking it with her pass-key. Poirot showed her a card, asking if she had seen it before, but she hadn't. Poirot then asked the valet the same question, with no luck. As Poirot prepared to leave for London, he asked Hastings to brush off some French chalk powder from his coat sleeve. The next day, Poirot revealed that the chambermaid and valet were the culprits behind the theft of the necklace, using a clever plan involving the French chalk.

"I have only two more days left with the radium, sir. My experiments will be complete by then," the woman said.  Poirot's eyes lit up. "And Inez Veroneau is informed of this? Excellent, our associates will return. Not a word about me to anyone, madam. Rest assured, I will safeguard your radium. Do you possess a key to the door connecting the laboratory to the garden?"  "Yes, sir. Here it is. I have a spare for myself. Additionally, here is the key to the garden door that opens into the alleyway between this villa and the adjacent one."  "Thank you, madam.

Tuppence took a brief moment to appreciate her own cleverness before replying gently, "I wouldn't want to argue with you, Mr. Whittington." "So, the question as always, how much?" Tuppence found herself in a difficult position. She had managed to deceive Whittington so far, but suggesting an obviously unrealistic amount might raise his suspicions. Suddenly, an idea came to her. "What if we agree on a small initial payment, with a more detailed discussion to follow?" Whittington shot her a menacing look. "Is this blackmail?" Tuppence responded with a charming smile. "Oh, no! How about we consider it payment for future services?" Whittington grunted in response.

"I let out a breath of relief. "You'll send it right away?" I pressed. He grinned and shook his head. "It will be sent when M. Hercule Poirot is within my grasp. Not a moment sooner." "But you gave your word." "Should this plan falter, I might have to rely on our little persuasion bird to motivate you further." Rage washed over me. "Dear God! If you " He waved a lengthy, slender yellow hand. "Rest assured, I have faith it will not fail. And once M. Poirot is in our possession, I will uphold my promise." "If you betray me." "I've sworn on the honor of my ancestors. You have nothing to fear. Take a break here. My staff will attend to your needs while I'm away." I found myself alone in this opulent subterranean sanctuary."

“There’s a rather impressive collection in that room. Do they see much use?” “Not so much these days, though occasionally we host what the boys refer to as a ‘fancy dress night.’ Quite amusing, if I may say so. Mr. Lawrence, in particular, is a riot. Utterly hilarious! I still recall the evening he appeared as the Shah of Persia, or something of the sort. A regal Eastern monarch, he claimed. He wielded a large letter opener and warned, ‘Dorcas, mind your manners and show proper respect.’”

"Race, please, share with us the details," he prompted. "Of course, I will divulge the tale. I'm sure you are all familiar with Sir Laurence Eardsley, the prominent South African tycoon? Although his wealth stemmed from gold mines, his son is the focus of this narrative. Prior to the War, rumors circulated about a potential new Kimberley hidden in the rocky terrain of the British Guiana rainforest. According to reports, two daring explorers had recently journeyed back from that region of South America, showcasing an extraordinary assortment of uncut diamonds, including some notably large ones."

"They don’t want to discourage me altogether. On the other hand, they don’t want to make it too easy. I’m a pawn in their game, Albert, that’s what I am. You see, if the spider lets the fly walk out too easily, the fly might suspect it was a put-up job. Hence the usefulness of that promising youth, Mr. T. Beresford, who’s blundered in just at the right moment for them. But later, Mr. T. Beresford had better look out!” Tommy retired for the night in a state of some elation. He had elaborated a careful plan for the following evening.

“Absolutely the hand of Mr. Brown!” Mr. Carter declared, taking a moment to pause. “You see what you are up against? Likely the most brilliant criminal mind of our time. It’s a concern, you know. You’re both so young. I would hate for anything to happen to you.” “We’ll be fine,” Tuppence insisted confidently. “I’ll watch out for her,” Tommy added. “And I’ll watch out for you,” Tuppence shot back, bristling at the protective tone. “Well, then, watch out for each other,” Mr. Carter suggested with a smile. “Now, let’s refocus on the matter at hand. There’s a hidden aspect to this treaty that we have yet to uncover.”

"I have an elderly uncle who's quite well-off, but he's no good," Tommy explained. "He once tried to adopt me, but I turned him down." Tuppence recalled, "I think I heard about that. You declined because of your mother." Tommy blushed. "Yes, it wouldn't have been fair to her. She was all I had. The old man despised her and wanted me away from her. Pure malice." "Your mother has passed away, right?" Tuppence asked softly. Tommy confirmed with a nod, causing Tuppence's eyes to glisten with emotion.

"I believe we can ease her distress. Shall we ascend?” “Of course.” Tommy’s heart raced as they accompanied the doctor upstairs. Jane Finn finally! The sought-after, the enigmatic, the elusive Jane Finn! Success had seemed so unlikely! And here in this residence, her memory nearly miraculously restored, lay the girl who held England's fate in her hands. Tommy let out a half sigh. If only Tuppence could have been there with him to witness the triumphant end of their shared endeavor! But he pushed thoughts of Tuppence away. His trust in Sir James was strengthening. He was a man who would surely uncover Tuppence’s location.

"I wanted to ask how you knew about those two?" "My friend, I understand human nature. When you combine a young boy like Renauld with a beautiful girl like Mademoiselle Marthe, the outcome is almost certain. And then, the argument! It was either money or a woman, and recalling Léonie's account of the boy's rage, I deduced the latter. So I took a chance and I was correct." "So that's why you cautioned me against falling for the lady? You already suspected that she had feelings for young Renauld?" Poirot grinned. "At least I noticed that she had worried eyes."

"For example, if the killers sought revenge, why not simply stab Renauld while he slept and be done with it?" "They were after the 'secret'," I pointed out. Poirot flicked a speck of dust off his coat sleeve with a dissatisfied expression. "But where is this 'secret'? It must be some distance away, as they made him get dressed. Yet his body was discovered murdered nearby, almost within earshot of the house. Furthermore, it seems too convenient for a weapon like the dagger to be casually lying around, easily accessible."

"I have secured them and, in my view, it is best to keep them locked up for now." The physicians left soon after. An idea had been brewing in my mind, and I sensed that the time was ripe to introduce it. However, I hesitated a bit. Knowing John's aversion to any form of attention and his laid-back outlook on life, I was unsure of how he would react. Convincing him of the validity of my proposal might prove to be challenging. On the contrary, Lawrence, with his unconventional nature and vivid imagination, seemed like a potential ally. It was evident that the moment had arrived for me to take charge.

I saw that I would be intercepted before reaching the platform I sought. Glancing at the clock, it showed one minute until eleven. If my scheme worked, I could pull it off. I had used the main entrance on Adderly Street to access the station. Now, I swiftly exited through a side door. Across from me stood the post office's side entrance, the primary one being on Adderly Street. As predicted, instead of pursuing me inside, my pursuer ran down the street to intercept me at the main entrance, or to signal the policeman to do so.

As we were still reeling from the doctor's bombshell, a telegram arrived at the Villa. It was a message from Poirot, informing me of his imminent return on the 12:28 train to Merlinville. With a quick glance at my watch, I realized I had just enough time to reach the station and greet him. It was crucial that Poirot be briefed on the latest shocking turn of events in the investigation. Clearly, he had wasted no time in obtaining the information he sought in Paris.

A large, faded chintz-covered settee was placed against the wall, while the window seats were also covered in the same pattern. Poirot, with his tiny cigarette, emphasized the need to carefully search the room for clues, especially in the desk. The key to the desk had a dirty envelope with a handwritten label, which Poirot found suspicious. The Bakers, sympathetic to Miss Violet, recalled the events surrounding the will signing. Poirot's investigation led to the discovery of a hiding place created by workmen from Plymouth, where a cavity was made beneath a brick in the fireplace. The cavity revealed crucial evidence, and Poirot wasted no time in examining it further.

"I remember the purser assuring me that cabin." "Pursers are always so preoccupied, don't you think?" I replied vaguely. "They're bound to overlook things from time to time." Mr. Chichester remained silent. "Is this your initial journey to Africa?" I asked casually. "To South Africa, yes. However, I've spent the past couple of years among the cannibal tribes in the heart of East Africa." "How exciting! Have you encountered many close calls?" "Close calls?" "Of being devoured, I mean?" "You shouldn't joke about such serious matters, Miss Beddingfeld."

Who is he? His identity remains a mystery. What does he look like? That remains unknown as well. How many times have we crossed paths with him? Five encounters, if memory serves me right. But can either of us confidently claim that we could identify him if we were to see him again? I pondered over the five distinct individuals who, inexplicably, turned out to be the same person. The stout keeper of the asylum, the man with the buttoned overcoat in Paris, James the footman, the reserved young doctor involved in the Yellow Jasmine case, and the enigmatic Russian Professor. None of them bore any resemblance to one another. "No," I admitted, feeling defeated.

I struck up a conversation with Mr. Chichester, hoping to glean some information. He mentioned his time in Africa, but I couldn't help but notice his lack of sunburn. As he fumbled with a piece of paper, claiming it was part of a sermon, my suspicions grew. Later, during a conversation about Italy, Mr. Pagett seemed uneasy and quickly excused himself. Sir Eustace joked about his secretary possibly committing a dark deed in Florence. Despite his respectable appearance, the idea lingered in the air. As the group dispersed, Mr. Chichester's clumsy action caught my attention once again. Colonel Race then approached me, commenting on my elusive nature at the previous night's dance. We discussed plans for the evening, hinting at a dance together.

"And you were correct." I gazed helplessly at Poirot, and he acknowledged my look. "My dear Hastings is, as you Brits say, enjoying the seaside. Have a seat, and I will detail the entire case that has concluded so satisfactorily." "Concluded?" "Indeed. They have been apprehended." "Who has been apprehended?" "The chambermaid and the valet, of course! Did you not suspect? Especially after my mention of French chalk?" "You mentioned it was used by cabinet-makers." "Indeed, to help drawers slide smoothly. Someone wanted that drawer to move in silence. Who else but the chambermaid? The plan was so clever that it eluded even Hercule Poirot at first glance."

"Without fail, Poirot's intuition proved correct. Soon after, the famous American movie star entered the room, prompting us to stand up in respect. Mary Marvell was undeniably one of the most beloved actresses in Hollywood. She had recently arrived in England with her husband, Gregory B. Rolf, who was also a well-known actor. Their wedding had occurred just a year earlier in the United States, marking their inaugural trip to England. The couple had been warmly welcomed by the public. Mary Marvell's stunning attire, luxurious furs, and exquisite jewelry, particularly a diamond known as "the Western Star," had captivated everyone's attention."

"I can't wait to ditch him in Cape Town," she said. "He's staying?" "Yes, he'll have a blast playing detective after Rayburn. It's right up Pagett's alley. He loves a good mystery. But I'm serious about my invitation. Will you join us? Mrs. Blair will be there to chaperone, and you can take breaks to explore." "Thank you, Sir Eustace," I replied, "but I think I'm heading to Durban tonight." "Don't be stubborn. Remember, there are plenty of lions in Rhodesia. You'll enjoy the lions."

"Mrs. Davenheim is a rather unintelligent woman, a nonentity," pondered Poirot. "Had he any enemies?" "Plenty of financial rivals," replied Hastings. "A figure was seen near the rose-garden," mentioned Hastings. "Beyond lies a lake with a boathouse," added Hastings. Japp walked in bursting with news. "We found his clothes, identical to what he wore that day," announced Japp. "Lowen was seen near the study," continued Japp. "Mr. Davenheim's ring was pawned by Billy Kellett," Japp explained. "Kellett saw a man with a big moustache," shared Japp.

“That's Dr. Bauerstein,” John remarked tersely. “And who might Dr. Bauerstein be?” “He's a London specialist, staying in the village for a rest cure following a severe nervous breakdown. He's renowned for his expertise in poisons, one of the foremost authorities in the field, I hear.” “And he happens to be a close friend of Mary's,” Cynthia added with her usual enthusiasm. John Cavendish furrowed his brow and shifted the conversation. “Care to take a walk, Hastings? This entire ordeal has been utterly dreadful. Evelyn Howard may have had a sharp tongue, but she was an unwavering friend.” With that, he led the way through the plantation, and we made our way to the village, traversing the woods that lined the estate.

I detest the idea of being hungry, though I am not concerned for my safety. Smuts will handle the revolution capably. But oh, how I long for a drink! I wonder if Pagett will remember to bring a bottle of whisky when he comes tomorrow? I threw on my hat and headed out, planning to purchase a few souvenirs. The curio shops in Jo’burg are quite charming. While examining a window full of luxurious karosses, a man exiting the shop bumped into me. To my surprise, it was Race. He didn't seem pleased to see me, but I insisted he accompany me back to the hotel. I tire of only having Miss Pettigrew to converse with. "I had no clue you were in Jo’burg," I said conversationally. "When did you arrive?"

After listing off dates, prices, and names of unfamiliar places, they finally finished checking and counting. "Excellent," declared Chichester, the scraping of his chair indicating his departure. "I will bring these to show the 'Colonel'." "When are you leaving?" "Ten o'clock tomorrow morning works for me." "Do you wish to visit the girl before your departure?" "No. It's strictly forbidden for anyone to see her until the 'Colonel' arrives. Is she doing well?" "I peeked in on her during dinner. I believe she was fast asleep."

"They're a dangerous group, Annette. If you assist me, I can remove you from their influence. And you might receive a substantial sum of money." But the young woman simply shook her head. "I cannot, sir; I am terrified of them." She turned away. "Wouldn't you do anything to help a fellow woman?" pleaded Tommy. "She's around your age as well. Will you not rescue her from their grasp?" "You're referring to Jane Finn?" "Indeed." "It's her you're searching for here? Right?" "Precisely." The woman gazed at him, then brushed her hand over her brow. "Jane Finn. That name is always in my ears. It sounds familiar."

Poirot, the one and only Hercule Poirot, was found dead! The match-box, purposefully disarranged, was a clever trap that would surely grab his attention, causing him to rearrange it and unknowingly trigger an explosion. Despite the fact that I was the one who set off the chain of events, I couldn't shake the overwhelming sense of guilt. According to Doctor Ridgeway, it was nothing short of a miracle that I survived with just a minor head injury. Even though it felt like I regained consciousness right away, it took a full day before I fully came to.

Lord Estair was visibly shaken as he entered Poirot's office. "I have come to consult you upon a matter of the most vital urgency. I must ask for absolute secrecy," he said. Poirot assured him, "You have the word of Hercule Poirot I can say no more!" Lord Estair then revealed the shocking news - the Prime Minister had been kidnapped just before the crucial Allied Conference. As Poirot delved deeper into the details, it became clear that time was of the essence. The race was on to rescue the Prime Minister before the conference began the following evening. The situation was dire, the stakes were high, and Poirot knew that failure was not an option.

Poirot examined the crime scene meticulously, his attention caught by a piece of lead-piping near the spade. Giraud dismissed it as irrelevant, but Poirot's curiosity was piqued. He then proceeded to explore the locked shed, much to Giraud's annoyance. The detective seemed focused on trivial details, such as a whitewashed line around the grave, which he questioned M. Bex about. Despite Poirot's unconventional methods, Giraud was impressed by his efficiency. As they left the scene, Giraud continued his thorough search, while Poirot hinted at a deeper mystery surrounding the case.

"Perhaps if the ring were found nearby, one could argue that Davenheim himself had accidentally dropped it," Japp suggested. "But why bother removing it from the body at all?" I exclaimed. "There could be a specific reason for that," Japp replied. "Did you know that just past the lake, there's a small gate that leads to the hill? And within a three-minute walk, you'll find what? A lime kiln.""Goodness!" I gasped. "So you're saying that the lime used to dispose of the body wouldn't harm the metal of the ring?""Exactly," Japp confirmed. "It appears to me," I remarked, "that this clarifies everything. What a ghastly crime!" Without a word, we both turned to Poirot.

"There was a piece of evidence in the case, seemingly insignificant but enough to link the killer to the crime. It was crucial for the killer to destroy it before it was uncovered and its importance recognized. That's why he decided to take the dangerous step of breaking into the place. However, the case was locked, forcing him to break it open and reveal his presence. The fact that he was willing to take such a risk indicated that the evidence was of significant value." "But what could it have been?" "Ah!" exclaimed Poirot, showing frustration."

Poirot hesitated, gazing towards the building, as the young boy eagerly chatted beside him, gesturing. The moment had arrived for me to take action. I stepped into the corridor. With a subtle signal from the towering Chinaman, a servant unlocked the entrance. "Don't forget the consequences of failure," my adversary whispered quietly. Outside, I stood on the staircase, motioning for Poirot to join me. He hurried over. "Ah! I see you are unharmed, my dear friend. I was starting to worry. Were you able to gain entry? Is the residence deserted?" "Indeed," I replied, striving to keep my tone casual.

In the cozy study, we found a charming couple - the man with a weathered face resembling a withered apple, and his wife exuding a sense of calm with her ample frame. Exhausted from the journey and the long drive, we had quickly retired to bed after a delicious meal of roast chicken, apple pie, and thick Devonshire cream. After a satisfying breakfast, we gathered in the small, wood-paneled room that once belonged to the late Mr. Marsh. A roll-top desk, meticulously organized with papers, adorned one wall, while a large leather armchair, clearly the favorite spot of its former owner, sat prominently in the room.

"Not in here," Tuppence pointed out, gesturing towards the tantalus in the dining-room. "Second door on the left down the hall." Together, Sir James and Tuppence carefully moved Mrs. Vandemeyer and laid her onto the bed. They attempted to revive her by splashing water on her face, but saw no immediate response. The lawyer checked her pulse. "It's touch and go," he murmured. "I hope that young man brings the brandy soon." Just then, Julius came back into the room with a glass of brandy, handing it to Sir James. Tuppence lifted Mrs. Vandemeyer's head while the lawyer tried to get her to drink a little of the brandy. Finally, the woman weakly opened her eyes.

All these notions raced through her mind in an instant, revealing a slim chance, albeit a risky one, that she could seize upon. Without hesitation, she staggered off the couch and dropped to her knees in front of Mrs. Vandemeyer, grabbing at her dress desperately. “I refuse to believe it,” she cried. “It must be poison, I'm certain of it. Please, spare me from drinking it” her tone escalated to a scream “spare me!” Mrs. Vandemeyer, holding a glass, peered down with a sneer at the sudden breakdown. “Get up, you foolish girl! Stop babbling nonsense."

He knew that maintaining the charade of a chess match was futile. Desperate to evade the inevitable showdown, he made every effort to deter Wilson. But when his attempts proved fruitless, Wilson's fate was sealed. It was imperative that Wilson never uncovered the truth - the renowned Savaronoff was utterly clueless when it came to chess. Aware of Wilson's preference for the Ruy Lopez opening, Number Four orchestrated a fatal strike by the third move, before any defensive strategies could be employed.

"Obviously,” Giraud began, “I quickly uncovered the true nature of that Chilian deception. Two individuals were involved, but they were not enigmatic foreigners! It was all a smokescreen.” “Impressive work so far, my dear Giraud,” Poirot murmured. “Especially after their clever ploy with the match and cigarette butt.” Giraud glared, then continued: “Someone must have been implicated in the crime to have dug the grave. No one actually gains from the crime, but someone believed they would. I learned of Jack Renauld’s dispute with his father, and the threats he made. The motive was clear.”

“Tell me, did you let Madame Daubreuil into the house last night?” “No, sir, it was the night before.” “But Françoise just said Madame Daubreuil was here last night?” “No, sir. A woman did visit Mr. Renauld last night, but it wasn't Madame Daubreuil.” The magistrate pressed further, but the girl was adamant. She was positive it wasn't Madame Daubreuil. This woman was dark, but shorter and much younger. Her identification was unwavering. “Had you ever seen her before?” “Never, sir.” Then, the girl hesitated and added: “But I believe she was English.”

Madame Daubreuil and her daughter were an intriguing pair. The daughter, innocent and pure, caught in the web of her mother's secrets. Madame Daubreuil, charming and enigmatic, with a past shrouded in mystery. As the examining magistrate probed for answers, the tension in the room grew palpable. The daughter's loyalty to her mother unwavering, while Madame Daubreuil's composure never faltered. The air was thick with unspoken truths and hidden motives. It was clear that beneath their facade of civility, lurked a darkness waiting to be revealed.

"Indeed," Poirot remarked with a hint of disdain. "Even in Santiago, they possess that knowledge. Even the most inexperienced English Miss is aware of it, thanks to the extensive publicity the Bertillon system has received in the media. Nevertheless, the absence of finger-prints intrigues me greatly. It is astonishingly simple to plant another person's prints. And the authorities are satisfied." He sighed. "I suspect our culprit lacks a systematic approach, or perhaps was rushed. Time will tell." With that, he gently returned the body to its initial pose.

Rayburn was crouched next to the man sprawled out near the saloon entrance. I rushed over, out of breath, and asked, "Did you have to hit him?" Rayburn's response was cold, "No need. He was already like this when I found him. Or maybe he's faking. Let's find out who he is." Anxious, I edged closer. It was clear that the man who attacked me was much larger than Chichester. Unlike Chichester, who was weak and flabby, this man seemed capable of using brute force. Rayburn lit a match, and we both gasped in shock.

"Why was the Mill House chosen as the murder scene? Could Pagett have been made a scapegoat for the stolen diamonds in Kimberley if I had not intervened? Do you think he is innocent?" "It seems that way, but we need to uncover his activities in Marlow. If he can explain that, we might be on the right track." Standing up, he said, "It's late. Get some rest, Anne. I'll take you to the boat just before dawn. You need to catch the train in Livingstone. A friend will keep you safe until it's time to leave. Head to Bulawayo and catch the train to Beira."

"I've kept quiet for years, knowing I had this weapon in reserve. But now things have changed. I want my price, and it won't come cheap. It's quite a staggering amount," she declared. "Incredible," the Count remarked. "Do you really carry these diamonds with you at all times?" His gaze swept across the messy room. Nadina chuckled softly. "Don't assume anything. I'm not that foolish. The diamonds are hidden in a secure location where no one would think to look for them."

What cunning! He anticipated every move a detective might make, steps that I, a foolish fool, actually made. He prepares two wills, has the staff sign both, then confidently presents his will on the back of a crumpled receipt, using a pen filled with his own unique ink. Under false pretenses, he convinces the baker and his spouse to add their signatures below his, then attaches it to his desk key, smirking to himself. Should his niece uncover his deception, she will prove her worth and expensive education, earning her rightful claim to his fortune.

"Have you noticed Pagett's shiner? I'm done with secretaries unless I find a nice girl with liquid eyes. What about you, Miss Anne? Will you come with me to Rhodesia?" Sir Eustace asked. "Thank you, but I must leave for Durban tonight," I replied. Despite my refusal, Sir Eustace insisted, mentioning lions in Rhodesia. As he called for Pagett, I hurried Suzanne to make plans. Suzanne expressed disappointment at not being able to go to Rhodesia, but I assured her she was still going. We discussed keeping an eye on Sir Eustace and Colonel Race, with Suzanne even suggesting confiding in the latter. I objected, wary of the consequences of involving others in our adventure.

I had informed the stewardess of my cold and insensitivity to smells. She appeared distressed, but I stood my ground. The evening dragged on, and I retired to bed, ready for any emergency. Vague thoughts crossed my mind, but I was certain that something would happen at one o’clock. The cabin was filled with silence as my fellow passengers settled in for the night. Suddenly, my door burst open, and a panicked man stumbled inside, pleading for help. With only seconds to spare, I swiftly concealed him behind my trunk and washed basin, transforming my appearance into that of a lady preparing for bed. When the door opened again, I was surprised to find a night stewardess standing there, looking for the source of the earlier noise.

"Is that your plan, Tuppence?” “It’s easy to mock, but I sense there may be some truth to it.” “How do you intend to make contact with your potential employers?” “Advertisement,” Tuppence said quickly. “Do you have a piece of paper and a pen? Men always seem to. Just like we always have hairpins and makeup.” Tommy handed her a worn green notebook, and Tuppence started writing. “Shall we write: ‘Former military officer, experienced in combat ’” “Absolutely not.” “Fine, my dear boy."

We made our way there on camels, the creatures kneeling patiently as we prepared to mount. Surrounding us were several boys, led by a talkative dragoman. I won't dwell on the sight of Poirot on a camel. His journey began with groans and ended with screams, gestures, and prayers to the Virgin Mary and all the saints. Eventually, he gave up and traveled the rest of the way on a small donkey. I have to say, riding a trotting camel is no laughing matter. I was sore for days.

"Ah, yes, indeed. That is where we must focus our efforts," he stated before turning towards the door. Just as he was about to leave, he hesitated and turned back to the woman seated in the room. "Madam, did your late husband ever mention anything about 'The Big Four'?" "The Big Four," she echoed, deep in thought. "No, I don't recall him ever mentioning that." That was the extent of the information we could gather from Mrs. Halliday. We quickly made our way back to the city, and the very next day found us headed towards the European mainland. Poirot couldn't help but chuckle as he remarked, "This Big Four certainly keeps me on my toes, my friend. I feel like I'm constantly running around, just like our dear old 'human foxhound'."

"Currently, I am swamped with work," Pagett announced. "Oh, before you go," I called out, "what did Mrs. Blair have in those suitcases?" "Just some fur rugs and a few fur hats, I believe." "Yes, that sounds right," I agreed. "She picked them up on the train. They are rather unique hats, so I understand why you couldn't place them. Any other items of interest?" "A few rolls of film and numerous baskets," Pagett responded. "Of course," I nodded. "Mrs. Blair tends to buy things in bulk."

"An elderly man stood by the mantelpiece, his shoulders slightly stooped. Dr. Durand was his name. “Most extraordinary,” M. Hautet remarked after the commissary spoke. “Do you have the letter, Monsieur?” Poirot handed it over, and the magistrate read it. “H’m. A secret is mentioned. What a pity he did not provide more details. We are grateful for your help, M. Poirot. Will you assist in our investigations? Or must you return to London?” “M. le juge, I intend to stay. I may not have arrived in time to save my client, but I feel compelled by honor to uncover the killer."

Poirot revealed the shocking truth to Jack Renauld about his father's past, leading Jack to make a life-changing decision. Jack decided to start a new life in South America with his mother and secretary, leaving behind a girl who loves him dearly. Poirot encouraged Jack to be honest with the girl and let her decide. Despite his doubts, Jack realized that true love conquers all and decided to pursue a future with her. As for Captain Hastings, his future plans remain uncertain, but the story ends with a light-hearted moment between him and a familiar face.

"His persuasion led me to switch allegiance." Sir Eustace glanced his way. He remained silent, yet Minks appeared to visibly crumble. "Rats deserting a sinking ship," noted Sir Eustace. "I despise rats. Sooner or later, I exterminate pests." "There's something I must disclose, Sir Eustace," I interjected. "The tin you tossed out the window didn't hold the diamonds. It contained ordinary pebbles. The diamonds are securely hidden. In truth, they reside in the large giraffe's belly."

He ushered them through the old house to the scene of the crime - Mr. Paynter's office. The room was spacious, adorned with shelves of books and large, luxurious armchairs. Poirot's gaze immediately fell upon the window facing the gravel terrace. "The window, was it left open?" he inquired. "That is the crux of the matter. The doctor exited through the door, simply pulling it closed. Yet, the following day, it was discovered locked. But by whom? Mr. Paynter? Ah Ling insists the window was shut tight. Dr.

"I pondered, Why not? The ceaseless unraveling of senseless puzzles is wearing thin. I have garnered ample renown. I shall pocket this sum and establish myself close to my longtime comrade." Poirot's gesture deeply moved me. "Thus, I agreed," he revealed, "and within sixty minutes, I must depart to board the ship-bound train. An amusing twist of fate, wouldn't you say? Nevertheless, I confess, Hastings, if the sum had not been so substantial, I may have hesitated, as of late I've initiated a personal inquiry."

“Could it have been Mrs. Inglethorp herself?” “There is another angle. Perhaps she simply neglected to secure the door to the passage before retiring for the night, only to rise later, in the early hours, and lock it then.” “Poirot, are you being serious?” “I am not asserting it as fact, but it is a possibility. Now, moving on to another aspect, how do you interpret the snippet of dialogue you caught between Mrs. Cavendish and her mother-in-law?” “I had overlooked that,” I mused. “It remains as cryptic as ever. It is difficult to believe that someone like Mrs. Cavendish, with her pride and reserved nature, would meddle so forcefully in a matter that was clearly not her concern.” “Exactly.

"Inglethorp’s sudden demise left many wondering about the fate of her wealth." The attorney paused briefly before responding, "The truth will become common knowledge soon enough. If Mr. Cavendish has no objections..." John quickly interjected, "None at all. I see no reason to evade your inquiry. In her final will, executed in August of the previous year, she bestowed her entire estate upon her stepson, Mr. John Cavendish, following a series of minor bequests to staff members, among others." "Wasn't that decision rather biased against her other stepson, Mr. Lawrence Cavendish?" "I don't believe so."

He simply took her away! Upon her arrival in England, she was completely devastated, yet somehow still alive.” Poirot solemnly shook his head. I tried to keep a straight face. Suddenly, he froze and pointed dramatically at the toast rack. “Ah, for example, this is too much!” he exclaimed. “What's wrong?” “This piece of toast. Do you not notice it?” He grabbed the culprit from the rack and displayed it for me to see. “Is it square? No. Is it a triangle? No. Is it even round? No. Does it have any shape that is remotely pleasing to the eye? What kind of symmetry is this? None.” “It's sliced from a cottage loaf,” I explained calmly.

Tommy anxiously awaited Albert's return at the inn. When Albert finally showed up, he revealed that while Tommy was being chased out of the window, something had been thrown out as well. Albert handed Tommy a piece of paper with just three words scribbled on it: "Same time tomorrow." Tommy was thrilled by this development. Albert went on to explain how he had written a message on a paper, wrapped it around a stone, and thrown it through the window. Tommy couldn't help but groan at Albert's audacious move.

"I can't erase the memory. You're amazing. I get it now." "Remember when I said you could confide in Papa Poirot safely? You doubted me." "It all makes sense now," Lawrence remarked. "The drugged cocoa, after the poisoned coffee, explains the delay." "True. But was the coffee really poisoned? That's the question. Mrs. Inglethorp never drank it." "What?" Everyone was shocked. "Yes. I mentioned a stain on Mrs. Inglethorp's carpet."

My aunt, who resides in the countryside, has been gravely ill for quite some time now. She’s calling out for me in her final moments.” Tommy gave a nod of approval. “Could you notify the appropriate authorities and rendezvous with me at Charing Cross in sixty minutes?” “I’ll be there, sir. You can rely on me.” As Tommy anticipated, loyal Albert proved to be a valuable companion. The two settled in at the inn in Gatehouse. Albert was tasked with gathering intel, which he did without any issues. Astley Priors was owned by Dr. Adams.

"But he seemed kind, and incredibly intelligent. I wouldn’t hesitate to approach him and confess everything to him.” To her surprise, Julius immediately dismissed the idea. “Listen,” he said firmly, “we can’t involve any lawyers in this. That man wouldn’t be of any help to us.” “I believe he could,” Tuppence stubbornly insisted. “No chance. I’ll be back in thirty minutes.” Julius returned after thirty-five minutes. He grabbed Tuppence's arm and led her to the window. “There it is.” “Oh!” Tuppence exclaimed with a hint of admiration in her voice as she looked down at the massive car. “It's quite the speed demon,” Julius boasted.

Madame Beroldy was a young and attractive woman, known for her charismatic personality. Rumors circulated about her mysterious background, with some claiming she was the illegitimate child of a Russian Grand Duke while others insisted it was an Austrian Archduke. Despite the speculation, Madame Beroldy neither confirmed nor denied the stories when questioned. Her presence in the quarter caused quite a commotion, leaving many intrigued by the enigma that surrounded her.

"But we wish to see Mr. Renauld,” I exclaimed. “We have an appointment. This is his Villa, right?” “Yes, sir, but…” Poirot leaned in. “But what?” “M. Renauld was murdered this morning.” Poirot swiftly exited the car, his eyes filled with intensity. He grabbed the man by the shoulder. “What did you say? Murdered? When? How?” The police officer stood firm. “I cannot provide any answers, sir.” “Understood. I see.” Poirot pondered for a moment. “The Police Commissioner, he is inside?” “Yes, sir.” Poirot handed over a card, quickly jotting down a few words on it.

I wondered why Poirot had come to London. Was it a last-minute choice or something he had planned earlier? Returning to Styles, I felt lost without Poirot's guidance. Did he know about the arrest in advance? Was he somehow involved? These questions plagued me. What should I do next? Should I inform everyone at Styles about the arrest, or keep it quiet? Despite my reluctance to admit it, I couldn't shake the worry about Mary Cavendish's reaction. Her potential shock troubled me deeply, pushing aside any doubts I had about her.

"In the same way, he made it clear that he left the coffee in the hallway. Although overlooked during the inquest, this detail now holds great importance. Our task is to determine who brought the coffee to Mrs. Inglethorp or who passed by while it sat there. Based on your information, only two individuals can be ruled out as having any connection to the coffee: Mrs. Cavendish and Mademoiselle Cynthia." "Agreed," I replied, feeling a sense of relief. Mary Cavendish was undoubtedly innocent. "By clearing Alfred Inglethorp," Poirot added, "I have been forced to reveal my hand earlier than planned."

I had come across it before I realized my error. The piece was concise. I can recall every detail perfectly, and there was nothing in it that would cause any distress." "You want me to recite it?" I prompted. "Yes." She hesitated for a moment and then slowly repeated, as I discreetly transcribed the words, the following: "DEAR SIR, The most important thing now, I believe, is to inspect the estate. If you are adamant about including the quarry, then seventeen thousand appears fair. 11% commission is excessive, 4% is sufficient. "Sincerely, "ARTHUR LEVERSHAM."
