Who was this mysterious young man who barged into my cabin unannounced? He was a complete stranger to me, not a crew member nor a fellow passenger. The real question remained: who was responsible for stabbing him, and for what reason? And what significance did Cabin No. 17 hold in this puzzling situation? As I pondered these questions, it became clear that something sinister was unfolding aboard the Kilmorden Castle. My list of suspects grew as I mentally noted those who required closer scrutiny.

I was enjoying an evening with my friend, Gerald Parker. The conversation turned to house-hunting in London, a topic Parker was passionate about. He had moved from one flat to another, always finding new places. Mrs. Robinson shared that she and her husband had finally found a flat in Montagu Mansions for a surprisingly low price. Parker was astonished by the good deal, suspecting there must be a catch. Mrs. Robinson seemed uneasy, mentioning some strange things about the place that made her wonder if it was haunted. Parker dismissed the idea, but Mrs. Robinson was not convinced.

"There was a subtle shift in his attitude towards me. 'I have an update for you. Your boyfriend is on his way. He'll arrive shortly. Keep your emotions in check, I have more to tell you. You tried to trick me this morning. I advised you to be honest, and initially you complied. But then you veered off course. You tried to convince me that the diamonds were with Harry Rayburn. I went along with it at first because it made it easier for me to persuade you to lure Harry Rayburn here."

I headed out after lunch, wearing my best hat (a hand-me-down from Suzanne) and my least wrinkled white linen. Taking a quick train to Muizenberg, I arrived in just thirty minutes. The journey was pleasant as we circled around the foot of Table Mountain, passing by some beautiful flowers. Due to my poor geography skills, I had never fully grasped that Cape Town is situated on a peninsula. So, I was taken aback when I stepped off the train and found myself staring at the sea once again. The sight of people enjoying the water was truly delightful.

“I demanded it,” gasped Tuppence. “She was just being escorted home to some high-ranking official.”   “How did you manage that?”   “I paid a visit to his residence,” said Julius. “I mentioned that in my opinion, a vehicle like that was valued at twenty thousand dollars. Then I made it clear that it held a personal value of around fifty thousand dollars to me if he exited the car.”   “And then?” said Tuppence, intrigued.   “And then,” replied Julius, “he exited the car, that’s all.”   The following two days passed without incident. Tuppence had received a succinct response to her plea from Mr. Carter. He highlighted that the Young Adventurers had taken on the task voluntarily, fully aware of the risks involved.

An expression formed on his face, a mix of confusion and relief. "Well!" he exclaimed. "It is clear now! I had a suspicion, but it seems I was wrong. Yes, completely mistaken. Yet, it is odd. But let it go!" With a casual shrug, he let go of whatever troubled him. I could have warned him that his fixation on the coffee would lead nowhere, but I held my words. Despite his age, Poirot was once a renowned figure in his prime.

"Are you serious?" "Yes. The pit was freshly dug just a few yards outside the boundary of the Villa grounds." "How long had he been dead?" Dr. Durand provided the answer. "I examined the body this morning at ten o’clock. Death must have occurred at least seven, and possibly ten hours earlier." "Hm, so between midnight and 3 a.m." "Precisely, and Madame Renauld’s testimony places it after 2 a.m. which further narrows down the time frame. Death was instant and clearly not self-inflicted."

"The identity of your friends will determine our next steps." Without a word, the man pulled out a cigarette case, removed four cigarettes, and placed them on the table before swiftly returning them to the case and back into his pocket. "Ah, I see," remarked Poirot, "and what exactly are your friends proposing?" "They propose, sir, that you utilize your remarkable skills in solving real crimes and return to your previous line of work, focusing on the mysteries of high society in London." "A rather peaceful proposition," noted Poirot. "And if I decline?" The man gestured expressively. "We would, naturally, be greatly disappointed," he replied.

At the window, a large roll-top desk was covered in scattered papers where the master of the house sat. Upon their arrival, he stood up. "Do you have a message for me? Ah," he greeted Tuppence with a smile, "it's you, isn't it? Bringing a message from Mrs. Vandemeyer, I presume?" "Not quite," Tuppence replied. "Actually, I only used that as an excuse to gain entry. Oh, and this is Mr. Hersheimmer, Sir James Peel Edgerton." "Nice to meet you," the American said, extending his hand. "Please, have a seat," Sir James offered, pulling out two chairs.

As I glanced at him, a sense of deja vu washed over me. His face triggered a memory, but I dismissed it quickly. Glancing down at my watch, I realized time was slipping away. With a swift turn, I headed towards Cape Town. Spotting a tram about to depart, I sprinted to catch it. Footsteps echoed behind me, growing louder. I leaped onto the tram, closely followed by the other runner. It was him - the man from the night before, the one with the distinctive nose. The pieces fell into place - the encounter at the station, the untied shoe on the road. The puzzle was coming together in a rather unexpected way.

The flowers arrangements had defied the usual seasons, mixing blooms that belonged to different times of the year. The guest list was exclusive and compact. Among the attendees were the American Ambassador, Mr. Carter, who had introduced his long-time friend, Sir William Beresford, Archdeacon Cowley, Dr. Hall, the daring duo of Miss Prudence Cowley and Mr. Thomas Beresford, and of course, the esteemed guest of honor, Miss Jane Finn. Julius had gone to great lengths to ensure Jane made a grand entrance. A mysterious knock on the door of the apartment shared by Tuppence and the American girl had set the events in motion.

"And lo and behold, within the fireplace lay the very same quartet of coal knobs I had meticulously scattered there. Poirot caught sight of my observation. "Ah, but of course, that was a stroke of genius on your part, along with the volumes. Let's say, if someone were to ever suggest to me, 'Your dear friend Hastings, he lacks in the intellect department, doesn't he?' I would retort: 'You couldn't be more mistaken.' It was a brilliant and magnificent notion that dawned on you in that moment." "So you grasped their significance?" "Do you take me for a fool? Naturally, I comprehended. It provided me with the exact caution I required, and the opportunity to refine my schemes."

"The man had gone off to fight in the war, showing courage and valor. He was declared missing, wounded, and presumed dead. I didn't press for further information, but I couldn't help but wonder about Colonel Race's involvement. To gather more insights, I decided to have a conversation with the night steward. After some persuasion, he revealed that the lady in question seemed unafraid, suggesting it was all part of a harmless prank or bet. Slowly but surely, I extracted all the details from him."

Tommy gently caressed his own head, lost in a world of fantasy. Suddenly, a brilliant notion sparked in his mind. Instead of just imagining, why not make it real? It was clear that Conrad was the true occupant of the residence. The rest, aside from the bearded German, only visited as a meeting point. So, why not lay in wait for Conrad behind the door, and upon his arrival, swiftly strike him with a chair or one of the old paintings. Of course, caution would be taken not to inflict severe harm.

She felt trapped from all sides, a sense of dread creeping in. "If they believe we're heading to Sir James," she confided in Jane, "it will throw them off. Let them think we're going to Mr. Carter instead. His estate lies somewhere north of London." As they crossed Holborn, a traffic jam brought their taxi to a halt. seizing the opportunity, Tuppence urged, "Hurry, open the door on the right!" Without hesitation, the two of them exited into the busy street. Within moments, they found themselves in a new taxi, heading back towards Carlton House Terrace. "That should confuse them," Tuppence remarked smugly.

With growing irritation, he struggled to make out any additional details; catching only snippets of conversation when voices rose, fueling his curiosity even more. His gaze lingered on the door handle, contemplating the possibility of turning it slowly and discreetly enough to avoid detection. After careful consideration, he concluded that it was indeed feasible. Gradually, barely shifting it an inch at a time, he maneuvered the handle with utmost caution, hardly daring to breathe. As he inched it further, he wondered if it would ever reach its limit. Finally, it refused to turn any more.

Somebody always talks! "Danvers sailed for England on the Lusitania. He carried the precious papers in an oilskin packet which he wore next his skin. It was on that particular voyage that the Lusitania was torpedoed and sunk. Danvers was among the list of those missing. Eventually his body was washed ashore, and identified beyond any possible doubt. But the oilskin packet was missing! "The question was, had it been taken from him, or had he himself passed it on into another's keeping? There were a few incidents that strengthened the possibility of the latter theory."

"Did you know," I suddenly interjected, "that Guy Pagett was present in Marlow when the murder took place?" "That changes everything. I was under the impression he was in Cannes with Sir Eustace." "He was believed to be in Florence but it turns out he never actually traveled there. My hunch is that he was indeed in Marlow, although I lack concrete evidence." "It's unbelievable that I never suspected Pagett until the night he attempted to push you off the boat. He's quite the talented actor." "Indeed, he is." "This would explain why the Mill House was selected. Pagett likely had the ability to enter and exit without being noticed."

An incredible change had overtaken my companion. His eyes sparkled with anticipation, his chest expanded with pride. "I've been foolish, my companions! But now I see the light." Major Norman hurried to the exit. "I'll fetch the car." "That won't be necessary. I won't be using it. Thankfully, the storm has passed." "Are you planning to walk, sir?" "No, my dear friend. I am not St. Peter. I choose to voyage across the ocean by ship." "Across the ocean?" "Indeed. To proceed systematically, one must start from the beginning. And the genesis of this case was in England. Therefore, we must return to England."

Tuppence pondered the contents of that safe again, wondering if anything had been found. The events of last night replayed in her mind, each detail carefully examined. Sir James's cryptic words seemed to be connected somehow. Suddenly, a wave of realization hit her, draining the color from her face. Her eyes widened in shock as she muttered, "It can't be true. I must be losing my mind to even consider such a possibility." Despite its monstrous nature, the idea seemed to make sense of everything. After a brief pause, she sat down to compose a note, carefully choosing each word.

"The crime must have taken place approximately two hours later, giving anyone who left on that train a solid alibi!" "Brilliant, Hastings! You've got it!" I jumped to my feet. "We need to check with the station. They surely couldn't have missed two strangers leaving on that train! Let's go immediately!" "Do you really think so, Hastings?" "Absolutely. We should head there right now." Poirot gently held me back with a touch on my arm. "Go ahead if you must, my friend, but if you do, I wouldn't bother asking about those two strangers."

"I know where the diamonds are," I declared confidently. Sir Eustace's eyes widened in surprise. "Where?" he demanded eagerly. "In a safe place, far away from here," I replied mysteriously. "But I can take you to them, if you agree to let Harry and I go free." Sir Eustace hesitated, then nodded. "Deal," he said. I led the way out of the room, with Sir Eustace following closely behind. As we walked down the corridor, I couldn't help but feel a sense of triumph. I had outsmarted the cunning criminal and saved the day. The diamonds were safe, and Harry and I were free at last. It was a satisfying end to a dangerous game of cat and mouse.

"Please, don't be upset! Let me focus on my coffee, while you enjoy your cocoa. Deal?" His quirky sense of humor made me chuckle, and we headed to the drawing-room. The coffee-cups and tray were exactly as we had left them. Poirot asked me to recount the events from the previous night, paying close attention to the position of the cups. "Mrs. Cavendish stood by the tray and poured. Then she joined you and Mademoiselle Cynthia by the window. Here are the three cups."

I have always been inclined to view work as something that should be taken on with a light and airy touch, if at all! Guy Pagett, on the other hand, is a man of seriousness and dedication. His lack of frivolity makes him a challenging companion. When I suggested he go to Florence, he eagerly accepted, despite the unusual timing. His devotion to guidebooks and galleries made it a worthwhile investment for me. However, our peace was shattered when he informed me of a murder in my house, involving a foreign woman. This unexpected turn of events has led me to reconsider my plans and embark on a new journey.

"I was in the neighborhood, yes. Sir Eustace has not already told you? I hoped he had not recognized me, but from the hints he has let drop, and his remarks, I fear it is only too certain. In any case, I meant to make a clean breast of the matter and offer him my resignation. He is a peculiar man, with an abnormal sense of humor. It seems to amuse him to keep me on tenter-hooks. All the time, I dare say, he was perfectly well aware of the true facts."

"Furthermore, there is additional evidence that, prior to his demise, he was engaged in a romantic entanglement with a French woman, known as Madame Daubreuil, who resides in the neighboring Villa. Can you believe that this is the same man who, as you claim, had no interest in women's company?" The secretary's gaze sharpened. "Wait a minute, Judge. You're on the wrong track. I was acquainted with Paul Renauld. What you are suggesting is simply not possible. There must be some other explanation." The judge shrugged. "Then what alternative explanation do you propose?" "On what basis do you conclude it was a romantic relationship?" "Madame Daubreuil would frequently visit him here in the evenings."

Nonetheless, the case came back to me with surprising clarity. It had caused quite a stir in the past, extensively covered in the English newspapers. Remembering the key details required little effort on my part. In my current state of exhilaration, everything seemed to fall into place. I must confess, I tend to act on impulse, a habit that Poirot often criticizes. However, in this particular instance, I believe my hastiness was justified. The way in which this new revelation aligned with Poirot’s perspective was truly remarkable. Without hesitation, I turned to Poirot and exclaimed, “Congratulations, Poirot."

"You know, I have feelings for someone else," I admitted. His response was a simple, "I understand." I hesitated before confessing, "It didn't start out that way when we met on the Kilmorden." His next words carried a weight I had never felt before, "I see." His expression was stern, a stark contrast to his usual demeanor. "What are you trying to say?" I asked, my voice wavering. "Is that breakfast?" The girl nodded. Tommy got up from the bed to examine the tray - a loaf, margarine, and coffee. "Not quite the Ritz," he muttered.

"No need to be upset, Anne. I was just joking around. Come sit here. Putting jokes aside, I believe you've stumbled upon something crucial. We've always assumed Pagett had an alibi. “Let's go and check the coffee cups,” he said.  “My dear Poirot! What's the point now that we know about the cocoa?” I replied.  “That dreadful cocoa!” Poirot exclaimed. Poirot was the one to reveal the shocking truth to Jack Renauld about his father's past as a fugitive from justice. In the end, Jack found the courage to approach her as a man ready for a new beginning. As for Captain Hastings, he preferred to reminisce about a morning in the garden rather than join the Renaulds on their journey.

By carefully crafting the structure of the story and the interactions between the characters, I aim to create a gripping tale that keeps the reader guessing until the very end.

"Very well, my friend, I agree. The thrill of the chase is a passion for you English. Now, the details." "Last Saturday, Mr. Davenheim boarded the 12.40 train from Victoria to Chingside, his estate, The Cedars, being located there. Tuppence insisted on frugal spending, reminding Tommy that walking was a cost-effective form of entertainment. Disappointment lingered from the previous day, but hope remained as they waited for responses to the new ad.

"Alfred Inglethorp and before you know it!” “Trust me, Miss Howard,” Poirot assured, “if Mr. Inglethorp is guilty, I will not rest until he faces justice. "As you did not provide me with an address, the letter was sent to me for forwarding," he clarified. Poirot examined the letter with interest. The handwriting, a woman's script, was long and slanted. These young detectives, followers of Giraud, they are all impolite and arrogant," he remarked.

"I've been admiring these flower beds. How many gardeners work here?" "Just three now, sir. We used to have five before the war, when this place was kept as it should be for a gentleman. "Better times will come again, Dorcas. At least, we hope so. Now, please send Annie to me here." "Yes, sir. Thank you, sir." "How did you know that Mrs.?"

"The woman had been dead for about twenty-four hours, according to the police surgeon. Despite The Daily Budget's assumption that the man in the Tube was responsible for her murder and subsequent suicide, the timeline proved otherwise. The woman was alive at three o’clock, while the Tube victim was already dead by two o’clock. Therefore, it was clear that the two events were unrelated. The discovery of an address to view a house in Marlow in the dead man's pocket was simply a coincidence, a common occurrence in life."

“Allow me to introduce Captain Lucien Bex, a dear friend from England,” Poirot gestured. The commissary and I exchanged nods before Bex redirected his attention to Poirot. “It has been quite some time, my old friend. Last I saw you was in Ostend back in 1909. I heard you had left the Force?” Poirot confirmed, “Indeed, I now operate a private business in London.” Bex inquired, “You mentioned having information that could be of help to us?” Poirot responded, “It is possible you are already aware. Did you know the victim had summoned me?” Bex was taken aback, “No, by whose request?” Poirot explained, “The deceased. He had foreseen an attempt on his life. Regrettably, he reached out to me too late.” The commissary interjected, “Sacri tonnerre!”

“Do you have any reason to pursue her legally? Perhaps something related to contempt of court, or some British matter? A spirited young American woman might struggle with your wartime rules and restrictions, and rebel against them. If that's the case, and corruption exists in this country, I can take care of it.” Tuppence assured him that everything was fine. “Great. Then we can collaborate. How about lunch? Should we eat here, or head to the restaurant?” Tuppence chose the latter option, and Julius respected her choice. They were enjoying Sole Colbert after finishing their oysters when a servant delivered a card to Hersheimmer.

"Hautet pondered the scene before him. 'Another crime!' he exclaimed. 'The depths of this case have yet to be plumbed. A veil of mystery shrouds it all. But who is the unfortunate victim this time?' 'That, M. le juge, is the question on everyone's mind. The victim remains unidentified,' Giraud replied. 'Where is the body?' inquired the doctor. Giraud stepped aside, revealing the body in the corner. 'Stabbed through the heart, as you can see, with the very dagger stolen yesterday morning. It appears the murder swiftly followed the theft, but I leave that determination to you. Feel free to examine the dagger - there are no fingerprints to be found.'"

"I think they must exercise caution. The key is always removed before exiting the room." "Is the cupboard located near the window?" "No, it's on the opposite side of the room. Why do you ask?" Poirot raised his shoulders. "Just curious. That's all. Will you join me inside?" We had arrived at the cottage. "No. I believe I'll head back. I'll take the longer route through the woods." The woods surrounding Styles were exceptionally picturesque. Following the stroll across the open park, it was delightful to leisurely wander through the serene glades. There was barely a whisper of wind, the birds' chirping was barely audible.

"We've spent too much time on this." "You're mistaken, my friend. The time spent was necessary. My agents, including Joseph Aarons, have been working on this for months. We've been narrowing it down for a while now."

They gazed out at the rugged peaks and dense pine forests below. Poirot pointed towards the horizon. "Is it there?" he whispered. "Yes," Harvey confirmed. "The Felsenlabyrynth, a maze of massive boulders with a winding path through them. The quarry is to the right, but we suspect the entrance is within the labyrinth." Poirot nodded. "Come, my friend," he said to me. "Let's descend to the terrace and bask in the sun." "Do you believe that's prudent?" I inquired. He simply shrugged.

I despise being entangled in such matters. The day took a turn when Guy Pagett entered my bedroom this morning, holding a telegram with a solemn expression that rivaled a mourner at a funeral. Guy Pagett, my diligent secretary, is an exemplary individual in every aspect - diligent, meticulous, and hard-working. Yet, he manages to irritate me like no other. I have pondered for quite some time on how to remove him from my service. However, it is not feasible to terminate a secretary simply because he prioritizes work over leisure, enjoys rising early, and possesses no discernible vices. The one redeeming quality about him is his somber countenance.

I made sure of that.” “You?” “Yes. Recall scolding me for sharing details with the household?” "Yes."

After contemplating, I made the decision to share the information with John, letting him choose whether to make it public. His reaction was a loud whistle of surprise. "You were right all along. I was in disbelief." "Indeed, it's quite shocking at first. But once you accept it, everything falls into place. Now, what's our next move? Tomorrow, everyone will know." John thought for a moment. "Don't worry," he finally spoke, "let's keep quiet for now. No need to rush. It'll come out soon anyway."

"And rightly so! Your crime was a horrifying one, condemned by both gods and men!” M. The door swung open. “M. le juge, M. le juge,” the attendant stuttered, “there is a woman here who claims, who claims ” “Who claims what?” the magistrate demanded, his patience wearing thin.

"I kept my silence, but inside I was grinning from ear to ear. Little did he know the truth." Poirot gave a subtle nod. I observed a slight tremor in his hand as he reached for his drink. "Handwriting can be a powerful tool in determining one's identity," he stated. "Do you happen to have a letter penned by Mr. Darrell?" Flossie Monro sadly shook her head. "He was not one for writing. The passenger responsible for arranging the transaction went by the name of Carton, and his physical description matched that of the man who met his demise on the Underground. This revelation solved one mystery, revealing that the diamonds were the crucial element in the entire affair. The final days aboard the Kilmorden passed swiftly as we approached Cape Town, prompting me to carefully consider my next steps. There were numerous individuals I needed to monitor closely - from Mr. Chichester to Sir Eustace and his secretary, not forgetting Colonel Race. Determining how to proceed was no easy task. My focus naturally gravitated towards Chichester, leading me to reluctantly consider the fate of Sir Eustace and Mr..

I always think of Mademoiselle Daubreuil as the girl with nervous eyes. His serious tone made me uneasy. “What do you mean, Poirot?” “We will find out soon enough, my friend. But I must go.” “You have plenty of time.” “Maybe maybe. But I prefer to take it easy at the station. I don't want to rush.” “I'll see you off,” I said, standing up. “Absolutely not. I won't allow it.” His firmness surprised me. He nodded decisively. “I'm serious, my friend. Goodbye! Can I give you a hug? Oh, right, I forgot it's not the English way.”

A decision. Bella or Jack Renauld? The promptings of my heart were to save the girl I loved at any cost to myself. But, if the cost were to another, the problem was altered. What would the girl herself say? I remembered that no word of Jack Renauld’s arrest had passed my lips. As yet she was in total ignorance of the fact that her former lover was in prison charged with a hideous crime which he had not committed. When she knew, how would she act? Would she permit her life to be saved at the expense of his? Certainly she must do nothing rash. If only I could find a way to save them both.

Oh,” her tone shifted to disappointment, “I accidentally had it on ‘bulb’ the whole time.” “I always enjoy watching a child with a new toy,” the Colonel remarked. “You're so mean, but I have another roll."

Therefore, my friend, I suggest we abandon our sleep tonight and keep watch in the apartment below with your trusty revolver, of course!” “Count me in,” I responded eagerly."

There was a sudden rap at the door, and before I could even utter a word of acknowledgement, it swung open. I was taken aback by the unexpected visitor. My mind raced with images of Mr. Pagett wielding a gun, or my missionary acquaintance armed with a sandbag. However, what stood before me was a night stewardess, her face displaying curiosity and an air of respectability. "Excuse me, miss, I thought I heard you call out," she remarked. "No," I replied firmly. "I did not." "I apologize for the intrusion." "It's quite alright," I reassured her. "I couldn't sleep. A wash seemed like a good idea." The words felt unfamiliar, as if self-care was a rare occurrence for me. "I'm sorry, miss," the stewardess repeated, her tone apologetic.

Tuppence was caught off guard by his aggressive tone, but she remained composed. Despite not fully understanding his accusations, her sharp wit urged her to maintain her facade. Whittington accused her of toying with him like a game of cat and mouse, pretending ignorance while knowing his true intentions. As he calmed down, the anger faded from his face and he scrutinized her, questioning if Rita had betrayed him. Tuppence silently denied his suspicions.

"I've behaved foolishly in various ways, Monsieur Poirot. I am deeply in debt but I am determined to turn things around. I care for the children and I aim to resolve my issues so we can continue living in our home. Gregory Rolf has presented me with a lucrative opportunity that could help me get back on track. I am hesitant, as I despise the idea of participating in the pretentious activities at the Chase, but I may not have a choice," He paused, meeting Poirot's sharp gaze.

I refrained from questioning Poirot about our destination in the presence of our captive, struggling to glean any insight into the situation. We arrived at a modest house set back from the road. A tipsy passerby staggered along the sidewalk, nearly bumping into Poirot, who uttered something sternly to him, the words escaping me. The three of us ascended the house's steps. Poirot pressed the doorbell and gestured for us to step back. Silence followed, prompting Poirot to ring the bell again before resorting to knocking loudly. A light flickered on above the door, which cautiously opened a crack.

"The Countess Vera Rossakoff burst into the room, causing a commotion. Number Four greeted her as a trusted ally. The countess recognized a familiar face and exclaimed in disbelief. Poirot, comparing himself to Napoleon, stood firm in his allegiance to the powerful."

"Feel free to tell the story in your own words," I encouraged, as he continued: "Arriving in Kimberley, we were filled with pride over our discovery. Carrying a valuable collection of diamonds, we sought the opinion of experts. It was at the Kimberley hotel where we encountered her." My body tensed slightly, my hand gripping the doorpost unconsciously. "Anita Grünberg, an actress. Youthful and strikingly beautiful. Though born in South Africa, her mother hailed from Hungary. There was an air of mystery surrounding her, adding to her allure for two young men fresh from the wilderness. It seems she had no trouble at all."

It felt like ages had passed, though only three days had gone by. "Focus, my dear," Poirot urged. "Organize your thoughts. Approach this methodically and systematically. That is the key to triumph."

"And the nephew? What do you know of his tastes? Was he with the party at all?” “I do not think so. "But do we really need to consider that? I cannot fathom Madame Renauld being in cahoots with Madame Daubreuil for a variety of reasons, some of which I have already discussed with you. Poirot, who had been standing by the window, moved to sit across from Miss Howard. "Mademoiselle," he began seriously, "I have a question for you.

"Having assumed I was alone on the boat deck, I was surprised to see another figure gazing out at the city. I instantly recognized him before he even turned around. The events of last night felt surreal in the calm morning light. What did he think of me? The words I had spoken made me cringe with embarrassment. Did I truly mean them? I quickly averted my gaze, focusing intently on Table Mountain. If Rayburn sought solitude up here, I would not intrude by making my presence known."

Let's go to Marsdon Manor and investigate further,” Poirot suggested, leading the way out of the consulting room. Mrs. Maltravers, a young and beautiful widow, followed us silently. Her eyes were red from crying, but her beauty was undeniable. She explained that her husband had been out shooting rooks on the day of his death. Poirot examined the rook rifle that was left in the hall. We needed to uncover the truth behind Mr. Maltravers' sudden demise.

"The sorrowful eyes that made contact with mine were not filled with blame, indicating that she had recently shed tears, as evidenced by the redness of her eyelids. Despite this, her demeanor remained as gruff as ever. “I received the message and immediately embarked on my journey. Just finished my night shift. Rented a car for a quicker arrival.” “Have you had any breakfast this morning, Evie?” inquired John. “No, I haven't.” “I suspected as much. Follow me, they haven't cleared breakfast yet, and they can prepare some fresh tea for you.” John then addressed me. “Take care of her, Hastings, will you? Wells is expecting me."

Poirot was examining the crime scene thoroughly, his attention caught by a piece of discoloured lead-piping near the spade. Giraud, the Paris detective, seemed uninterested and continued his search. Poirot, however, was intrigued and found it very interesting. M. Bex, impressed by Poirot's quick understanding of the situation, praised him highly. The detective's efficiency was undeniable, even though I harbored a dislike for him. Poirot's focus on seemingly insignificant details puzzled me, but he seemed determined to uncover the truth.

"Remember, not a word of this to Giraud," I cautioned Poirot. "He seems to dismiss me as inconsequential. But we'll see about that. I did drop a hint to him, out of common decency. If he chooses to ignore it, that's on him." Poirot nodded, trusting in my discretion. "Very well then, let's engage our little grey cells. Do you have an estimate of when the tragedy occurred?" I replied, "Around two o'clock, I believe." Poirot raised an eyebrow in surprise. "Yes, Mrs. Renauld mentioned hearing the clock chime while the men were present in the room."

He insisted to her multiple times that it was four-thirty, not four o’clock when she heard the voices. However, Dorcas remained unfazed. At least an hour, if not more, had passed since she heard the voices and five o’clock, the time she brought tea to her mistress. The coroner's inquest took place on Friday at the Stylites Arms pub in the village. Poirot and I sat side by side, not called upon to testify. The initial procedures were completed. The jurors examined the corpse, and John Cavendish confirmed the identity.

"Absolutely. Rubenstein was defeated by Savaronoff, who became the Russian champion several years back. Some claim Wilson is a close match to Capablanca." Wilson seemed perfectly healthy, no signs of heart issues. His sudden death is truly baffling." "Are you implying that Dr. Savaronoff may have had a hand in his demise?" I interjected. “Detective Poirot addressed the group with a list of seemingly random words: ‘Name,’ ‘Place,’ ‘Tuesday,’ ‘Dinner,’ ‘Journey,’ ‘Country,’ ‘Story,’ ‘Rook Rifle,’ ‘Shot,’ ‘Suicide,’ ‘Money.’ The room fell silent as Poirot’s gaze settled on each person in turn. ‘Thank you all for your cooperation,’ he said, dismissing them with a wave of his hand. Later, as the suspects filed out, Poirot turned to me with a knowing smile. ‘Do you see it now, Hastings?’ he asked. I was at a loss. ‘I’m afraid not,’ I admitted. ‘Allow me to enlighten you,’ Poirot replied, leaning in to share his insights.”

“Good gracious, we’ve certainly surprised the poor man!” she exclaimed to an invisible crowd. “I beg your pardon for my outburst! Dressed elegantly in black attire adorned with exquisite pearls, the woman known to us as Countess Vera Rossakoff made a striking appearance. Little did we know at the time that she was secretly working as an agent for the notorious Big Four. Despite her allegiance to our enemies, Poirot inexplicably harbored a soft spot for the countess, admiring her flamboyant nature. In his eyes, she was a truly unique woman, unlike any other. Her betrayal seemed to have little impact on his unwavering fondness for her.

With a cry of terror piercing the night, the girl vanished through the window, her wrists like steel. Poirot, impatient, brushed Françoise aside and hurried down the passage to the other maids. The door was locked from the inside, but a heavy fall was heard. Eventually, Cinderella opened the door to reveal Mrs. Renauld gasping for breath on the bed. She had been nearly strangled. Poirot examined a silk rope ladder - a means of escape. Meanwhile, a figure lay dead on the ground, revealed to be the beautiful Marthe Daubreuil. Confused memories flooded my mind as Poirot reprimanded Françoise for not disclosing Mrs. Renauld's change of room. The chaos culminated in Poirot demanding the doctor for Mrs. Renauld and then the police.

"Tell me where she is. What have you done with her?" "She's safe, hidden away where no one can reach her. For now, she's unharmed. Notice how I said 'for now'." ” She reluctantly agreed, promising to revisit the topic once we reached the Falls. The train departed at nine in the morning. Sir Eustace remained in a foul mood, while Miss Pettigrew appeared meek. Colonel Race exuded his usual air of confidence. I couldn't shake the feeling that our previous discussion was a figment of my imagination. Tommy was in the midst of savoring a delightful bite of Sole à la Jeanette when Julius appeared in the doorway. With a wave of the menu, Tommy caught Julius's attention. Julius's eyes nearly bulged out of his head at the sight of Tommy. He crossed the room and vigorously shook Tommy's hand. "Goodness gracious!" he exclaimed. "Is it truly you?" "Of course it's me. Why wouldn't it be?" "Why wouldn't it be? My goodness, you know you were presumed dead, don't you? We were about to hold a requiem for you." "Who believed I was dead?" Tommy demanded.

"Is it possible that she may have taken an overdose of her medicine by accident?" asked Lawrence. The Coroner and jury looked up, intrigued. "I believe there have been cases where the cumulative effect of a drug, administered over time, has resulted in death," he continued. "My mother, before her death, was taking a tonic containing strychnine." The Coroner exclaimed, "Ah! This is the first we have heard of the deceased taking strychnine at the time of her death. We are much obliged to you, Mr. Cavendish."

I wandered further, eventually collapsing under the shade of a towering oak tree. My outlook on humanity was gentle and benevolent. I found myself even pardoning Poirot for his unnecessary secrecy. Truly, I was content with the universe. A yawn escaped me. The crime crossed my mind, feeling distant and almost imaginary. Another yawn emerged. Perhaps, I considered, it was all a figment of my imagination. Surely, it was simply a nightmare. The reality of the situation became clear - it was Lawrence who killed Alfred Inglethorp using a croquet mallet.

With no trains departing until noon the next day, she couldn't have left town. So, where on earth is she? Race, her partner, is frantic. He has done everything in his power to find her. Law enforcement officers from all over the region have been called in to assist.

I was relieved to receive a telegram informing me that Anne was safe in Kimberley with Suzanne Blair. Anne had always been a resilient woman, much like a terrier with a knack for turning up smiling. The news of her safety brought me comfort, but I couldn't help but wonder why she had chosen to leave the hotel in the middle of the night to get to Kimberley. Did she sprout wings and fly there? It seemed unlikely, but with Anne, anything was possible. Her mysterious ways always left me guessing, a common theme in my life. As a crime novelist, I was accustomed to uncovering secrets and solving mysteries, but with Anne, the answers never came easy. It was a puzzle I may never solve, adding to the intrigue of our complicated relationship.

"It's undeniable that the letters arrived via post, yet there's a peculiar scent lingering on them, reminiscent of joss-sticks that immediately evoked the East in my mind. I enjoy my exclusive Club, a competitive game of Bridge, a gourmet meal, and a fine glass of wine. I prefer the charm of England during the summer months and the luxury of the Riviera in winter. Even if I don't seek out excitement, it seems to find me, and I often find myself entangled in unexpected situations.

"Sorry, but I have to go," she said abruptly before rushing out of the room. It didn't take long before another man entered - a burly figure with a tiny red mustache and pince-nez glasses. "I'm Dr. Treves," he announced. "Mrs. Templeton couldn't make it, she's not feeling well. Nervous breakdown, you see. Worried about her husband and all. I've given her some medication and advised bed rest. But she insists you stay for dinner, and I'll be your host. Your reputation precedes you, M. Poirot, and we're eager to have you here."

In this tale, we encounter a cunning and devious woman who is well aware of her husband's financial troubles. She grows weary of her elderly spouse, whom she married solely for his wealth, and hatches a plan to have him take out a sizable life insurance policy. After a fortuitous accident involving a young soldier, she seizes upon an opportunity to carry out her scheme. The following day, believing her husband to be away at sea, she casually remarks on the peculiar story shared the previous evening.

Walking away from each other after a tense exchange, I strolled along Edgware Road (the meeting had occurred in a St. John’s Wood residence) and through Hyde Park towards St. George’s Hospital. Upon arriving, I made my way into Hyde Park Corner Tube Station and purchased a ticket for Gloucester Road. Standing on the platform, I proceeded to the far end. Curiosity drove me to confirm the existence of points and an aperture connecting the two tunnels past the station towards Down Street. To my satisfaction, I was proven correct.

"You understand the nature of women. She's enthusiastic about the film stunt." "I see," replied Poirot. After a moment of contemplation, he quickly stood up. The purser conveyed his apologies for her absence in a sincerely manner as he assigned me her room, and afterwards Colonel Race shared some intriguing insights about her. Rumors of her involvement in espionage circulated in Paris, though no evidence was ever found. It appeared that Colonel Race had been deployed to investigate this matter. He disclosed details about a sophisticated criminal network, revealing it to be non-German in nature.

The incident had occurred at Trafalgar Square. “Was it a mere accident, or a premeditated act?” “I cannot say for certain. Unexpectedly, a tall and visibly drunk man blocked their path. “Good evening, ladies,” he slurred.

"He might have tampered with the curry ingredients," I proposed. "And he made sure to have an alibi, avoiding eating the dish himself." My deduction seemed to catch Poirot's attention. "Mr. Paynter, a robust man of fifty-five, would not go down without a fight, Hastings. Such a scenario is unlikely." "We are getting closer, Poirot," I exclaimed confidently.

"When they forced the door open, the window was immediately pushed ajar by one of the intruders. The housemaid responsible claimed the window was likely left unfastened. The key could have tumbled out of the keyhole, been deliberately placed by one of the trespassers, or even slid under the door from outside. Uncertainty shrouds every detail, Monsieur Poirot."

“Hercule,” I inquired, “what substance was contained within this small vial?” Hercule gazed out the window. “Strychnine hydrochloride,” he replied, never missing a beat. My reaction was subdued, as I had anticipated this revelation. “The pure form of strychnine hydrochloride is rarely utilized, primarily for medicinal purposes. The liquid solution is more commonly found in pharmaceuticals, explaining the undisturbed fingerprints.” Curious, I asked, “How were you able to capture this image?” Hercule shrugged nonchalantly, “I simply dropped my hat off the balcony.”

"I heard it was done recently, isn't that right?" "Yes, they were working on it yesterday afternoon. But let's go inside, Dorcas is waiting." "Well, well! Let me enjoy this sight for a moment." "Yes, but we have more pressing matters to discuss." "And who's to say these begonias aren't just as important?" I couldn't argue with him when he was in this mood. "You don't agree? But history has shown otherwise. Let's go talk to Dorcas." Dorcas stood in the boudoir, hands folded, with her grey hair tightly pulled back under her cap.

As the Revolution finally subsided, Colonel Race arrived in Cape Town. Following his suggestion, we all moved into the grand villa in Muizenberg once owned by Sir Lawrence Eardsley. Plans were made for my return to England with Suzanne, where we would marry at her London home. The trousseau was to be purchased in Paris, a task that Suzanne took great pleasure in organizing. Despite the excitement, the future appeared strangely distant. At times, a suffocating sensation gripped me, leaving me breathless. On the eve of our departure, sleep eluded me.

Sir James carefully folded the paper and stashed it in his pocket-book before surveying the dimly lit room. "Our young friend spent quite some time confined here, did they not?" he remarked. "A truly sinister place. Note the lack of windows and the solid door. Any activity within these walls would remain hidden from the outside world." Tuppence felt a chill run down her spine. His words stirred a sense of unease within her. What if there lurked someone inside the house? Someone who could lock them in and abandon them to their fate? The notion struck her as ludicrous.

"It was Mr. Inglethorp of the Hall, I thought there was no harm in it. He said it was to poison a dog.” The wretched young man wilted visibly under the Coroner’s frown. "Oh, no, sir of course not. It was only human nature to endeavour to please “The Hall” especially when it might result in custom being transferred from Coot’s to the local establishment. “Yes, sir, Mr. Inglethorp did so. “Is it not customary for anyone purchasing poison to sign a book?”

"I find the South African climate to be quite delightful." "I'm aware of the climate, having been there just before the war." "Thank you, Pedler. I'll have the package sent to General Smuts directly. As I made my way home, I pondered the intricate paths of governmental decisions.

Other footsteps trailed close behind them. As they approached Sir James's door, Tuppence grasped the bell while Jane took hold of the knocker. The mysterious man who had been following them reached the bottom of the steps, hesitating briefly before the door swung open. With a sense of urgency, they stumbled into the hallway together. Sir James emerged from the library, surprised by the commotion. Stepping forward, he wrapped his arm around Jane to steady her. Leading her into the library, he gently lowered her onto the plush sofa. Sir James reached for a tantalus on the nearby table, pouring a small amount of brandy and coaxing Jane to drink it.

I waited anxiously, but no one appeared. There was no sign of being trailed. I proceeded toward the open space, counting my steps. After six paces, I halted abruptly. A noise came from behind me, not from anyone tailing me, but from someone already present, lurking. Suddenly, a feeling of impending danger washed over me, an instinctual alarm similar to what I experienced on the Kilmorden that fateful evening. I quickly glanced back, only to be met with silence. Continuing forward, the rustle sounded once more. Persisting on my path, I glanced back again.

Nadina, the Russian dancer who had captivated Paris, gracefully acknowledged the applause and disappeared backstage. Her dressing room was filled with bouquets and luxurious garments, as Jeanne, her dresser, chattered on. A knock at the door interrupted them. The mysterious Count Sergius Paulovitch had arrived, a man of elegance and weariness. Switching to English, they discussed the 'Colonel,' a criminal mastermind planning his retirement. Nadina revealed her plan to travel to London incognito, arousing the Count's curiosity. He mentioned a fortune teller's prophecy about the 'Colonel's' downfall involving a woman, sparking Nadina's interest. They speculated on the 'Colonel's' future and the mysteries that lay ahead.

Surprisingly, my conscience suddenly became restless. It kept bothering me, reminding me of my Aunt Jane living way out West. The thought of her troubled me deeply. I had a feeling that Amos Finn was not going to turn his life around. So, I made a decision to hire someone to track her down. Unfortunately, the outcome was grim - both Aunt Jane and Amos Finn were found dead. However, they had a daughter named Jane who had survived the Lusitania disaster on her way to Paris. Despite her survival, no one on this side of the ocean seemed to know about her whereabouts. Feeling impatient with the lack of progress, I decided to take matters into my own hands and travel over to speed things up.

"Just as you prefer," Tommy answered. "I understand it's trendy to criticize the police. I personally have faith in them." He appeared completely relaxed. Tommy Beresford belonged to that category of young Englishmen lacking any exceptional intellectual prowess, yet excelling in challenging situations. Their innate shyness and carefulness vanish when under pressure. Tommy was fully aware that his only hope for survival rested in his own cleverness, and beneath his calm demeanor, he was frantically brainstorming.

"The issue you wish to discuss with him is grave?” “Absolutely! Last night, my uncle, who is my closest friend, was brutally murdered.” “Here in the city?” “No, in Yorkshire. I hurried upstairs and quickly briefed Poirot on the matter. He anticipated my next words. “I understand. You want to lead the investigation yourself, correct? Well, why not? "Surely there's a hidden escape route. Join me in the search," I suggested, taking a step back inside. Innocently, Poirot began to follow me. Suddenly, a realization hit me like a ton of bricks. I was betraying him, playing the role of Judas. "Stop, Poirot!" I yelled. "Go back. It's a setup. Save yourself. Forget about me. Escape now." Before I could finish my warning, strong hands seized me. A Chinese servant darted forward, aiming to capture Poirot.

"Given the later time of the crime, suspicion is deflected from the culprit. An interruption by Bella causes frustration and hastens his actions. Madame Renauld is bound and gagged, a mistake from the past corrected. The culprit's escape route is staged, leading to their own demise. The investigation unravels two crimes, one solved and the other a deeper mystery. Poirot's methodical approach triumphs over Giraud's incompetence. Madame Renauld's strength and deception to protect her son are commendable. The lead piping serves a sinister purpose, revealing the true killer. The focus shifts to Jack Renauld as the prime suspect. The mystery deepens with the discovery of the dagger."

"Given the timing of the crime, suspicion cannot be cast on him. His annoyance at the unexpected visit from Bella is evident, but he quickly gets rid of her. He binds and gags Madame Renauld, rectifying his past mistake. The night is cold as he buries the dead man, leaving clues against himself. His plan unravels when justice catches up to him. The unraveling of the case has been both perplexing and baffling. Poirot's brilliance shines through as he outwits his rivals. Madame Renauld's silent suffering reveals her strength as she protects her son's secret. The lead piping was used to disguise the victim's identity, a clue that led Poirot in the right direction. Now, the focus shifts to finding out who truly killed M. Renauld."

“I recognize the name, but it doesn’t ring a bell right now. "Your presence here tonight, Beresford, comes as quite a surprise to me. The last I knew, your friends were deeply concerned about your well-being. "Did I mention what caused Monsieur Lawrence to go as white as a sheet upon entering his mother's room that fateful night? That evening, Jarvis, my butler, informed me that a man, who refused to give his name, wanted to speak with me privately. Wary of insurance agents, I instructed Jarvis to turn him away. Guy Pagett, typically reliable, was unfortunately unwell with a bilious attack. It seemed that the hard-working young men often fell victim to such ailments. When Jarvis returned, he revealed, "The man says he is here on behalf of Mr. Milray." This unexpected connection changed everything.

"She lowered her gaze, seemingly filled with shame, and whispered in a trembling voice: “You can't, you can't... not if you knew.” Then, with sudden determination, she looked me straight in the eye and demanded: “What do you know?” “I know you visited Mr. Renauld that evening. He offered you a check which you tore up in a fit of rage. Perhaps you were feeling lost and wandered aimlessly, but regardless, just before midnight, you were still in the vicinity and spotted a figure on the golf course.” Once more, I fell silent."

"I'm about to share a different side of the story," I declared confidently. Harry's attention was unwavering as I detailed the same sequence of events chronicled in this book. After hearing his version of events, I finally understood the purpose behind Carton's clever scheme, or rather Nadina's, as I was convinced it was her ingenious plan all along. It became clear that no surprise attacks against her or her husband would lead to the recovery of the diamonds.

His expression remained stoic, perpetuating the unsettling aura that enveloped him. Mrs. Inglethorp descended the stairs last, her demeanor still marked by unease. Cynthia and I settled by the window in the drawing-room, where Mary Cavendish delivered our coffee, her demeanor betraying a sense of anticipation.

I woke up from a nightmare, a horrifying one where she was in grave danger. Alarmed, I rushed to her room to check on her safety. At half past six, a disguised Miss Howard arrives at the chemist’s shop pretending to be Alfred Inglethorp. She fabricates a story about a dog in order to acquire the deadly strychnine. With precision, she forges Alfred Inglethorp's name in John's handwriting, a skill she had meticulously practiced beforehand. To ensure John cannot provide an alibi, she cleverly crafts an anonymous note in his handwriting, luring him to a secluded location where his presence would go unnoticed. With her plan coming together seamlessly, Miss Howard departs for Middlingham while Alfred Inglethorp makes his way back to Styles.

I must admit that after the first jolt of the Kilmorden, I quickly retreated below deck. A kind stewardess took me in, recommending dry toast and ginger ale. For three days, I remained confined to my cabin, consumed by misery. My passion for solving mysteries had vanished, leaving behind a shell of the once eager Anne who had rushed to South Kensington. Now, as I reflect on my return, I can't help but smile at the memory of Mrs. Flemming in the drawing-room, waiting to speak with me.

"But you are quite the cunning one. You seek my assistance yet leave behind the crimson herring on the path." Japp erupted in laughter. "That's your signature move, Mr. Poirot. Yes, I'd place my bet on the Chink, I confess. It only makes sense that he tampered with the curry, and if he attempted once to remove his master from the equation, he may attempt again." "I ponder if he would," murmured Poirot. "But it's the underlying reason that perplexes me. Perhaps some form of heathen vengeance." "I ponder," Poirot repeated. "There hasn't been a theft? Nothing has vanished? No gems, nor cash, nor documents?" "No, not precisely.

I rolled my eyes. There was no use arguing with him when he got like this. It occurred to me, not for the first time, that Poirot was starting to show his age. Thankfully, I was there to balance out his fading faculties. Poirot watched me with a twinkle in his eye. “You're not happy with me, my friend?” “Poirot,” I replied icily, “I would never presume to tell you what to do. You're entitled to your own opinions, just as I am to mine.” “A most commendable attitude,” Poirot said, standing up quickly.

“I am quite superstitious. Luck, fate, all that jazz. It seems like destiny has singled you out to be involved in all of this.” Tommy let out a chuckle. “Goodness me! I can only imagine Whittington’s reaction when Tuppence dropped that name! I would have been startled myself. But listen, sir, we’ve been taking up so much of your time. Do you have any advice for us before we head out?” “I believe not. My specialists, following ordinary procedures, have not succeeded. You will need to bring creativity and an open mind to the mission. Even if that doesn't work, don’t lose hope. There’s a chance things will escalate quickly.” Tuppence looked puzzled.

"Evidently, he was correct!” With tears welling up, she bid us a composed goodbye. Poirot, walking alongside me, made his usual gesture. “Well, that settles it! Let's return to London, my dear friend, as it seems there is no mystery to solve here. But” “But what?” “Just a small inconsistency, nothing more! Did you catch it? No? The tale stirred my new secretary, Rayburn, who appeared visibly moved. Anne Beddingfeld's curiosity about Rayburn was evident, prompting me to share a brief explanation.

The focus shifted towards achieving peace rather than escalating conflict. However, the Cabinet was acutely aware of the perilously close call they had narrowly averted. Mr. Carter couldn't shake the haunting memory of the bizarre incident that unfolded in the Soho residence the previous evening.

In the corner by the fire-place stood a large writing-table. A man, or what once was a man, sat at the table. His right hand clutched the telephone base, but he lay forward, felled by a brutal blow to the head from behind. The murder weapon was easily found - a marble statuette with a bloodstained base. The doctor’s swift examination confirmed the worst. "Stone dead. Death was quick. Surprising he even had time to make a call. Best not to disturb the body until the police come." Following the manager's advice, we combed through the apartment, but the outcome was inevitable.

He stared at me, a sly smile playing on his lips. "You've erred, haven't you?" I shook my head. "I highly doubt it." "You've handed me the incorrect scroll. This one is unexposed." I exited with all the poise I could gather. It's humbling to recognize one's own foolishness from time to time! But no one enjoys the revelation. As I passed by a prominent shipping company, I abruptly stopped. A stunning replica of the company's ship, labeled "Kenilworth Castle," caught my eye. A reckless notion crossed my mind. Without hesitation, I pushed the door open and stepped inside.

I bid farewell to the familiar world. Despite my best efforts, my response quivered slightly. "Once and for all, no! Your letter can go to hell!" Rarely does a person find themselves on the brink of eternity, yet as I uttered those words in the depths of that East End cellar, I was convinced they would be my final ones. I steeled myself for the impending rush of dark waters below, anticipating the suffocating terror of the plummet. To my astonishment, a soft chuckle reached my ears, prompting me to open my eyes.

"At what time should we commence?" "The stroke of midnight holds an air of solemnity and seems fitting, I believe. It is unlikely that anything will transpire before then." Promptly at twelve o’clock, we stealthily entered the coal-lift and descended to the second level. With Poirot's deft touch, the wooden door swung open swiftly, granting us access to the apartment. Moving from the scullery to the kitchen, we settled comfortably in two chairs, leaving the door to the hall slightly ajar. "Now, all that remains is to wait," Poirot remarked contently, closing his eyes. The wait felt interminable to me, as I dreaded the thought of succumbing to sleep.

Ventnor, who had stayed in cabin C 24 adjacent to Philip Ridgeway's, had intrigued me with Poirot's deductions about his existence and appearance. Frustrated, I pointed out how the information contradicted Poirot's theory, but he simply grinned and remarked, "As usual, you see nothing, Hastings."

When I considered it, did anyone ever bother to include the year when writing a date? If 17 was code for Cabin 17, then what about 1? Perhaps one o'clock. In that case, 22 must be the date. Glancing at my pocket almanac, I saw that tomorrow was indeed the 22nd. My excitement grew. It seemed I had finally uncovered the correct path. One thing was certain - I could not leave the cabin. The stench of asafœtida had to be endured. Reviewing my clues once more, I deduced that something was set to occur on the 22nd at 1 a.m. or 1 p.m. I leaned towards 1 a.m. It was currently seven o'clock. In six hours, the truth would be revealed. The following hours were a blur.

My father had never shown me love, that much I understood. Had he shown me affection, perhaps I would have reciprocated. There was no love between us, but we were connected, and I had taken care of him, silently admiring his intelligence and unwavering dedication to science. It pained me that my father passed away at a time when life held the most fascination for him.

"They're not the hands of a gentleman," he stated, in response to my gaze. "In fact, his attire suggests he's a man of means. Quite intriguing, wouldn't you say?" "Intriguing indeed," I concurred. "And there's no identifiable markings on any of his clothes. What can we deduce from that? This individual was attempting to present himself as someone else. He was pretending. But why? Was he running from something? Was he trying to evade capture by assuming a different persona? At this point, we can only speculate. However, one thing is certain - he was just as determined to hide his true self as we are to uncover it."

Poirot and I quickly discussed the situation before he hurried away. I patted him on the back, acknowledging his success. "They've revealed the hiding spot to you, haven't they? But you must send a wire to France immediately. Going in person will be too slow." Poirot gave me a puzzled look. "Some things, my friend, cannot be communicated through telegrams." Just then, Major Norman came back with a Flying Corps officer, Captain Lyall, who would be flying Poirot to France.

"Monsieur le juge, he died of an epileptic fit, if I am not mistaken," declared Poirot, causing a stir. Dr. Durand conducted a thorough examination and then stood up. "So, Doctor?" inquired Poirot. "I must agree with you, Monsieur Poirot. I was initially misled by the stabbing, but now I see the truth," admitted Dr. Durand. Poirot basked in the praise, becoming the center of attention. The examining magistrate showered him with compliments.

No one was staying in the house that night, keeping me occupied in Mr. Ryland's study until late. Anticipating this, I knew I wouldn't make it to the station to meet Poirot. But I was certain I would be free before eleven. Just as I predicted, at ten-thirty, Mr. Ryland signaled the end of our meeting. I excused myself and left discreetly. Pretending to head to bed, I snuck down a back staircase and slipped out into the garden, wearing a dark overcoat to conceal my white shirt-front.

"That's fine," Poirot assured, "he's a friend of mine." We proceeded upstairs in unison. Seated in a chair near the window was a worn-out young man who appeared to be on the brink of collapse. Poirot approached him. "Are you John Halliday?" The man nodded. "Let me see your left arm. John Halliday has a mole just below his left elbow." The man extended his arm. The mole was indeed there. Poirot nodded to the countess. She turned and exited the room. A glass of brandy helped revive Halliday slightly. "My God!" he whispered. "I've been through hell... Those fiends are pure evil. My wife, where is she? What does she know? They told me she would believe... " "She doesn't," Poirot stated firmly.

The hallway was deserted. Without hesitation, I swiftly made my way to the door, opened it, and stepped out into the bright sunlight. I sprinted down the driveway with a sense of urgency. Once I reached the open road, I slowed my pace to a casual stroll. Onlookers gazed at me with curiosity, undoubtedly noting the layer of dust that clung to my face and clothes, evidence of my recent escapade in the attic. Eventually, I arrived at a nearby garage and entered. "I've been in a bit of a mishap," I informed the attendant. "I require a vehicle to transport me to Cape Town immediately. I have a ship to catch in Durban." It wasn't long before my request was fulfilled.

The Villa was shrouded in darkness, the inhabitants fast asleep. As we stood below Mrs. Renauld’s open window, a cry for help pierced the night. Poirot sprang into action, rushing to the front door, then scaling a tree with feline grace to enter through the window. The scene inside was chaotic, with Mrs. Renauld barely clinging to life. The true culprit, Marthe Daubreuil, lay dead on the ground, a victim of her own twisted plot. The events of that night unfolded like a macabre dance, revealing a web of deceit and greed that only Poirot could untangle.

"Moving on, let's discuss something else. Did your mistress own a dark green gown in her collection?" Dorcas was taken aback by the sudden inquiry. "No, sir." "Are you certain?" "Absolutely, sir." "Is there anyone else in the household who possesses a green garment?" Dorcas pondered. "Miss Cynthia has a light green evening dress." "Is it a light or dark shade of green?" "It's a light green, sir; a type of chiffon material." "I see, that's not what I'm looking for. And no one else owns anything green?" "No, sir, not to my knowledge." Poirot's expression remained inscrutable, revealing nothing of his feelings.

Dressed identically to his attire in London, he always kept a small clothes-brush in his pocket to combat the dust that clung to his dark clothing. “And my boots,” he lamented. “Look at them, Hastings. My boots, usually gleaming patent leather, now filled with sand both inside and out, a painful sight. In addition, this heat is causing my once impeccable moustaches to droop in defeat!” “But look at the Sphinx,” I suggested. “Even I can sense the enigmatic allure it emits.” Poirot gazed at it disapprovingly. “It appears quite unhappy,” he observed. “Partially buried in sand in such a disorderly manner, how could it not be?”

I was relieved when the man, Chichester, and the Dutchman left the house. I waited for a while before making my move. The hall was empty, so I quickly unlatched the door and stepped outside into the sunshine. I ran down the drive and headed towards Cape Town. After a short while, I reached a garage and asked for a car to take me to catch the boat to Durban. I had to find out if Chichester was on board. As I drove towards the docks, I realized that the Kilmorden Castle was already sailing away. My only hope was to sail after him and confront him about the diamonds. I decided to sail to Durban and see what awaited me there.

"We won't waste time. Take him out! Take him out!" The crowd erupted into cheers. "Do you understand?" the German demanded, staring at Tommy. "Any last words?" Tommy nonchalantly shrugged. "Bunch of idiots. They should be asking the real questions. How did I even find this place? Remember what Conrad mentioned along with your secret code, right? How did I even obtain that? You think I just stumbled upon these stairs and blurted out the first thing that came to mind?" Tommy smirked, satisfied with his closing statement.

We made it to shore safely, though my wet clothes clung uncomfortably to my body. Despite the rough terrain ahead, we had to press on towards Livingstone. The journey was grueling, with my skirts tearing on thorns and my stockings long gone. Eventually, I had to stop from sheer exhaustion. Harry, ever the gentleman, offered to carry me for a while. And so, I found myself arriving in Livingstone draped over his shoulder like a piece of luggage. How he managed to carry me all that way, I will never understand.

"Ten minutes passed before the door creaked open, revealing a slim figure dressed in mourning attire. 'Monsieur Poirot?' she hesitated. Poirot gallantly rose to his feet and hurried to her side. 'Madame!' he exclaimed. 'I apologize for the intrusion. But alas, business knows no bounds.' Mrs. Maltravers allowed him to guide her to a chair. Her eyes were swollen from crying, yet her beauty shone through. She appeared to be in her late twenties, fair-skinned with piercing blue eyes and a delicate mouth."

"It's probably quite pleasant for Clarence to have you as his spouse." "I'm quite a handful to live with! But he can always retreat to the Foreign Office, where he adjusts his monocle, settles into a large armchair, and dozes off. Perhaps we should telegram him and inquire about Race. I do enjoy sending telegrams. They tend to vex Clarence. He always insists a letter would suffice. I doubt he would divulge much, though. He is incredibly discreet. It's precisely this quality that makes cohabitation with him unbearable for extended periods. Nonetheless, let's continue with our matchmaking."

With the ability to feign emotions, she mirrors her mother's cold, calculating nature. It's unclear if she truly believed in her control over the boy's feelings. Though she charmed him, the boy could easily be pulled away by his father. However, with Mr. Renauld's demise and Jack inheriting a large portion of his fortune, the marriage becomes imminent. In a single move, she will secure wealth far beyond the meager sums she has managed to obtain thus far. Her sharp mind grasps the straightforwardness of the situation. It all seems effortless.

"I've got a cousin who is a nurse," I mentioned. "And she is absolutely terrified of 'Sisters'."  "I can see why. Sisters are quite intimidating, Mr. Hastings. You've no idea! But I'm not a nurse, thank goodness, I work in the pharmacy."  "How many people do you poison?" I inquired, with a grin.   Cynthia grinned back. "Oh, hundreds!" she replied.  "Cynthia," Mrs. Inglethorp called out, "could you jot down a few notes for me?"  "Of course, Aunt Emily." Cynthia stood up immediately, and there was something in her demeanor that hinted at her subordinate position, and that Mrs. Inglethorp, as kind as she might be, never let her forget it.  My hostess then turned to me.

I arrived at the edge of the cliff, overlooking the vast ocean below, far from any signs of civilization. A young boy with a friendly smile greeted me at the door. "Are you here to see Mrs. Raffini?" he asked. Leading me through a narrow hallway, he opened a door for me. As I prepared to enter, a feeling of unease washed over me. Ignoring my instincts, I crossed the threshold and the door closed abruptly behind me. A man stood up from his desk, approaching me with a welcoming smile. "We are delighted you decided to join us, Miss Thompson," he said.

And what choice did I have? None. In just fifteen minutes, I would be departing from the station, leaving Pagett behind as he waved goodbye. He had managed to outmaneuver me skillfully. Furthermore, his attitude towards me had shifted. It was filled with a forced friendliness that didn't suit him, making my stomach turn. This man was a deceitful hypocrite. After attempting to kill me, he now showered me with flattery! Did he really think I didn't recognize him that fateful night on the boat? No, it was all an act, one that he expected me to go along with, all the while hiding his true intentions.

"But imagine if you had actually married that little doctor of yours. It's a good thing you didn't - he doesn't seem like the type who would appreciate having explosives lying around the house! Are you planning to inform Lord Nasby about this?" I shook my head. "Yet you still think he's innocent?" "I've seen innocent people get punished before." "Well, Anne, you need to accept the possibility. Despite your beliefs, he could very well be the one who committed this murder." "No," I stated firmly. "He's not the one." "You're letting your emotions cloud your judgment." "No, I'm not. He may have had a reason to harm her, but he didn't."

Anne Beddingfeld was tired of the monotony of her life. Her father, Professor Beddingfeld, was completely engrossed in studying Primitive Man, leaving Anne to handle the practicalities of everyday life. She despised anything related to Palaeolithic Man, despite her involvement in typing and revising her father's work on Neanderthal Man. The absence of her mother since childhood added to the sense of sameness in her life. But Anne always longed for some excitement, a break from the mundane routine that consumed her days.

At the start of January, a month filled with detestable fog, a woman reveals her daring plan to blackmail the elusive 'Colonel' with unique diamonds hidden away from prying eyes. Despite her confidence, a mysterious man warns her of underestimating the 'Colonel's' wrath, hinting at a potential threat from her past. As she prepares to face the powerful 'Colonel,' she confides in the man about a husband from her native South Africa who will stand by her side. With secrets and danger lurking around every corner, she must tread carefully in a high-stakes game of deception and betrayal.

"All women do." "Will they be practicing low jumps?" I inquired, chuckling. "No, I'm afraid not. I need to head to Durban." Sir Eustace glanced at me, let out a heavy sigh, then opened the door to the next room and called for Pagett. "If you're done with your nap, my friend, how about working for a change?" Guy Pagett entered the room. He nodded to both of us, looking surprised at the sight of me, and responded in a somber tone: "I've been typing that memo all afternoon, Sir Eustace." "Then stop typing it."

Carter’?” Tommy whispered a name in her ear. “Oh!” exclaimed Tuppence, impressed. “And let me tell you, old chap, he’s something else!” “Oh!” echoed Tuppence once more. Then she mused, “I quite like him, don’t you? He seems so worn out and disinterested, yet you sense that deep down he’s as sharp as a razor, full of energy. Oh!” She did a little jump. “Tommy, pinch me. Pinch me, please. I can’t believe this is happening!” Mr. Beresford complied. “Ouch! That’s sufficient! Yes, we’re wide awake. We’ve landed a gig!” “And what a gig! The partnership is off to a great start.” “It’s more legitimate than I anticipated,” Tuppence remarked thoughtfully.

Harry took a moment to collect his thoughts before continuing. "I was deeply in love with her, so much so that it scared her at times. But his love for her was different - quieter, yet more profound. She was his everything, and her betrayal shattered his world. The pain was so intense, it left him unable to move." Harry fell silent for a moment, then resumed speaking. "You see, I was declared 'Missing, presumed dead.' I never bothered to correct the mistake. I adopted the alias Parker and sought refuge on this familiar island. Initially, I had hoped to clear my name during the war, but now that determination had faded."

The waiting game was all too familiar. A quick glance at the Robinson listing in the phone book was all it took to confirm suspicions. It was only a matter of time before a fair-haired Mrs. Robinson would make an appearance. And when she did, the avenger would not be far behind. Armed with a name and address, vengeance would be swift. Miss Elsa Hardt, as always, narrowly escaping her fate. Oh, Hastings, the introduction to the true Mrs. Robinson will be quite the affair! The shock of a break-in awaiting them at home. We must make haste.

I arrived at my destination with little information to go on. The commander's orders were clear - I was to be dropped off at a specific location along the Belgian coast. After that, I was on my own. It felt surreal, like a scene from a movie. But I knew in my heart that everything was part of Poirot's grand scheme. So, I moved forward without hesitation, placing my trust in my departed friend. Once I reached the designated spot, a waiting car whisked me away, speeding across the flat Flemish plains. That evening, I found myself in a cozy inn in Brussels. The following day, our journey continued, leading us through lush, wooded hills.
